description.overview: 25B-NBOMe (2C-B-NBOMe) is a potent synthetic psychedelic from the NBOMe series, derived from 2C-B. Often sold as 'LSD' or '2C-B' on blotter. Produces intense visuals but with significant dangers. Multiple deaths reported. Bitter/metallic taste and severe tongue numbness. Active at sub-milligram doses. Less common than 25I or 25C but equally dangerous.
description.origins: Synthesized in 2003 by Ralf Heim for research, never intended for human use. Appeared on research chemical market around 2010-2011 as part of NBOMe series. Less popular than 25I-NBOMe but still caused deaths and hospitalizations. Emergency scheduled along with other NBOMes 2013-2016 depending on country. Often confused with actual 2C-B despite being much more dangerous.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense visual hallucinations, stimulation, sometimes sold as '2C-B' or 'LSD.' Typical dose 500-1000mcg. Effects 6-10 hours. Some users thought they were getting safer 2C-B but received dangerous NBOMe instead. Less sought-after than 25I-NBOMe but still appeared on blotter. Testing essential—cannot distinguish from LSD or 2C-B by appearance.
description.dangers: CAN BE FATAL—deaths reported though less common than 25I-NBOMe. Severe vasoconstriction, seizures, hyperthermia, cardiovascular stress. More dangerous than the 2C-B it's derived from. Bitter/metallic taste and tongue numbness (2C-B powder also bitter but NBOMe on blotter shouldn't be). Ehrlich shows NO reaction (differentiates from LSD). Unpredictable potency—deaths from doses thought to be safe. Often mis-sold as actual 2C-B or LSD. Physical effects dangerous: increased heart rate/BP, stroke risk. Psychological: anxiety, panic, bad trips. CRITICAL: Test all blotter with Ehrlich. If bitter on blotter, SPIT OUT.

scientific_papers.summary: Review of NBOMe series including 25B-NBOMe, documenting toxicity and deaths

notes: DANGEROUS: Often mis-sold as 2C-B or LSD. Bitter/numbing taste on blotter. Can be fatal. Ehrlich test shows NO reaction (unlike LSD).

description.overview: Alprazolam (Xanax) is a fast-acting, potent benzodiazepine prescribed for anxiety and panic disorders. Produces relaxation, sedation, and anxiolytic (anti-anxiety) effects. One of the most prescribed and most abused benzos due to rapid onset and euphoric effects at higher doses. Street 'Xanax' pills frequently counterfeit and contain fentanyl, other benzos (flualprazolam, etizolam), or no active ingredient.
description.origins: Developed by Upjohn (now Pfizer) in late 1960s, FDA-approved 1981. Became one of most prescribed psychiatric medications in US. Short half-life (6-12 hours) makes it effective for acute anxiety but also increases addiction potential. Available in immediate-release tablets (0.25mg to 2mg) and extended-release (Xanax XR). 'Bars' (2mg) became street drug of choice in 2000s-2010s, often combined with opioids or alcohol.
description.uses: Medical: Anxiety disorders, panic disorder, anxiety associated with depression. Short-term use recommended due to tolerance and dependence. Rapid relief of acute anxiety/panic attacks. Recreational: Sedation, disinhibition, euphoria (at high doses), blackout experiences, combining with opioids or alcohol ('lean'). Popular in hip-hop culture. Pressed counterfeit pills widely available on street/dark web. Typical prescribed dose 0.25-2mg; recreational users often take 4-10mg+ leading to blackouts and dangerous behavior.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE—physical dependence develops within weeks. Withdrawal can be FATAL (seizures, delirium tremens)—requires medical supervision to safely discontinue. Blackouts and amnesia common at recreational doses leading to dangerous behavior, accidents, sexual assault. Combining with opioids or alcohol frequently FATAL (respiratory depression). Counterfeit 'Xanax' bars often contain fentanyl—numerous overdose deaths. Pressed pills may contain flualprazolam (longer-acting, more sedating RC benzo) or other research chemicals. Tolerance develops rapidly requiring higher doses. Cognitive impairment, motor coordination issues increase fall/accident risk. Paradoxical reactions possible (increased anxiety, aggression). Rebound anxiety when stopping. Elderly particularly vulnerable to falls, confusion, dementia-like symptoms. Reagent tests don't work on benzos—fentanyl test strips essential for any street pills.

scientific_papers.journal: Expert Opinion on Drug Metabolism & Toxicology
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of alprazolam's high addiction potential and withdrawal management

description.overview: Bromo-DragonFLY (DOB-DragonFLY) is an extremely potent and dangerous synthetic psychedelic with an extraordinarily long duration of 18-36+ hours. Named for its molecular structure resembling a dragonfly, it has been responsible for multiple deaths due to overdose, extreme vasoconstriction, and being mis-sold as other substances. Active in sub-milligram doses with a very narrow safety margin.
description.origins: Synthesized in 1998 by Matthew Parker at Purdue University as part of research on serotonin receptor binding. Never intended for human consumption. Appeared on the recreational market in the mid-2000s, often mis-sold as 2C-B-FLY or LSD. Multiple deaths and severe injuries in 2008-2009 led to emergency scheduling in many countries. Remains available but rare.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense, extremely long-lasting psychedelic experiences. Effects can persist 24-36 hours or longer. Some users sought it for its unique visual and mental effects, but extreme duration, narrow dosing window, and severe dangers have made it highly discouraged by harm reduction communities. Often consumed unknowingly when sold as safer substances.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS—multiple deaths and serious injuries reported. Causes severe vasoconstriction leading to tissue necrosis, limb amputation, seizures, hyperthermia, and death. Duration of 18-36+ hours makes bad trips prolonged nightmares. Extremely dose-sensitive: difference between threshold and dangerous dose is tiny (200-800mcg range). Often mis-sold as 2C-B-FLY, LSD, or other psychedelics. Onset can take 2-6 hours, leading users to redose and overdose fatally. Physiological effects include extreme vasoconstriction, tissue damage, potential organ failure. Psychological effects: terror, confusion, psychosis lasting days. No antidote. Medical intervention may be required for days. Considered one of the most dangerous research chemicals. AVOID—multiple safer alternatives exist.

notes: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS: Multiple deaths. Extreme vasoconstriction, 18-36+ hour duration. Often mis-sold. AVOID. Reagent tests cannot distinguish from 2C-B-FLY.

description.overview: Clonazepam (Klonopin) is a long-acting benzodiazepine prescribed for anxiety, panic disorder, and seizures. Duration 6-12 hours, long half-life (30-40 hours) means effects accumulate. More potent than diazepam. High abuse potential. Widely prescribed and frequently diverted. Known for causing severe dependence and difficult withdrawal.
description.origins: Developed by Hoffmann-La Roche, introduced 1975. FDA-approved for seizures, panic disorder. Became widely prescribed for anxiety despite recommendations for short-term use only. Generic versions available. Schedule IV controlled substance. Common in medical settings and street markets. Often prescribed long-term despite addiction risks.
description.uses: Medical: Panic disorder, anxiety disorders, seizure disorders (especially absence seizures), akathisia, acute mania. Typical dose 0.5-2mg for anxiety, up to 20mg for seizures. Duration 6-12 hours. Recreational/diverted: Anxiety relief, sedation, euphoria (mild), sleep aid, potentiating opioids (dangerous), managing stimulant comedowns. Popular among those with anxiety or opioid use disorder.
description.dangers: Severe physical dependence—withdrawal can be FATAL (seizures, delirium). Long half-life means effects accumulate and withdrawal delayed. Cognitive impairment, memory issues, 'benzo fog.' Respiratory depression when combined with opioids/alcohol—FATAL. Blackouts, amnesia at higher doses. Dangerous driving impairment. Tolerance develops. Extremely difficult withdrawal (worse than many benzos due to long half-life). Counterfeit Klonopin may contain other benzos, RC benzos, or fentanyl.

scientific_papers.title: Clonazepam in panic disorder: Clinical efficacy and withdrawal
scientific_papers.summary: Study of clonazepam efficacy and dependence issues

notes: Klonopin. Long-acting benzo (6-12 hr effects, 30-40 hr half-life). Benzos show NO reagent reaction. Effects accumulate over days. Withdrawal FATAL—never stop cold turkey. More potent than Valium. Very difficult withdrawal due to long half-life. Often diverted. Counterfeit pills may contain RC benzos or fentanyl. Never combine with opioids or alcohol.

description.overview: Diazepam (Valium) is a long-acting benzodiazepine prescribed for anxiety, muscle spasms, seizures, and alcohol withdrawal. One of the first benzos developed (1963) and still widely used. Long half-life (20-100 hours including active metabolites) provides sustained effects. Less potent than alprazolam—10mg diazepam ≈ 0.5mg alprazolam. Common in medical settings. High abuse and diversion potential.
description.origins: Synthesized by Leo Sternbach at Hoffmann-La Roche in 1959, marketed 1963. Became one of most prescribed medications globally by 1970s. Cultural icon—'mother's little helper' (Rolling Stones song 1966). Widely prescribed for anxiety, muscle spasms, seizures. Schedule IV controlled substance. Generic since patent expiration. Still extensively prescribed despite newer benzos. Common diversion and black market availability.
description.uses: Medical: Anxiety disorders, panic attacks, muscle spasms, seizures (status epilepticus), alcohol withdrawal (detox protocol), pre-surgical sedation. Typical dose 2-10mg for anxiety, up to 40mg for alcohol withdrawal. Recreational: Anxiety relief, sedation, muscle relaxation, euphoria (mild), sleep aid, potentiating other drugs. Duration 6-8 hours but metabolites active 20-100 hours. Popular for comedowns from stimulants.
description.dangers: Physical dependence develops with regular use—withdrawal can be FATAL (seizures, delirium). Long half-life means withdrawal symptoms delayed 2-7 days after stopping, lasting weeks. Respiratory depression when combined with opioids, alcohol, or other CNS depressants. Cognitive impairment, memory issues ('benzo fog'). Blackouts at higher doses. Dangerous driving impairment. Tolerance develops. Paradoxical reactions (increased anxiety, aggression). Elderly at high risk for falls, confusion, cognitive decline. Long-term use linked to dementia. Counterfeit Valium may contain other substances.

scientific_papers.title: Diazepam: 50 years of clinical use
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of diazepam's 50-year history in medicine

notes: Valium. Classic long-acting benzo. Benzodiazepines show NO reagent reaction. Pharmaceutical pills should match databases exactly. Long half-life (20-100 hours with metabolites) means effects last much longer than dose suggests. Less potent than Xanax (10mg Valium = 0.5mg Xanax). Withdrawal FATAL—never stop cold turkey. Common in medical detox protocols. Often diverted. Never combine with opioids or alcohol.

description.overview: Etizolam is a thienodiazepine, chemically related to benzodiazepines but not technically a benzodiazepine. Produces similar effects: anxiety relief, sedation, muscle relaxation, amnesia. Prescribed in Japan, India, and Italy but not FDA-approved in US. Widely available as research chemical. Frequently found in counterfeit Xanax bars and sold as 'legal' benzo alternative. Shorter half-life than most benzos (6-8 hours). Potency similar to alprazolam (Xanax). Extremely addictive with dangerous withdrawal.
description.origins: First synthesized in Japan in 1980s. Approved as prescription medication in Japan, India, and Italy for anxiety and sleep disorders. Remained obscure in West until 2010s research chemical boom. Became popular as 'legal' benzodiazepine alternative in countries where it's unscheduled. Exploded in popularity 2015-present as Xanax substitute. Frequently pressed into fake Xanax bars. Scheduled in many US states and some countries but remains unscheduled federally in US (as of 2024). Easy online availability. Often combined with opioids (dangerous). Popular in hip-hop/SoundCloud rap culture.
description.uses: Medical (Japan/India/Italy): Anxiety disorders, insomnia, panic attacks. Typical therapeutic dose 0.5-2mg. Recreational/self-medication: Anxiety relief, sedation, euphoria (some users), sleep aid, alcohol-like intoxication. Typical recreational dose 1-4mg. Duration 5-8 hours. Popular among those seeking Xanax effects legally or cheaply. Often combined with opioids (extremely dangerous—respiratory depression). Blacked-out behavior and amnesia common at higher doses. Some users compulsively redose. Pressed into fake Xanax bars—users often don't know they're taking etizolam.
description.dangers: SEVERE ADDICTION AND WITHDRAWAL: Physical dependence develops rapidly (days to weeks). Withdrawal can be FATAL—seizures, delirium tremens, psychosis. NEVER stop abruptly after regular use—taper required. Respiratory depression when combined with opioids, alcohol, or other CNS depressants—many deaths. Blackouts and amnesia common—users wake up in jail, hospitals, or worse with no memory. Compulsive redosing while blacked out. Disinhibition leads to dangerous behavior. Impaired driving. Found in counterfeit Xanax—users don't know what they're taking or dosing. Tolerance develops quickly. Often adulterated with fentanyl in pressed pills. Harm reduction extremely difficult due to blackouts.

scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of etizolam prevalence in fake Xanax pills seized by law enforcement

scientific_papers.title: Etizolam dependence and withdrawal
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports of severe etizolam withdrawal syndrome

scientific_papers.title: Designer benzodiazepines: An emerging threat
scientific_papers.summary: Review of etizolam and other RC benzos in drug supply

notes: CRITICAL: Benzodiazepines and analogues (including etizolam) do NOT react with standard colorimetric reagents. No color change = cannot confirm or rule out benzos. Frequently found in COUNTERFEIT XANAX BARS. Withdrawal can be FATAL—never stop cold turkey. Test pills with fentanyl strips—fake bars often contain fentanyl. Verify pharmaceutical pills with pill ID databases. Etizolam blacked-out behavior extremely common. Not technically a benzodiazepine but acts like one. Legal status varies by region.

fentanyl_strips.summary: MANDATORY for any pressed benzo pills. Fake Xanax frequently contains fentanyl.

pill_databases.summary: Etizolam rarely comes in pharmaceutical pills in US. If pill looks like Xanax but isn't from YOUR prescription, likely fake containing etizolam, flualprazolam, or fentanyl.

description.overview: Flualprazolam is an extremely potent designer benzodiazepine, ~2x stronger than alprazolam (Xanax). Not approved for medical use anywhere. Produces intense sedation, amnesia, and muscle relaxation. Longer duration than Xanax (8-12 hours). Frequently found in counterfeit Xanax bars. Causes severe blackouts and compulsive redosing. Extremely addictive with life-threatening withdrawal. One of most dangerous research chemical benzos.
description.origins: Research chemical first appearing on online markets around 2017-2018. Never approved for medical use. Specifically designed as more potent Xanax alternative. Rapidly gained popularity in RC benzo scene. Frequently pressed into fake Xanax bars (often alongside etizolam or fentanyl). Seized in large quantities by law enforcement. Emergency scheduling in many jurisdictions 2020-2021. China production. Still widely available despite scheduling. Became notorious for extreme blackouts and dangerous behavior.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational/self-medication: Extreme anxiety relief, sedation, sleep aid, Xanax-like effects but stronger and longer. Typical dose 0.5-1mg (very potent—compare to Xanax 1-2mg). Duration 8-12 hours. Mostly consumed unknowingly in fake Xanax bars. Intentional use among RC benzo community. Extreme blackouts common—users report losing entire days. Compulsive redosing while blacked out. Often combined with opioids (deadly). Popular in addiction and poly-substance use contexts.
description.dangers: EXTREME DANGER: Ultra-potent—easy to overdose. Severe blackouts lasting 12-24+ hours—users wake up in jail, hospitals, with no memory of actions. Compulsive redosing during blackouts leads to massive doses. Respiratory depression when combined with opioids/alcohol—FATAL. Physical dependence develops extremely rapidly. Withdrawal can be FATAL—seizures, delirium, death. NEVER stop cold turkey—medical taper required. Disinhibition causes dangerous, criminal behavior. Found in fake Xanax bars—users don't know dosage or what they're taking. Often contains fentanyl as well. Tolerance builds fast. Harm reduction nearly impossible due to blackout potential.

scientific_papers.title: Flualprazolam: A new designer benzodiazepine
scientific_papers.summary: First forensic analysis of flualprazolam in counterfeit pharmaceuticals

scientific_papers.title: Designer benzodiazepines and their prevalence in drug-facilitated crimes
scientific_papers.summary: Study showing flualprazolam in fake Xanax and associated with blackouts/crimes

notes: EXTREME DANGER: ~2x more potent than Xanax, longer duration, extreme blackouts. Benzodiazepines show NO reagent reaction—cannot test with colorimetric reagents. Frequently in FAKE XANAX BARS. Test with fentanyl strips—often contains fentanyl. Withdrawal can be FATAL. Compulsive redosing during blackouts common—users take entire bottles unknowingly. If pill looks like Xanax but isn't from YOUR prescription at pharmacy, assume it's fake containing flualprazolam, etizolam, or fentanyl. DO NOT mix with opioids or alcohol—respiratory depression FATAL.

fentanyl_strips.summary: CRITICAL for any street Xanax bars. Many fake bars contain fentanyl in addition to flualprazolam.

pill_verification.summary: Flualprazolam not approved anywhere—all pills are counterfeit. If it looks like Xanax but isn't pharmaceutical, it's fake.

description.overview: Phenibut (β-phenyl-GABA) is a GABA-B receptor agonist developed in Russia for anxiety, sold as unregulated dietary supplement in US. Produces anxiety relief, sociability, mild euphoria, and improved sleep. Not a benzodiazepine but has similar effects. Legal and widely available online. Marketed as nootropic/cognitive enhancer. Addiction potential severely underestimated by users.
description.origins: Developed in 1960s Soviet Union for cosmonauts to reduce stress without sedation impairment. Prescription medication in Russia, Latvia, Ukraine (trade names: Noofen, Anvifen). Remains unscheduled in US, UK, and most Western countries. Sold as dietary supplement despite not being approved by FDA. Became popular in nootropic/biohacking communities in 2010s. Reddit, Longecity forums popularized use.
description.uses: Medical (in Russia): Anxiety disorders, insomnia, PTSD, alcohol withdrawal. Typical dose 250-1000mg. Supplement use: Anxiety relief, social anxiety reduction, sleep aid, mood enhancement. Some users report improved sociability and reduced social inhibition (similar to alcohol but without intoxication). Popular for public speaking, dates, interviews. Effects: 2-4 hours onset, 15-24 hour duration. Recreational: Euphoria at higher doses (2-3g+), combining with alcohol or other drugs (dangerous).
description.dangers: SEVERE PHYSICAL DEPENDENCE develops with daily use (even at recommended doses). Withdrawal can be DANGEROUS: seizures, psychosis, hallucinations, severe anxiety, insomnia, agitation. Withdrawal worse than many report—can last weeks. Tolerance develops rapidly requiring dose escalation. Long half-life (5-6 hours) but effects last much longer—easy to redose and overdose. Combining with alcohol or other depressants dangerous (respiratory depression). Liver toxicity possible with chronic use. Very difficult to quit once dependent—requires slow taper (months). Rebound anxiety severe. Highly variable individual response—some very sensitive. Sold with minimal warnings about addiction potential. Users often don't realize they're dependent until they try to stop. Not detected on standard drug tests. Quality varies between suppliers—heavy metal contamination possible. Some countries beginning to schedule/ban.

notes: GABA analogue sold as nootropic supplement. No reagent reactions. Physical dependence can develop with regular use.

description.overview: 6-APB (6-(2-Aminopropyl)benzofuran), known as 'Benzo Fury,' is a synthetic empathogen-entactogen and stimulant, chemically related to MDMA and MDA. Produces euphoria, emotional openness, stimulation, and psychedelic visuals. Duration significantly longer than MDMA (8-14 hours). Popular in UK club scenes before being banned. Part of benzofuran family (5-APB, 5-MAPB, etc.).
description.origins: Synthesized in 1993 by David Nichols at Purdue University for research purposes. Remained obscure research chemical until late 2000s. Marketed in UK as legal high under brand name 'Benzo Fury' in early 2010s before being scheduled in 2013. Gained popularity as MDMA substitute when MDMA quality/availability declined in UK. Now Schedule I in most countries but still available on research chemical markets.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like empathy and euphoria, music enhancement, dancing, emotional connection. Produces more psychedelic visuals than MDMA, especially at higher doses. Popular at festivals and raves as MDMA alternative. Typical dose 80-120mg; effects last 8-14 hours (much longer than MDMA's 4-6 hours). Some users prefer benzofurans for longer-lasting experiences; others find duration exhausting.
description.dangers: Very long duration can be physically and mentally exhausting. Cardiovascular stress: increased heart rate and blood pressure over extended period. Vasoconstriction. Serotonin depletion worse than MDMA due to longer duration—severe comedown depression possible. Neurotoxicity concerns similar to MDMA but less studied. Jaw clenching, eye wiggling (nystagmus), overheating risk. Difficult to sleep for 12-18 hours after dosing. Higher doses produce intense psychedelic effects that can be overwhelming. Limited research on long-term effects. Sold as MDMA or mixed into pills—always test. Reagent reactions similar to MDMA but distinguishable with multiple reagents. Tolerance develops; cross-tolerance with MDMA. Recommended waiting period 3+ months between uses like MDMA.

scientific_papers.title: The rise of 'Benzo Fury': a review of the benzofuran NPS phenomenon
scientific_papers.summary: Review of 6-APB's emergence as legal high in UK and subsequent health concerns

notes: Benzo Fury. MDMA-like empathogen/entactogen. Longer duration than MDMA (8-10h). Benzofurans have unique reaction patterns.

description.overview: Methylphenidate (Ritalin, Concerta) is a prescription stimulant medication used primarily to treat ADHD and narcolepsy. It increases dopamine and norepinephrine activity in the brain, improving focus, attention, and impulse control. Structurally different from amphetamine but with similar therapeutic effects. Commonly diverted for academic performance enhancement.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1944 by Leandro Panizzon at Ciba (now Novartis). Named 'Ritalin' after his wife Rita who used it for low blood pressure. FDA-approved in 1955 for treating hyperactivity and later ADHD. Became Schedule II controlled substance in 1971. Extended-release formulations (Concerta, Ritalin LA) developed in 2000s to reduce abuse potential.
description.uses: Medical: ADHD treatment (children and adults), narcolepsy, treatment-resistant depression (off-label). Improves focus, reduces hyperactivity and impulsivity in ADHD patients. Recreational/Academic: Cognitive enhancement for studying, productivity, euphoria at high doses. Popular among college students during exams. Typical therapeutic dose 5-20mg; recreational users may take 40-80mg+.
description.dangers: Cardiovascular risks: increased heart rate and blood pressure, risk of heart attack/stroke with pre-existing conditions or high doses. Abuse potential lower than amphetamine but still significant. Tolerance develops with regular use. Nasal damage from snorting crushed pills (common route of abuse). Can trigger anxiety, paranoia, psychosis at high doses. Appetite suppression, insomnia, irritability. Growth suppression in children with long-term use (controversial). Withdrawal: fatigue, depression, difficulty concentrating. Interactions with MAOIs can be dangerous. Pharmaceutical pills should match pill ID databases—counterfeit Ritalin rare but possible.

scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of methylphenidate effectiveness and safety for ADHD treatment

description.overview: Codeine is a naturally occurring opioid found in opium poppy, commonly prescribed for mild to moderate pain and cough suppression. Weaker than morphine (codeine is a prodrug that converts to morphine in the liver). Found in prescription medications like Tylenol #3, cough syrups (promethazine-codeine), and standalone pills. Popular in 'lean' or 'purple drank' culture when mixed with soda and candy.
description.origins: Isolated from opium in 1832 by French chemist Pierre Robiquet. Widely used in medicine since late 1800s as safer alternative to morphine for mild pain. Included in over-the-counter cough syrups until stricter regulations in 1970s-90s. Hip-hop culture popularized 'lean' (codeine cough syrup + soda) in 1990s-2000s Houston scene, spreading nationally. Now Schedule II-V depending on formulation and concentration.
description.uses: Medical: Mild-moderate pain relief, cough suppression, diarrhea treatment. Often combined with acetaminophen (Tylenol #3) or aspirin. Typical dose 15-60mg for pain. Recreational: 'Lean' or 'purple drank' (codeine cough syrup + promethazine + soda + candy), euphoria, relaxation, nodding. Doses 60-120mg+ for recreational effects. Effects: 3-4 hours duration, less intense than other opioids but still addictive.
description.dangers: Addiction and physical dependence develop with regular use—opioid withdrawal includes muscle aches, anxiety, insomnia, nausea. Respiratory depression at high doses or when combined with other depressants (alcohol, benzos, promethazine). Acetaminophen toxicity—many codeine pills contain APAP which causes liver damage/failure at high doses (>4000mg daily). 'Lean' culture glamorizes dangerous behavior—multiple celebrity deaths (Pimp C, DJ Screw, Lil Peep used multiple substances). Genetic variation in CYP2D6 enzyme means some people convert codeine to morphine very efficiently (ultra-rapid metabolizers = overdose risk) while others get no effect (poor metabolizers). Constipation, nausea, itching common. Promethazine in cough syrup adds sedation and respiratory depression risk. Driving impairment. Gateway to stronger opioids for some users.

scientific_papers.summary: Case report demonstrating fatal codeine toxicity in ultra-rapid CYP2D6 metabolizer

scientific_papers.title: Recreational use of codeine-containing cough syrup
scientific_papers.summary: Study on 'purple drank' culture and health risks of recreational codeine syrup misuse

scientific_papers.title: Codeine, ultrarapid-metabolism genotype, and postoperative death

notes: Mild opioid. Often combined with acetaminophen—monitor APAP dose to avoid liver damage. Lean/purple drank popular in hip-hop culture.

description.overview: Oxycodone is a semi-synthetic opioid analgesic prescribed for moderate to severe pain. Approximately 1.5x more potent than morphine. Available as immediate-release (Roxicodone, Percocet with acetaminophen) and extended-release (OxyContin). Extremely high abuse and diversion rates. The counterfeit 'M30' pills (fake oxycodone 30mg) are now the #1 cause of fentanyl overdose deaths—virtually all street M30s contain fentanyl, not oxycodone.
description.origins: Synthesized from thebaine (opium alkaloid) in 1916 by German chemists Martin Freund and Edmund Speyer. Introduced commercially in 1939. OxyContin (extended-release) launched by Purdue Pharma in 1996 with aggressive marketing claiming low addiction risk—this sparked the modern opioid epidemic. Purdue pled guilty to criminal charges in 2007 and 2020 for misleading marketing. By 2010s, pill mills and overprescribing led to epidemic of addiction and transition to heroin/fentanyl when prescriptions tightened. Now, counterfeit 'M30' pills are primary fentanyl delivery method.
description.uses: Medical: Moderate-severe pain (post-surgical, cancer, chronic pain). Typical dose 5-30mg every 4-6 hours for immediate-release; 10-80mg every 12 hours for OxyContin. Recreational/diverted: Pills crushed and snorted, chewed, or dissolved for injection to bypass extended-release mechanism. Euphoria, pain relief, sedation, 'nodding.' Street pills ('blues,' 'M30s,' 'roxies') almost universally counterfeit containing fentanyl.
description.dangers: COUNTERFEIT EPIDEMIC: The DEA reports 6 out of 10 fake M30 pills contain lethal fentanyl doses. If you didn't get it from YOUR prescription at a pharmacy, assume it's fake and contains fentanyl. Addiction develops rapidly—one of highest abuse potentials among opioids. Physical dependence and severe withdrawal. Respiratory depression and overdose, especially when combined with alcohol, benzos, or other depressants. Acetaminophen toxicity in Percocet formulations (liver damage/failure). Constipation, nausea, sedation. IV use carries infection risks. OxyContin abuse contributed to opioid epidemic and transition to heroin/fentanyl. Fake pills are manufactured by cartels with pill presses—look identical to real pills but contain fentanyl, carfentanil, or nothing.

scientific_papers.title: OxyContin and the opioid epidemic: Purdue Pharma's role
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of OxyContin marketing practices and contribution to opioid epidemic

scientific_papers.title: Counterfeit oxycodone tablets containing fentanyl: A new public health threat
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of fake M30 pill crisis and fentanyl contamination rates

scientific_papers.title: Trends in opioid analgesic abuse and mortality in the United States
scientific_papers.summary: Epidemiological study tracking oxycodone abuse patterns and transition to heroin

notes: CRITICAL: Street 'M30' pills are ALMOST ALWAYS COUNTERFEIT FENTANYL. If you didn't get it from YOUR prescription at a licensed pharmacy, assume it contains fentanyl. Always use fentanyl test strips on any suspected oxycodone pill from the street. Real pharmaceutical pills should match pill identification databases (drugs.com) exactly—check imprint, color, size, texture. Fake pills may have: uneven edges, chalky texture, incorrect color, wrong thickness, crumbly consistency. Even perfect-looking pills can be deadly fakes. Visual inspection alone is NOT reliable—Mexican cartels use industrial pill presses.

fentanyl_strips.summary: MANDATORY for any street pill. Dissolve small amount, test with fentanyl strips before consuming.

pill_databases.summary: Compare to drugs.com pill identifier. Check imprint, shape, color, score lines.

description.overview: Hydrocodone is a semi-synthetic opioid analgesic prescribed for moderate pain and cough suppression. Similar potency to morphine. Almost always combined with acetaminophen (Vicodin, Norco, Lortab) or ibuprofen. One of the most prescribed opioids in the US. High diversion and abuse rates. Counterfeit Vicodin pills increasingly contain fentanyl.
description.origins: First synthesized in Germany in 1920 from codeine. Introduced to US market in 1943 combined with other medications. Vicodin (hydrocodone + acetaminophen) launched in 1978 and became one of most prescribed medications in America. Originally Schedule III but rescheduled to Schedule II in 2014 due to abuse epidemic. Tighter prescribing regulations led to decline in legitimate prescriptions but increase in counterfeit pills containing fentanyl.
description.uses: Medical: Moderate pain (dental procedures, injuries, post-surgical), cough suppression. Typical dose 5-10mg hydrocodone combined with 300-325mg acetaminophen (Norco 5/325, 10/325). Recreational: Euphoria, pain relief, relaxation, 'nodding.' Pills often taken in excess or combined with alcohol. Some users extract hydrocodone from acetaminophen ('cold water extraction') to avoid liver damage at high doses.
description.dangers: Addiction and physical dependence common—opioid withdrawal includes muscle aches, anxiety, insomnia, nausea, sweating. Respiratory depression and overdose, especially when combined with alcohol, benzodiazepines, or other CNS depressants. Acetaminophen toxicity—exceeding 4000mg daily causes liver damage and potential liver failure (fatal). Many deaths from Vicodin abuse involve acetaminophen overdose in addition to opioid effects. Constipation, nausea, drowsiness common. Driving impairment. COUNTERFEIT PILLS: Fake Vicodin increasingly common, often containing fentanyl instead of hydrocodone. Always verify pharmaceutical source.

scientific_papers.summary: Review of hydrocodone's abuse potential and rationale for Schedule II reclassification

scientific_papers.title: Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity in patients treated with hydrocodone combination products
scientific_papers.summary: Study documenting liver damage from acetaminophen in Vicodin formulations

scientific_papers.title: Trends in hydrocodone prescribing after Schedule II reclassification

notes: Vicodin, Norco, Lortab. Almost always combined with acetaminophen—never exceed 4000mg APAP daily (liver damage). Street pills may be counterfeit fentanyl—test with fentanyl strips. Reagent tests show opioid reactions but cannot distinguish from other opioids. Verify pharmaceutical pills with pill ID databases.

fentanyl_strips.summary: Test any street Vicodin/Norco pills. Counterfeit pills with fentanyl increasing.

description.overview: Mephedrone (4-methylmethcathinone, 4-MMC) is a synthetic cathinone stimulant and empathogen. Known as 'meow meow,' 'M-CAT,' or 'drone.' Produces MDMA-like euphoria and empathy combined with cocaine-like stimulation. Extremely compulsive redosing behavior. Popular in UK rave scene 2008-2010 before being banned. Still encountered, often sold as MDMA, molly, or bath salts. Very 'moreish' (users have difficulty stopping once started).
description.origins: First synthesized in 1929 but remained obscure. Re-emerged in 2003 on research chemical markets. Exploded in popularity in UK 2008-2009 as legal high sold in head shops and online. Media panic and several deaths led to emergency UK ban in April 2010, followed by worldwide scheduling. Peak use 2009-2010; still available on black/gray markets but less common than during legal era. Chinese labs were primary manufacturers. Often mis-sold as MDMA or methylone currently.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like empathy, euphoria, music enhancement, dancing, sociability combined with cocaine-like rush and stimulation. Typical dose 100-250mg oral or nasal. Duration 2-3 hours (shorter than MDMA). Extremely compulsive redosing—users report going through grams in a session unable to stop. Often used at clubs, raves, festivals. Effects described as 'rolling and rushing' simultaneously. Some prefer it to MDMA for stronger stimulant component; others find it too compulsive and 'tweaky.'
description.dangers: EXTREME compulsive redosing—users report inability to stop until supply exhausted, leading to massive doses, severe comedowns, and harm. Cardiovascular stress: tachycardia, hypertension, chest pain. Hyperthermia and dehydration (especially in hot environments). Jaw clenching, bruxism, muscle tension. Severe 'comedown' includes depression, anxiety, paranoia, insomnia lasting days. Vasoconstriction can cause blue/cold extremities. Psychosis with heavy use or binging. Possible neurotoxicity (unknown long-term effects). Deaths reported from hyperthermia, cardiovascular events, and combining with other substances. Nasal insufflation extremely caustic—burns nasal passages. Often cut or substituted with other cathinones, caffeine, or sold as MDMA. Harm reduction extremely difficult due to compulsive redosing nature.

scientific_papers.title: Mephedrone (4-methylmethcathinone): pharmacology, metabolism and toxicity
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of mephedrone's effects, risks, and deaths associated with use

scientific_papers.title: The rise and fall of mephedrone in the United Kingdom
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of mephedrone's legal high era, use patterns, and banning in UK

scientific_papers.title: Compulsive use linked to 4-MMC: A comparison to MDMA
scientific_papers.summary: Study showing mephedrone users report significantly more compulsive redosing than MDMA users

testing.alt: yellow to orange (similar to amphetamine, NOT purple like MDMA)
NO blue color (unlike MDMA which turns blue)

notes: CRITICAL: Often sold as MDMA or molly. Mephedrone does NOT turn purple with Marquis (it goes yellow/orange) and does NOT turn blue with Simon's. If suspected MDMA gives yellow/orange Marquis + no Simon's blue reaction, likely mephedrone or another cathinone. Extremely compulsive redosing behavior—harm reduction very difficult. Users report going through entire supplies in one session. Short duration (2-3 hours) leads to repeated dosing. MUCH more 'tweaky' and stimulating than MDMA. Severe comedowns common.

comparison_to_mdma.summary: Test with Simon's reagent—MDMA turns blue, mephedrone does NOT. Marquis: MDMA purple-black, mephedrone yellow-orange.

description.overview: Alpha-pyrrolidinopentiophenone (α-PVP), known as 'Flakka' or 'gravel,' is an extremely potent synthetic cathinone stimulant. Notorious for causing severe psychosis, violent behavior, and bizarre incidents ('zombie drug' media coverage). Much more potent and dangerous than mephedrone. Cheap, highly addictive, and widely available in mid-2010s. Associated with multiple deaths and emergency room visits. Effects include extreme stimulation, paranoia, hallucinations, hyperthermia, and violent outbursts.
description.origins: First synthesized in the 1960s but remained obscure until 2010s. Exploded in Florida and other US states 2013-2015 as cheap MDPV replacement after MDPV scheduling. Marketed as 'bath salts' or 'research chemicals.' Media dubbed it 'zombie drug' after incidents of naked, violent users. Chinese labs mass-produced it. Scheduled federally in 2014 but continued availability. Peak crisis 2014-2015; still encountered but less common than height of epidemic.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Extreme stimulation, euphoria (initial), increased energy and alertness. Typical dose 5-30mg (extremely potent). Often vaped, snorted, or injected. Duration 2-4 hours. Compulsive redosing extremely common. Popular among those seeking cheap, intense stimulation. Some users report positive experiences at low doses, but risk of psychotic episodes very high. Often used in binges lasting days.
description.dangers: EXTREME DANGER: Causes severe psychosis, paranoia, hallucinations (visual and auditory), violent behavior, self-harm, bizarre actions. 'Excited delirium' syndrome—hyperthermia, extreme agitation, superhuman strength perception, death. Cardiovascular toxicity: tachycardia, hypertension, cardiac arrest. Kidney damage reported. Vasoconstriction. Compulsive redosing leads to massive doses and severe toxicity. Addiction develops rapidly. Withdrawal includes severe depression, fatigue, anhedonia. Often triggers violent incidents and law enforcement encounters. Deaths from hyperthermia, cardiac events, and accidents. Media-documented cases: users attacking others, running naked, exhibiting superhuman strength. Extremely caustic—nasal damage from snorting. NOT recreational—harm potential extreme.

scientific_papers.title: Alpha-PVP (flakka): A new synthetic cathinone invades the drug scene
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of alpha-PVP pharmacology, toxicity, and public health crisis

scientific_papers.title: Excited delirium and bath salts: A review of the literature
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of alpha-PVP and related cathinones causing excited delirium syndrome

scientific_papers.title: Flakka-induced prolonged psychosis
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports of severe psychotic episodes lasting weeks after alpha-PVP use

notes: EXTREME DANGER: Flakka/gravel. Known for causing psychosis, violent behavior, 'zombie' incidents. NOT recreational—severe harm potential. If encountered, extreme caution advised. Often sold as bath salts or other stimulants. Pyrrolidinophenones (alpha-PVP, MDPV, etc.) have similar reagent reactions to other cathinones—yellow/orange with Marquis. Cannot be distinguished from other cathinones by reagent alone. If you suspect Flakka, DO NOT USE—psychosis risk extreme. Harm reduction: Start with extremely small dose if testing, have sitter, benzos available for psychotic episodes.

description.overview: Methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV) is an extremely potent synthetic cathinone stimulant, the original 'bath salts' drug that sparked the 2010-2011 media panic. Much more potent than cocaine or methamphetamine. Causes intense stimulation, euphoria, paranoia, and hallucinations. Highly addictive with severe compulsive redosing. Active at 5-20mg doses. Associated with violent incidents, psychosis, and deaths. Largely replaced by alpha-PVP after scheduling but still encountered.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1969 by Boehringer Ingelheim as potential ADHD medication but never marketed. Remained obscure until 2000s research chemical scene. Exploded in popularity 2009-2011 as legal high sold as 'bath salts,' 'plant food,' or 'research chemicals' with labels 'not for human consumption.' Miami 'cannibal' incident (2012) falsely attributed to MDPV caused media panic (actually not MDPV but became face of bath salts crisis). Emergency scheduling 2011, Schedule I 2012. Largely disappeared from market, replaced by alpha-PVP and other analogues.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense euphoria, stimulation, increased alertness, hypersexuality. Typical dose 5-20mg (extremely potent—less than grain of rice). Usually insufflated, sometimes oral or IV. Duration 2-4 hours. EXTREME compulsive redosing—users report inability to stop until supply exhausted. Popular 2009-2011 as legal stimulant. Effects described as more intense than cocaine with longer duration. Binges lasting days common. Now rare due to scheduling and replacement by analogues.
description.dangers: EXTREME DANGER: Severe paranoia, auditory and visual hallucinations, psychosis, violent behavior. 'Excited delirium'—hyperthermia, agitation, superhuman strength, death. Cardiovascular toxicity: extreme tachycardia (>200 bpm reported), hypertension, vasoconstriction, cardiac arrest. Hyperthermia can be fatal. Compulsive redosing impossible to control—users report going through grams in sessions. Severe comedown: depression, exhaustion, suicidal ideation. Physical dependence and severe withdrawal. Multiple deaths documented. Violent incidents common—attacks on others, police encounters. Nasal damage from snorting. Often triggers psychotic breaks requiring psychiatric hospitalization. NOT safe at any dose—unpredictable severe reactions.

scientific_papers.title: MDPV: The new bath salts drug wave
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive pharmacology study showing MDPV is 10x more potent than cocaine

scientific_papers.title: Clinical manifestations of bath salt intoxication
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of emergency room presentations from MDPV and bath salts epidemic

scientific_papers.title: MDPV-induced psychosis: Case series
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of severe psychotic episodes from MDPV use

notes: Original 'bath salts' drug (2010-2011). EXTREMELY potent and dangerous. Causes severe psychosis, paranoia, hallucinations, violent behavior. 10x more potent than cocaine. Compulsive redosing uncontrollable. Now rare (replaced by alpha-PVP) but still encountered. Cannot be distinguished from other cathinones by reagent tests alone. If suspected MDPV: DO NOT USE. Harm potential extreme—not recreational. This is the drug that caused the bath salts moral panic and emergency scheduling.

description.overview: Methylone (βk-MDMA, bk-MDMA) is a synthetic cathinone empathogen, the beta-ketone analogue of MDMA. Produces MDMA-like effects but shorter duration, less empathogenic, more stimulating. Was the most common MDMA substitute 2010-2015 in 'molly' and ecstasy pills. Less intense than MDMA, often described as '70% of MDMA's magic.' Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 2-4 hours (vs MDMA's 4-6). Largely replaced by eutylone/n-ethylpentylone in recent years but still encountered.
description.origins: First synthesized by chemists Peyton Jacob III and Alexander Shulgin in 1996, documented in PiHKAL. Remained obscure until late 2000s. Exploded in popularity 2010-2014 as legal MDMA substitute. Sold as 'molly,' in pressed pills as 'ecstasy,' or as 'bath salts.' Often intentionally substituted for MDMA when MDMA scarce or expensive. Emergency scheduling 2013, Schedule I 2014. Peak use 2011-2014. Declined after scheduling but still found in pills and powders sold as MDMA. Chinese labs produced industrial quantities.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like empathy, euphoria, increased sociability, music enhancement. Less 'rolling' than MDMA, more 'speedy.' Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 2-4 hours. Often used at raves, festivals, clubs. Some users prefer shorter duration; others disappointed by lack of MDMA's emotional depth. Compulsive redosing common due to short duration. Often unknowingly consumed by people expecting MDMA. Less popular since scheduling made it no longer 'legal high' advantage.
description.dangers: Less toxic than MDMA at equivalent doses but still carries risks: Cardiovascular stress (tachycardia, hypertension), hyperthermia and dehydration (especially in hot environments), neurotoxicity concerns (less studied than MDMA), serotonin depletion and comedown depression, jaw clenching and muscle tension. Compulsive redosing leads to higher doses and increased harm. Often sold as MDMA—users taking 'MDMA doses' (100-150mg) may redose thinking it's weak MDMA, leading to excessive methylone consumption. Unknown long-term effects. Deaths reported but less common than with MDMA. Often combined with other substances in pressed pills. Less empathogenic than MDMA—users often disappointed and seek 'real' MDMA. Harm reduction difficult when sold as MDMA.

scientific_papers.title: Methylone and MDMA: Behavioral and neurochemical comparison
scientific_papers.summary: Study comparing methylone to MDMA—similar but less potent empathogenic effects

scientific_papers.title: Methylone as MDMA substitute in ecstasy tablets
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis showing methylone was most common MDMA substitute 2010-2012

notes: CRITICAL: Most common MDMA substitute 2010-2015, still encountered. Methylone does NOT turn purple with Marquis (yellow/orange) and does NOT turn blue with Simon's. MDMA: purple-black Marquis + blue Simon's. Methylone: yellow/orange Marquis + NO blue Simon's. If suspected MDMA gives cathinone reactions, likely methylone or another substitute. Described as '70% of MDMA'—shorter duration, less empathogenic, more stimulating. Test with multiple reagents to distinguish from MDMA.

comparison_to_mdma.summary: Simon's test is KEY. MDMA turns blue, methylone does NOT. Marquis: MDMA purple-black, methylone yellow-orange.

description.overview: Eutylone (bk-EBDB) is a synthetic cathinone empathogen-stimulant, the beta-ketone analogue of MBDB. Currently one of the most common MDMA substitutes found in 'molly' and ecstasy pills (2020s). Replaced methylone after its scheduling. Similar effects to MDMA but more stimulating, less empathogenic. Often sold as MDMA or mixed with MDMA in pills. Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 3-5 hours. Compulsive redosing common.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1960s but remained obscure until 2010s. Gained popularity after methylone scheduling (2014) as next-generation legal MDMA substitute. Exploded in use 2017-present, now one of primary adulterants in MDMA market. Often found alongside N-ethylpentylone (similar cathinone). Lab testing shows eutylone present in significant percentage of pills/powders sold as MDMA. Chinese labs primary producers. Not yet federally scheduled in US (as of 2024) but banned in many states.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like effects but more stimulating, less emotional. Euphoria, increased energy, sociability, music enhancement. Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 3-5 hours. Often unknowingly consumed by people expecting MDMA. Some users find it 'speedier' and less satisfying than MDMA. Compulsive redosing very common. Used at raves, festivals, clubs. Less empathogenic than MDMA—disappointing for users seeking 'rolling' experience.
description.dangers: Cardiovascular stress: tachycardia, hypertension, vasoconstriction. More stimulating than MDMA—higher anxiety, paranoia risk. Compulsive redosing leads to excessive doses. Hyperthermia and dehydration (hot environments). Neurotoxicity unknown but presumed similar to other cathinones. Serotonin depletion and severe comedown. Jaw clenching, muscle tension. Often sold as MDMA—users don't know what they're taking, leading to unexpected effects and overdosing when redosing thinking it's 'weak MDMA.' Unknown long-term effects. Deaths reported but less studied than MDMA. Often combined with actual MDMA or other substances in pills, making dosing unpredictable.

scientific_papers.summary: Analysis showing eutylone is current primary MDMA adulterant in US drug supply

scientific_papers.title: Pharmacology of eutylone and related synthetic cathinones
scientific_papers.summary: Study of eutylone's pharmacological profile compared to MDMA

testing.alt: yellow to orange (NOT purple like MDMA)
NO blue color (unlike MDMA which turns blue)

notes: CRITICAL: Currently one of most common MDMA substitutes (2020s), replacing methylone. Eutylone does NOT turn purple with Marquis (yellow/orange) and does NOT turn blue with Simon's. If suspected MDMA shows cathinone reactions, likely eutylone, n-ethylpentylone, or methylone. More stimulating and less empathogenic than MDMA. Test EVERYTHING sold as molly—eutylone contamination extremely common. Often mixed with actual MDMA in pills making identification harder.

comparison_to_mdma.summary: Simon's test essential. MDMA turns blue, eutylone does NOT. Marquis: MDMA purple-black, eutylone yellow-orange. Lab testing ideal for definitive ID.

description.overview: N-Ethylpentylone (ephylone, bk-EBDP) is a synthetic cathinone empathogen-stimulant similar to eutylone. Currently one of the most common MDMA adulterants (2020s). More stimulating and less empathogenic than MDMA. Often found alongside eutylone in MDMA samples. Typical dose 100-250mg. Duration 3-6 hours. Significant compulsive redosing behavior.
description.origins: First appeared on research chemical markets in 2010s. Gained prominence 2018-present as methylone replacement. Often found in pills and powders sold as MDMA or molly. Lab analysis shows frequent presence in drug checking samples. Sometimes combined with actual MDMA to mimic MDMA effects while cutting costs. Chinese production. Not federally scheduled in US (as of 2024) but various state bans.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like stimulation and euphoria but less emotional warmth. Increased energy, sociability, music enhancement. Typical dose 100-250mg. Duration 3-6 hours. Most users consume unknowingly expecting MDMA. Described as 'speedy' and unsatisfying compared to real MDMA. Compulsive redosing very common—users take more seeking MDMA's empathogenic effects. Popular at festivals, raves, clubs as cheap MDMA substitute.
description.dangers: Cardiovascular effects: tachycardia, hypertension, increased stroke risk. More stimulating than MDMA—anxiety, paranoia, restlessness common. Compulsive redosing leads to dangerous doses. Hyperthermia in hot environments. Neurotoxicity profile unknown. Severe comedown: depression, exhaustion, irritability. Jaw clenching, muscle tension, bruxism. Often mis-sold as MDMA—users take MDMA-sized doses and redose excessively when effects don't match expectations. Deaths reported. Unknown long-term effects. Frequently combined with other cathinones or actual MDMA in pills.

scientific_papers.title: N-Ethylpentylone: An emerging synthetic cathinone
scientific_papers.summary: First comprehensive analysis of N-ethylpentylone prevalence in drug supply

scientific_papers.title: Pharmacological profile of ephylone and eutylone
scientific_papers.summary: Comparison of N-ethylpentylone to MDMA and other cathinones

testing.alt: yellow to orange (NOT purple like MDMA)
NO blue color (unlike MDMA which turns blue)

notes: CURRENT THREAT: One of most common MDMA adulterants alongside eutylone (2020-2024). Does NOT turn purple with Marquis or blue with Simon's—clear indicator it's NOT MDMA. Yellow/orange cathinone reactions. Often found mixed with eutylone or actual MDMA. Test everything sold as molly. More stimulating, less empathogenic than MDMA. Cannot be distinguished from eutylone/methylone by reagent alone—all show similar cathinone reactions. Lab testing needed for specific cathinone ID.

comparison_to_mdma.summary: Simon's test KEY. MDMA = blue. N-Ethylpentylone = NO blue. Marquis: MDMA purple-black, N-ethylpentylone yellow-orange.

description.overview: Lisdexamfetamine (Vyvanse) is a prodrug stimulant medication for ADHD and binge eating disorder. Converted to dextroamphetamine in the body after oral consumption. Longer-acting and smoother than immediate-release amphetamines. Designed to reduce abuse potential compared to Adderall. Now one of most prescribed ADHD medications. Common diversion for academic performance enhancement. Cannot be snorted or injected effectively (prodrug must be metabolized first).
description.origins: Developed by New River Pharmaceuticals (acquired by Shire, now Takeda) specifically to create an abuse-deterrent amphetamine formulation. FDA-approved 2007 for ADHD. Approved 2015 for binge eating disorder—first medication for this indication. Designed as 'pro-drug' that requires enzymatic conversion in blood to become active dextroamphetamine. This prevents rapid onset from snorting/injecting, theoretically reducing abuse. Now one of top prescribed ADHD medications, competing with Adderall. Schedule II controlled substance. Patent expired 2023, generics now available.
description.uses: Medical: ADHD treatment (children and adults), binge eating disorder. Typical dose 30-70mg once daily. Converted to d-amphetamine in body—30mg Vyvanse ≈ 10mg d-amphetamine. Effects last 10-14 hours (all-day coverage). Recreational/Academic: Cognitive enhancement, studying, increased focus and energy. Popular among college students. Some users still abuse despite prodrug design. Oral only—cannot be effectively snorted or injected. Lower 'rush' than Adderall makes it less preferred recreationally but still diverted.
description.dangers: Similar to amphetamine: Cardiovascular risks (increased HR/BP, risk of heart issues), abuse potential (lower than immediate-release stimulants but still significant), tolerance and psychological dependence, appetite suppression and weight loss, insomnia if taken too late, anxiety and irritability, potential for psychosis with chronic high-dose use. Prodrug design means delayed onset—some users take more thinking it's not working, leading to overdose when all doses convert. Mixing with other stimulants or alcohol dangerous. Withdrawal: fatigue, depression, hypersomnia. Cannot be 'rushed' like other stimulants—frustrates some abusers but doesn't eliminate abuse.

scientific_papers.title: Lisdexamfetamine: A prodrug stimulant for ADHD
scientific_papers.summary: Review of lisdexamfetamine's prodrug mechanism and reduced abuse potential

scientific_papers.title: Abuse liability of lisdexamfetamine versus d-amphetamine
scientific_papers.summary: Study showing lisdexamfetamine has lower abuse potential than immediate-release amphetamine

scientific_papers.title: Lisdexamfetamine for binge eating disorder
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical trial leading to FDA approval for binge eating disorder

testing.alt: orange (metabolizes to d-amphetamine which gives orange reaction)

notes: Vyvanse. Prodrug converted to d-amphetamine in body. Cannot be effectively snorted or injected (requires metabolism). Pharmaceutical capsules should match pill ID databases exactly. Reagent tests show amphetamine-like reactions (orange) after metabolism. Longer-acting than Adderall (10-14 hours). Lower abuse potential but still diverted. Counterfeit Vyvanse rare but possible—verify pharmaceutical source. One of most prescribed ADHD medications.

description.overview: 3-Methoxyphencyclidine (3-MeO-PCP) is a dissociative research chemical from the arylcyclohexylamine class, closely related to PCP and ketamine. More potent and longer-lasting than ketamine. Produces dissociation, euphoria, and stimulation. Popular as ketamine alternative but much longer duration (8-14 hours vs 1-2 hours). Active at 5-20mg doses. Known for inducing manic episodes, delusions of sobriety, and compulsive redosing. Dangerous when combined with other substances.
description.origins: First synthesized in 1979 but remained obscure until 2000s research chemical boom. Gained popularity 2008-2012 as legal ketamine alternative. Often marketed as 'Methoxetamine' (MXE) replacement after MXE scheduling. Chinese labs primary manufacturers. Legal status varies—banned in many countries but unscheduled in some regions. Peak use 2012-2016; still widely available. Frequently mis-sold as ketamine or MXE.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Dissociation, out-of-body experiences, euphoria, stimulation, music enhancement. Typical dose 5-15mg (very potent). Duration 8-14 hours (much longer than ketamine). Insufflated, oral, or sublingual. Popular in psychonaut/research chemical communities. Some users report 'warm' dissociation similar to PCP. Others find it stimulating and manic. Effects highly dose-dependent and unpredictable.
description.dangers: MANIC EPISODES: Users report feeling invincible, delusions of sobriety, poor decision-making, dangerous behavior. Extremely long duration (12+ hours) can be overwhelming. Compulsive redosing common—users take more while already dissociated. Cardiovascular effects: tachycardia, hypertension. Bladder damage with chronic use (similar to ketamine). Psychosis, paranoia, confusion. 'Hole' experiences can be terrifying and last hours. Extremely dangerous when combined with other depressants (alcohol, benzos, opioids)—respiratory depression, death. Stimulant effects mask sedation—users don't realize how intoxicated they are. Tolerance develops quickly. Addiction potential. Deaths reported from overdose and accidents while intoxicated. Often sold as ketamine—users expecting ketamine duration get trapped in 12-hour dissociative state.

scientific_papers.title: 3-MeO-PCP: A new dissociative substance on the drug scene
scientific_papers.summary: First comprehensive analysis of 3-MeO-PCP pharmacology and prevalence

scientific_papers.title: Manic psychosis induced by 3-methoxyphencyclidine
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports of manic episodes and psychosis from 3-MeO-PCP use

notes: DANGER: Often sold as ketamine but MUCH longer duration (8-14 hours vs 1-2 hours). Causes manic episodes, delusions of sobriety, extremely poor judgment. Very potent—5-15mg active dose. Compulsive redosing while dissociated common. Cannot be reliably distinguished from ketamine or PCP by reagent tests alone—similar arylcyclohexylamine reactions. If suspected ketamine lasts >4 hours, likely 3-MeO-PCP or analogue. DO NOT combine with depressants—respiratory depression fatal. Stimulant effects deceive users into thinking they're less intoxicated than they are.

description.overview: Methoxetamine (MXE, 3-MeO-2-Oxo-PCE) is a dissociative research chemical designed as a safer ketamine alternative. Longer duration than ketamine (4-8 hours), less bladder toxicity (theoretically). Produces dissociation, euphoria, and introspection. Was most popular ketamine substitute 2010-2015. Emergency scheduling and China ban (2015) made it rare. Now mostly replaced by 3-MeO-PCP and other analogues. Described as 'warmer' and more euphoric than ketamine.
description.origins: Synthesized specifically as ketamine alternative with reduced bladder toxicity. Appeared on research chemical markets around 2010. Exploded in popularity 2011-2014 as 'legal ketamine' sold openly online. Marketed with harm reduction angle (less bladder damage). Chinese manufacturers produced industrial quantities. Emergency scheduled in UK 2012, USA 2013, China ban 2015. Peak use 2012-2014. Now rare and expensive due to China ban. Largely replaced by 3-MeO-PCP, DCK, 2-FDCK. Historical significance as most successful ketamine RC.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Dissociation, out-of-body experiences, euphoria, introspection, music enhancement. Typical dose 30-80mg. Duration 4-8 hours (longer than ketamine's 1-2 hours). Insufflated, oral, sublingual, or IM injection. Popular at raves, festivals, and psychonaut communities 2010-2014. Described as more 'warm' and euphoric than ketamine's 'cold' dissociation. 'M-hole' comparable to K-hole but longer. Some prefer it to ketamine; others find duration exhausting.
description.dangers: Bladder toxicity STILL OCCURS despite marketing claims—less than ketamine but not eliminated. Cardiovascular effects: tachycardia, hypertension. Long duration (6-8 hours) can be mentally exhausting. Compulsive redosing. Respiratory depression when combined with depressants. 'Hole' experiences can last hours and be terrifying. Confusion, poor coordination, falls and injuries. Tolerance builds quickly. Psychological addiction. Dangerous driving impairment. Deaths reported from overdose and poly-drug combinations (especially with alcohol, opioids, benzos). Now rare—products sold as MXE often other dissociatives (3-MeO-PCP, DCK). Test before use if claimed to be MXE.

scientific_papers.title: Methoxetamine: From drug of abuse to rapid-acting antidepressant
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of MXE as ketamine alternative and potential therapeutic applications

scientific_papers.title: The rise and fall of methoxetamine: A cautionary tale
scientific_papers.summary: Study of MXE's rapid popularity and subsequent emergency scheduling

notes: Historical dissociative—now rare after China ban (2015). Most popular ketamine alternative 2010-2014. Longer duration than ketamine (4-8 hours). Cannot reliably distinguish from ketamine or 3-MeO-PCP by reagent alone. If product sold as MXE, likely actually 3-MeO-PCP, DCK, or 2-FDCK (MXE expensive/scarce). Bladder damage still possible despite early marketing claims. Warmer, more euphoric than ketamine according to users. Combine duration + reagent results to distinguish from ketamine (MXE lasts 4-8 hrs, ketamine 1-2 hrs).

description.overview: Morphine is the principal active alkaloid in opium, isolated from the opium poppy (Papaver somniferum). The prototypical opioid—all other opioids are compared to morphine for potency. Used medically for severe pain (post-surgical, cancer, trauma). Available as immediate-release and extended-release (MS Contin). Highly addictive with severe physical dependence. Standard pharmaceutical opioid but also diverted for recreational use. Less common on street than oxycodone/heroin due to lower oral bioavailability.
description.origins: Isolated from opium in 1804 by German pharmacist Friedrich Sertürner, making it the first active alkaloid extracted from a plant. Named after Morpheus, Greek god of dreams. Revolutionized pain management in medicine. Widely used in 1800s, including during American Civil War (created many addicts). Injectable morphine introduced mid-1800s. Recognized as highly addictive by early 1900s. Controlled substance since 1914 Harrison Narcotics Act. Still gold standard for severe pain management. Oral morphine (immediate and extended-release) and IV morphine standard in hospitals.
description.uses: Medical: Severe acute pain (trauma, post-surgical), chronic pain (cancer), end-of-life care (hospice), severe breathlessness. Typical dose 15-30mg oral, 5-10mg IV/IM. MS Contin (extended-release) 15-200mg every 8-12 hours. Recreational: Euphoria, pain relief, sedation, 'nodding.' Less preferred recreationally than oxycodone due to poor oral bioavailability (~30%). IV/IM injection more effective but carries infection risks. Street use less common than heroin or oxycodone.
description.dangers: Severe addiction and physical dependence—withdrawal includes severe muscle aches, anxiety, insomnia, vomiting, diarrhea. Respiratory depression—fatal overdose, especially when combined with alcohol, benzos, or other CNS depressants. Constipation (severe, chronic). Nausea and vomiting common. Tolerance develops rapidly—requires increasing doses. IV use carries infection risks (HIV, Hep C, bacterial endocarditis). Hypotension, sedation, cognitive impairment. Driving extremely dangerous. Naloxone reverses overdose but must be administered quickly. Gateway to heroin for some users (when prescription cut off). Counterfeit pharmaceutical morphine rare but possible.

scientific_papers.title: Morphine: The prototypical opioid - A review
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of morphine pharmacology, clinical use, and addiction risks

scientific_papers.title: Morphine and the origins of the opioid crisis
scientific_papers.summary: Historical analysis of morphine's role in development of opioid epidemic

notes: Prototypical opioid—all others measured against it (e.g., 'oxycodone is 1.5x morphine'). Less common on street than oxy/heroin but still diverted. Pharmaceutical pills should match pill ID databases. Reagent tests show opioid reactions but cannot distinguish morphine from other opioids. Lower oral bioavailability (~30%) makes it less desirable recreationally. MS Contin (extended-release) often abused by crushing to defeat time-release. Test with fentanyl strips if source unknown—counterfeit morphine may contain fentanyl.

description.overview: Tramadol (Ultram, ConZip) is an atypical synthetic opioid with dual mechanism: mu-opioid agonist AND serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). Weaker than traditional opioids (1/10th potency of morphine) but still addictive and dangerous. Prescribed for moderate pain. Unique SEIZURE RISK not seen with other opioids. Lower abuse potential led to late scheduling (Schedule IV in US in 2014). Still widely prescribed and diverted. Dangerous when combined with other serotonergic drugs.
description.origins: Synthesized by German pharmaceutical company Grünenthal in 1962. Marketed as safer opioid alternative with lower abuse potential. FDA-approved in US 1995. Initially unscheduled, considered non-addictive—this proved false. Evidence of abuse and dependence accumulated. Rescheduled to Schedule IV in 2014 after decades of unrestricted prescribing. Now recognized as addictive with unique risks. Popular in some regions (Middle East, Africa) where stronger opioids restricted. Online pharmacy sales common.
description.uses: Medical: Moderate pain (post-surgical, dental, chronic pain), osteoarthritis pain. Typical dose 50-100mg every 4-6 hours, max 400mg/day. Extended-release formulations available. Recreational: Mild euphoria, pain relief, mood elevation (from SNRI effects). Less intense than traditional opioids. Some users prefer unique 'energizing' opioid effect from SNRI component. Typical recreational dose 100-300mg. Popular among those with limited opioid access.
description.dangers: SEIZURE RISK: Tramadol lowers seizure threshold, especially at doses >400mg/day or when combined with other drugs that lower seizure threshold (SSRIs, bupropion, etc.). Seizures can occur even at therapeutic doses in susceptible individuals. SEROTONIN SYNDROME: When combined with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs, or other serotonergic drugs—life-threatening (hyperthermia, agitation, seizures, death). Addiction and physical dependence (though 'weaker' than other opioids, withdrawal still occurs). Respiratory depression, especially with other CNS depressants. Nausea, dizziness, constipation. Hypoglycemia in diabetics. Deaths reported from overdose and serotonin syndrome. Often underestimated due to 'weak opioid' reputation—still dangerous.

scientific_papers.title: Tramadol: Seizure risk and serotonin syndrome
scientific_papers.summary: Review of tramadol's unique seizure risks and serotonin syndrome potential

scientific_papers.title: Tramadol dependence and withdrawal: A case series
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of tramadol addiction despite 'low abuse potential' marketing

testing.alt: orange to yellow (different from typical opioid purple)

notes: Ultram. UNIQUE SEIZURE RISK even at therapeutic doses—do NOT exceed 400mg/day. SNRI component means SEROTONIN SYNDROME possible when combined with antidepressants. Weaker than other opioids but still addictive. Reagent reactions differ from typical opioids (orange/yellow vs purple) due to different chemical structure. Pharmaceutical pills should match pill ID databases. Often dismissed as 'weak' but deaths occur. Never combine with SSRIs, SNRIs, or MAOIs.

description.overview: 5-APB (5-(2-Aminopropyl)benzofuran) is a synthetic empathogen-entactogen from the benzofuran family, closely related to 6-APB. Produces MDMA-like empathy, euphoria, and psychedelic effects. Component of 'Benzo Fury' products. Duration 6-10 hours (longer than MDMA). Less common than 6-APB but similar effects. Popular in UK rave scene before 2013 ban. Still available as research chemical but less prevalent than during legal high era.
description.origins: Synthesized by David Nichols team at Purdue University in 1990s for research purposes. Remained obscure until late 2000s. Often sold mixed with 6-APB in 'Benzo Fury' products in UK 2010-2013. Emergency scheduled in UK 2013 alongside 6-APB. Less individually popular than 6-APB—usually encountered in mixtures. Chinese and European RC labs produced it. Now Schedule I in most countries. Still available on research chemical markets but 6-APB more common.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like empathy and euphoria, emotional openness, music enhancement, mild psychedelic visuals. Typically 50-100mg dose. Duration 6-10 hours. Often used at raves, festivals, parties. Described as slightly more psychedelic and less stimulating than 6-APB. Some users prefer it for stronger visuals; others find 6-APB more euphoric. Often sold mixed with 6-APB making individual effects hard to assess.
description.dangers: Long duration (8-10 hours) physically and mentally exhausting. Cardiovascular stress: increased heart rate and blood pressure over extended period. Serotonin depletion worse than MDMA due to longer duration—severe comedown possible. Neurotoxicity concerns similar to MDMA but less studied. Jaw clenching, muscle tension, hyperthermia risk. Insomnia for 12-18 hours after dosing. Higher doses cause intense psychedelic effects that can be overwhelming. Limited long-term safety data. Often mixed with 6-APB making dosing unpredictable. Cross-tolerance with MDMA. Recommended 3+ month breaks between uses. Sometimes sold as MDMA—test to verify.

scientific_papers.title: Benzofuran compounds: 5-APB and 6-APB pharmacology
scientific_papers.summary: Comparison of 5-APB and 6-APB effects and pharmacological profiles

testing.alt: purple to black (similar to MDMA but distinguishable)

notes: Component of 'Benzo Fury' (often mixed with 6-APB). Longer duration than MDMA (6-10 hours). Reagent reactions similar to 6-APB and MDMA—Mandelin green distinguishes from MDMA. Slightly more psychedelic than 6-APB. Often sold mixed with 6-APB making pure 5-APB rare. Test with multiple reagents. Cross-tolerance with MDMA and 6-APB. Wait 3+ months between uses.

description.overview: 5-MAPB (1-(benzofuran-5-yl)-N-methylpropan-2-amine) is a synthetic empathogen-entactogen from the benzofuran family. Closely related to 5-APB and 6-APB but with N-methyl group making it structurally most similar to MDMA. Described as most MDMA-like benzofuran. Produces strong empathy, euphoria, and emotional warmth with less stimulation than amphetamine-based empathogens. Duration 5-7 hours. Popular as 'legal MDMA' alternative before scheduling.
description.origins: Synthesized by David Nichols research team in 1990s. Remained obscure until 2010s research chemical boom. Gained popularity 2012-2014 as closest benzofuran to MDMA. Often sold separately from 5-APB/6-APB as 'premium' option. Emergency scheduled in UK 2013, various countries followed. Chinese labs primary manufacturers. Now Schedule I in most jurisdictions. Still available as research chemical. Considered by some users as best benzofuran for replicating MDMA experience.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Strong MDMA-like empathy and emotional connection, euphoria, music enhancement, tactile enhancement. Typical dose 50-100mg. Duration 5-7 hours. Less stimulating than MDMA—more 'chill' experience. Popular at intimate gatherings, festivals, therapeutic/introspective settings. Some users prefer it over MDMA for less 'speedy' effects. Others find it less euphoric than MDMA. Often described as 'rolling without rushing.'
description.dangers: Cardiovascular effects: tachycardia, hypertension. Serotonin depletion and comedown (though reportedly less harsh than MDMA). Neurotoxicity unknown but presumed similar to MDMA/5-APB. Jaw clenching, muscle tension, dehydration. Hyperthermia risk in hot environments. Insomnia for hours after effects end. Limited safety research—long-term effects unknown. Cross-tolerance with MDMA and other serotonergic empathogens. Can be overwhelming at high doses. Sometimes adulterated or mis-sold as MDMA. Recommended 3+ month breaks. Not as extensively studied as MDMA—unknowns remain.

scientific_papers.title: MDMA and benzofuran analogues: Comparative pharmacology
scientific_papers.summary: Comparison of 5-MAPB, MDMA, and other empathogenic benzofurans

notes: Most MDMA-like benzofuran—has N-methyl group like MDMA. Duration 5-7 hours. Turns blue with Simon's (like MDMA) due to secondary amine structure. Less stimulating than MDMA—described as 'rolling without rushing.' Mandelin green reaction distinguishes from MDMA (MDMA goes black). Often considered best benzofuran for replicating MDMA experience. Cross-tolerance with MDMA. Wait 3+ months between uses.

description.overview: Lorazepam (Ativan) is a pharmaceutical benzodiazepine prescribed for anxiety, insomnia, and seizures. Intermediate-acting (10-20 hour half-life). More potent than diazepam—1mg lorazepam ≈ 10mg diazepam. Common in medical settings for acute anxiety and seizure control. High abuse potential. Physical dependence develops rapidly. Dangerous withdrawal can be fatal. Frequently diverted for recreational use and combined with opioids (deadly).
description.origins: Developed by DJ Richards for Wyeth Pharmaceuticals. Patent filed 1963, FDA-approved 1977 for anxiety disorders. Became one of most prescribed benzos by 1980s-90s. Widely used in hospitals for acute anxiety, alcohol withdrawal, seizures. Schedule IV controlled substance. Now generic and widely available. Common diversion and black market sales. Often prescribed long-term despite recommendations for short-term use only.
description.uses: Medical: Anxiety disorders, panic attacks, insomnia, acute seizures, alcohol withdrawal, pre-surgical sedation, chemotherapy-induced nausea. Typical dose 0.5-2mg for anxiety, 2-4mg for insomnia. Recreational/diverted: Anxiety relief, sedation, euphoria (some users), sleep aid, potentiating opioids (dangerous), comedown management from stimulants. Often combined with alcohol (very dangerous). Duration 6-8 hours.
description.dangers: SEVERE ADDICTION: Physical dependence develops in weeks of daily use. Withdrawal can be FATAL—seizures, delirium tremens, psychosis. NEVER stop abruptly—medical taper required. Respiratory depression when combined with opioids, alcohol, or other CNS depressants—many deaths. Memory impairment, cognitive dysfunction, paradoxical anxiety. Blackouts and amnesia at higher doses. Rebound anxiety worse than original. Tolerance develops rapidly. Disinhibition leads to risky behavior. Extremely dangerous driving impairment. Often diverted—counterfeit Ativan may contain other benzos or fentanyl. Elderly at higher risk for falls, confusion. Long-term use linked to dementia.

scientific_papers.title: Lorazepam: Clinical pharmacology and therapeutic use
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of lorazepam pharmacology and medical applications

scientific_papers.title: Benzodiazepine dependence and withdrawal: Lorazepam case series
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of lorazepam dependence and withdrawal syndrome

notes: Ativan. Benzodiazepines show NO reagent reaction—cannot test with colorimetric reagents. Pharmaceutical pills should exactly match pill ID databases. Withdrawal can be FATAL—never stop cold turkey after regular use. Often combined with opioids—respiratory depression DEADLY. More potent than Valium (1mg = 10mg diazepam). Common in medical settings. Diverted pills may be counterfeit—verify source. Never combine with alcohol or opioids.

pill_verification.summary: Compare to pharmaceutical databases. Ativan pills should have specific imprints. If doesn't match exactly, may be counterfeit or different benzo.

description.overview: Modafinil (Provigil, Modalert) is a wakefulness-promoting medication approved for narcolepsy, sleep apnea, and shift work sleep disorder. NOT an amphetamine—unique mechanism of action. Produces wakefulness, alertness, and cognitive enhancement without traditional stimulant side effects. Popular as nootropic/'smart drug' for studying, productivity, and performance enhancement. Lower abuse potential than amphetamines. Widely diverted and used off-label by students, professionals, military.
description.origins: Developed by French neurophysiologist Michel Jouvet and Lafon Laboratories in 1970s. Originally called adrafinil prodrug. Modafinil (active metabolite) isolated and approved in France 1994 for narcolepsy. FDA-approved in US 1998. Marketed as non-addictive wakefulness drug. Military use documented (air force pilots, special forces). Became popular cognitive enhancer 2000s-2010s. Schedule IV in US (low abuse potential). Generic since 2012. Widely available via online pharmacies.
description.uses: Medical: Narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea, shift work sleep disorder. Typical dose 100-200mg once daily. Off-label/recreational: Cognitive enhancement, studying, productivity, staying awake for extended periods, ADHD (off-label), depression augmentation.
