Popular among students, tech workers, military, shift workers. Effects: Wakefulness, alertness, improved focus, reduced need for sleep. Duration 12-15 hours. Less euphoric than amphetamines—described as 'functional wakefulness.'
description.dangers: Serious skin reactions (rare but dangerous—Stevens-Johnson syndrome, DRESS). Cardiovascular effects: increased blood pressure and heart rate (milder than amphetamines). Psychiatric effects: anxiety, agitation, psychosis in susceptible individuals. Headache, nausea, insomnia (if taken too late). Dependence possible but less severe than amphetamines—psychological more than physical. Masks sleep deprivation—users stay awake dangerously long. Dangerous driving when sleep-deprived despite feeling alert. Interactions with hormonal birth control (reduced effectiveness). Rare but serious allergic reactions. Often purchased online from questionable sources—quality concerns.

scientific_papers.title: Modafinil: A review of neurochemical actions and effects on cognition
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of modafinil's unique mechanisms and cognitive enhancement effects

scientific_papers.title: Modafinil for cognitive enhancement in healthy non-sleep-deprived subjects
scientific_papers.summary: Systematic review showing modafinil improves cognition in healthy individuals

notes: Provigil, Modalert. NOT an amphetamine—unique wakefulness agent. Lower abuse potential but Schedule IV controlled substance. Pharmaceutical pills should match databases. Often purchased online from India pharmacies (Modalert)—quality variable. Duration 12-15 hours—don't take after noon or insomnia guaranteed. Can mask dangerous sleep deprivation—users feel alert but still cognitively impaired. Rare serious skin reactions—stop immediately if rash develops. May reduce birth control effectiveness.

description.overview: Dextroamphetamine (d-amphetamine, Dexedrine) is the dextrorotatory stereoisomer of amphetamine. More potent and euphoric than racemic amphetamine. Prescribed for ADHD and narcolepsy. Main active component of Adderall (which is 75% d-amphetamine, 25% l-amphetamine). Produces stronger CNS effects with less peripheral side effects than racemic amphetamine. High abuse potential. Common diversion among students.
description.origins: Isolated as the more active enantiomer of amphetamine in 1930s. Marketed as Dexedrine by Smith, Kline & French in 1937. Widely used by military in WWII (both Allies and Axis). Became popular for weight loss and energy in 1950s-60s. Scheduled as controlled substance 1971. Adderall (mixed amphetamine salts with d-amphetamine as main component) introduced 1996. Still prescribed for ADHD. Schedule II controlled substance. Generic formulations available.
description.uses: Medical: ADHD (Dexedrine, component of Adderall), narcolepsy. Typical dose 5-40mg daily. Recreational/Academic: Cognitive enhancement, studying, increased focus and energy, euphoria, weight loss. Popular among college students during exams. Typical recreational dose 10-40mg. Duration 4-6 hours (immediate-release), 8-12 hours (extended-release Dexedrine Spansule). Effects: More euphoric and less jittery than racemic amphetamine. Preferred recreationally over mixed salts by some users.
description.dangers: Similar to amphetamine: Cardiovascular risks (tachycardia, hypertension, risk of heart attack/stroke), high abuse potential, tolerance and psychological dependence, neurotoxicity at high doses, psychosis and paranoia with chronic use or high doses, appetite suppression and malnutrition, insomnia, anxiety, irritability. More euphoric than racemic amphetamine = higher abuse potential. Compulsive redosing. Severe comedown: fatigue, depression. Withdrawal: extreme fatigue, depression, hypersomnia. Nasal damage from snorting. Counterfeit Dexedrine/Adderall pills may contain methamphetamine. Dangerous when mixed with other stimulants or MAOIs.

scientific_papers.title: Dextroamphetamine vs mixed amphetamine salts: Comparative efficacy
scientific_papers.summary: Comparison of d-amphetamine to mixed salts (Adderall) for ADHD treatment

notes: Dexedrine. Main component of Adderall (75% d-amphetamine). More euphoric than racemic amphetamine—higher abuse potential. Reagent tests CANNOT distinguish d-amphetamine from l-amphetamine or methamphetamine—all give orange/brown reactions. Pharmaceutical pills should match pill ID databases. More potent than racemic amphetamine (1mg d-amphetamine ≈ 2mg racemic). Popular for studying but significant addiction risk.

description.overview: Nitrous oxide (N2O, laughing gas, whippits, nangs) is a dissociative anesthetic gas used medically and recreationally. Legal for medical/dental use and food preparation (whipped cream chargers). Produces brief (1-3 minute) euphoria, dissociation, and laughter. Extremely popular at music festivals and parties. Generally considered low-risk for single use but dangerous with chronic heavy use (vitamin B12 depletion). Very common—often underestimated due to legal status.
description.origins: Discovered by Joseph Priestley in 1772. Anesthetic properties recognized by Humphry Davy in 1799 who hosted 'laughing gas' parties. Introduced to dentistry/surgery 1840s-1860s. Still used medically (dental anesthesia, childbirth pain relief). Recreational use documented since 1800s. Legal to sell for legitimate purposes (whipped cream chargers). Extremely widespread recreational use at festivals, concerts, parking lots. Easy access makes it one of most commonly used inhalants.
description.uses: Medical: Dental anesthesia, pain relief during childbirth, minor surgical procedures. Recreational: Euphoria, laughter, brief dissociation, audio distortions, out-of-body sensations. Typical use: 1-3 chargers (8g each) inhaled from balloon or whipped cream dispenser. Duration 1-3 minutes. Often repeated multiple times in session. Extremely popular at festivals (vendors sell balloons). Used by all demographics due to legal status and accessibility. Effects described as 'wah-wah' sound distortions, time dilation, floating sensation.
description.dangers: VITAMIN B12 DEPLETION: Chronic heavy use (multiple sessions per week) inactivates vitamin B12, causing nerve damage (peripheral neuropathy), anemia, cognitive impairment. Can be permanent if not caught early. OXYGEN DEPRIVATION: Inhaling pure N2O without oxygen causes hypoxia—brain damage, unconsciousness, death. Always use with balloon (allows some oxygen mixing). FALLS AND INJURIES: Dissociation causes loss of balance—never use while standing. Deaths from falling. FROSTBITE: Direct inhalation from charger or tank causes severe frostbite to mouth, throat, lungs. ALWAYS use balloon. Tank use especially dangerous—can deliver too much pressure. Combining with other depressants (alcohol, ketamine) increases unconsciousness risk. Heavy use can cause SUDDEN DEATH from cardiac arrhythmia. Not suitable for people with B12 deficiency, megaloblastic anemia, or neurological conditions.

scientific_papers.title: Nitrous oxide-induced vitamin B12 deficiency and neuropathy
scientific_papers.summary: Case reports of severe B12 deficiency and nerve damage from chronic nitrous oxide use

scientific_papers.title: Recreational nitrous oxide abuse: Prevalence and neurotoxicity
scientific_papers.summary: Study documenting increasing recreational use and neurological complications

testing.alt: N/A - cannot test gas with reagents

notes: Whippits, nangs, laughing gas. Cannot be tested with reagents (gas form). VERY common at festivals—often underestimated due to legal status. Major dangers: (1) VITAMIN B12 DEPLETION with chronic heavy use—causes permanent nerve damage. Supplement B12 if using regularly. (2) NEVER inhale directly from charger or tank—causes frostbite. ALWAYS use balloon. (3) ALWAYS sit or lie down—falls cause serious injuries. (4) Ensure some oxygen in mix—pure N2O causes hypoxia. Generally low-risk for occasional use but heavy users (multiple times per week) at serious risk for B12 deficiency. Consider one of safest recreational drugs for single use but dangerous with chronic abuse.

b12_supplementation.summary: If using N2O regularly (multiple times per week), supplement vitamin B12 (methylcobalamin 1000mcg daily). Watch for symptoms: numbness, tingling in extremities, weakness, cognitive issues. Stop use immediately if symptoms appear.

description.overview: 4-HO-MET (4-hydroxy-N-methyl-N-ethyltryptamine, Metocin) is a synthetic psilocybin analogue and research chemical. Structurally very similar to psilocin (4-HO-DMT from magic mushrooms). Produces visual-heavy psychedelic experience with less headspace/introspection than psilocybin. Shorter duration (4-6 hours vs 6-8 hours). Popular as 'shrooms lite'—easier, more recreational psychedelic. Less likely to cause difficult/challenging experiences than psilocybin.
description.origins: First synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in TiHKAL (Tryptamines I Have Known And Loved) 1997. Remained obscure until mid-2000s research chemical boom. Gained popularity 2008-2012 as legal psilocybin alternative. Often marketed as 'research chemical,' 'not for human consumption.' Chinese and European labs produce it. Legal status varies—unscheduled in some countries, controlled in others (UK banned 2016). Still widely available on research chemical markets. Considered one of most popular 4-substituted tryptamines.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Visual psychedelic effects (geometric patterns, color enhancement, breathing walls), euphoria, giggles, music enhancement. Less introspective/philosophical than psilocybin—more 'fun' and recreational. Typical dose 15-25mg. Duration 4-6 hours. Popular at festivals, concerts, and recreational settings. Described as more controllable and less intense emotionally than mushrooms. Some prefer it for social psychedelic experiences. Others find it lacks depth of classic psychedelics.
description.dangers: Similar to psilocybin but less studied: Anxiety, paranoia, bad trips possible (though reportedly less common than psilocybin). Confusion, disorientation. Nausea common. Increased heart rate and blood pressure. Not physically dangerous but psychological distress significant for some users. Dangerous behavior while impaired (wandering into traffic, etc.). Long-term effects unknown—not as extensively researched as psilocybin. Can trigger latent mental illness (psychosis, schizophrenia) in predisposed individuals. Not suitable for people with personal or family history of psychotic disorders. Often sold as psilocybin/mushroom extracts—dosing confusion possible. Cross-tolerance with psilocybin and LSD.

scientific_papers.title: Pharmacology of 4-substituted tryptamines: Comparison to psilocin
scientific_papers.summary: Study comparing 4-HO-MET and related tryptamines to psilocin pharmacologically

notes: Metocin. Psilocybin analogue—'shrooms lite.' Visual-heavy, less introspective/emotional than real mushrooms. Shorter duration (4-6 hours). Ehrlich/Hofmann turn purple confirming indole/tryptamine but CANNOT distinguish 4-HO-MET from psilocin, 4-AcO-DMT, or other tryptamines. Often sold as psilocybin or mushroom extracts. Considered one of easier, more recreational psychedelics. Popular as legal psilocybin alternative before regional scheduling. Cross-tolerance with mushrooms, LSD.

description.overview: Ethylone (bk-MDEA, 3,4-methylenedioxy-N-ethylcathinone) is a synthetic cathinone empathogen, the beta-ketone analogue of MDEA (Eve). Similar to methylone but with ethyl group instead of methyl. Produces MDMA-like effects but shorter duration and less empathogenic. Less common than methylone but still encountered as MDMA substitute. Duration 2-4 hours. More stimulating than empathogenic.
description.origins: Developed as research chemical in mid-2000s. Gained some popularity 2009-2012 as MDMA/methylone alternative. Never as popular as methylone—usually secondary choice. Often found in pills sold as MDMA alongside methylone. Scheduled in many countries 2012-2014 following methylone. Chinese labs produced it. Now less common—largely replaced by eutylone and n-ethylpentylone. Still occasionally encountered in research chemical markets or mis-sold as MDMA.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: MDMA-like empathy and euphoria but weaker and more stimulating. Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 2-4 hours. Used at raves, festivals. Often compared unfavorably to methylone (which itself compared unfavorably to MDMA). Described as more 'speedy' and less 'rolling' than MDMA. Some compulsive redosing. Most users consume unknowingly expecting MDMA.
description.dangers: Similar to methylone: Cardiovascular stress, hyperthermia and dehydration, serotonin depletion and comedown, compulsive redosing due to short duration. Stimulating effects can cause anxiety, restlessness. Often sold as MDMA—users don't know what they're taking. Unknown long-term effects. Less studied than methylone. Jaw clenching, muscle tension. Cross-tolerance with MDMA and other serotonergic drugs. Not as empathogenic as MDMA—disappointing for users seeking connection/therapeutic effects.

scientific_papers.title: Ethylone and other cathinone substitutes for MDMA
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of ethylone presence in pills sold as MDMA

testing.alt: yellow to orange (NOT purple like MDMA)
NO blue (unlike MDMA which turns blue)

notes: bk-MDEA. Less common MDMA substitute (less popular than methylone). Yellow/orange Marquis, NO Simon's blue = cathinone not MDMA. Cannot distinguish ethylone from methylone/eutylone by reagent alone—all cathinones give similar reactions. More stimulating, less empathogenic than MDMA. Shorter duration (2-4 hours) leads to redosing. Often found in pills sold as MDMA. Test to verify.

description.overview: 4-AcO-DMT (4-acetoxy-N,N-dimethyltryptamine, Psilacetin) is a synthetic psilocybin analogue and research chemical. Likely metabolizes to psilocin (4-HO-DMT) in the body, producing nearly identical effects to magic mushrooms. Duration 4-6 hours. Extremely popular as legal psilocybin alternative. Described as indistinguishable from mushrooms by many users. Easier to dose precisely than mushrooms.
description.origins: First synthesized by Albert Hofmann (LSD discoverer) at Sandoz 1963, documented in patents but not developed. Remained obscure until 2000s research chemical boom. Gained massive popularity 2010-present as most accurate legal psilocybin substitute. Widely available on research chemical markets. Legal status varies—unscheduled in many countries, banned in some (UK 2017). Chinese and European labs produce it. Considered best psilocybin RC by many users.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational/therapeutic: Identical to psilocybin mushrooms—introspection, emotional processing, visual effects, mystical experiences, nature connection. Typical dose 15-25mg (equivalent to 2-3g mushrooms). Duration 4-6 hours. Used for same purposes as mushrooms: spiritual exploration, therapy, creativity, recreation. Advantage: Precise dosing (powder/capsules) vs variable mushroom potency. Many users prefer it to mushrooms for consistency.
description.dangers: Same as psilocybin: Anxiety, paranoia, bad trips (psychological distress), confusion, disorientation. Nausea common. Not physically dangerous but psychologically intense. Can trigger latent psychosis in predisposed individuals. Not suitable for people with personal/family history of psychotic disorders. Challenging experiences possible—requires proper set and setting. Cross-tolerance with psilocybin, LSD, and other tryptamines. Impaired judgment—dangerous behavior possible. Long-term effects unknown but presumed similar to psilocybin.

scientific_papers.title: 4-AcO-DMT as psilocybin prodrug: Pharmacological analysis
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis showing 4-AcO-DMT likely converts to psilocin in vivo

notes: Psilacetin. Psilocybin prodrug—metabolizes to psilocin (active compound in mushrooms). Effects virtually identical to magic mushrooms. Most popular psilocybin RC—considered most accurate substitute. Ehrlich/Hofmann purple confirms tryptamine but CANNOT distinguish from psilocin, 4-HO-MET, or other indoles. Often sold as 'synthetic psilocybin' or mushroom extract. Advantage: precise dosing vs variable mushroom potency. Cross-tolerance with mushrooms and LSD.

description.overview: 2C-E (2,5-dimethoxy-4-ethylphenethylamine) is a psychedelic phenethylamine from the 2C-x family. More intense and less predictable than 2C-B. Shorter duration than DOx series (4-8 hours). Produces strong visual effects and 'challenging' headspace. Often described as difficult or uncomfortable but insightful. Popular in psychonaut communities.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Remained obscure until 2000s research chemical boom. Gained popularity 2005-2015 as legal psychedelic. Often compared unfavorably to 2C-B (more difficult, less euphoric). Emergency scheduled in many countries 2012-2016. Chinese labs produced it. Now less common than peak popularity. Considered more 'serious' or 'dark' than other 2C-x compounds.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Strong psychedelic visuals, introspection, challenging thought patterns. Typical dose 10-20mg. Duration 4-8 hours. Used for therapeutic/spiritual exploration. Described as 'teacher' substance—provides insights but not necessarily pleasant. Some users find it valuable for personal growth; others find it too uncomfortable. Less recreational than 2C-B.
description.dangers: Physically uncomfortable: nausea, body load, muscle tension common. Can cause difficult psychological experiences—anxiety, confusion, existential distress. Less 'fun' than 2C-B. Vasoconstriction. Challenging headspace can be overwhelming. Reports of lasting anxiety after difficult trips. Dose-sensitive—small increases cause major intensity jumps. Can trigger HPPD. Often sold as 2C-B or other substances—verify with testing.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-E and related phenethylamines: Structure-activity relationships
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of 2C-E pharmacology compared to other 2C-x compounds

notes: More intense and challenging than 2C-B. Duration 4-8 hours. Green Marquis reaction (similar to 2C-B but can vary). Ehrlich negative (phenethylamine). Often described as uncomfortable or difficult—strong body load. Considered 'serious' psychedelic for introspection, not recreation. Dose-sensitive. Sometimes sold as 2C-B—verify with testing. Not recommended for beginners.

description.overview: DPT (N,N-Dipropyltryptamine) is a psychedelic tryptamine structurally related to DMT. When smoked, produces short intense trip similar to DMT but longer (1-2 hours vs 10-15 minutes). When taken orally or insufflated, lasts 2-4 hours. Known for 'darker' or more challenging experiences than DMT. Used in religious contexts by Temple of the True Inner Light church.
description.origins: First synthesized 1950s. Studied in 1960s-70s for potential therapeutic use. Adopted by Temple of the True Inner Light (NYC) as sacrament since 1980s. Remained obscure until 2000s research chemical availability. Less popular than DMT due to more difficult experiences. Legal status varies—unscheduled federally in US but some state bans. Still available on research chemical markets.
description.uses: Religious: Sacrament in Temple of the True Inner Light church. Recreational/spiritual: Short intense psychedelic experiences (smoked), longer introspective trips (oral). Typical dose 50-100mg oral, 20-50mg smoked. Duration 1-2 hours smoked, 2-4 hours oral. Used for spiritual exploration, introspection. Described as more challenging and 'darker' than DMT—less euphoric, more introspective.
description.dangers: Psychologically intense—can cause anxiety, paranoia, difficult experiences. Often described as 'darker' or more challenging than DMT. Nausea common, especially oral. Confusion, disorientation. Can trigger latent mental illness. Not suitable for those with psychotic disorder history. Less forgiving than DMT according to users. Vasoconstriction. Body load. Cross-tolerance with other tryptamines.

scientific_papers.title: DPT: Pharmacology and subjective effects
scientific_papers.summary: Early clinical study of DPT's psychedelic effects

notes: Dipropyltryptamine. DMT relative but darker/more challenging according to users. Ehrlich/Hofmann purple (tryptamine) but cannot distinguish from DMT or other tryptamines. Smoked: 1-2 hours (longer than DMT's 10-15 min). Oral: 2-4 hours. Used as religious sacrament by Temple of the True Inner Light. Less recreational, more introspective than DMT. Not recommended for beginners.

description.overview: 3-HO-PCP (3-hydroxyphencyclidine) is a dissociative research chemical related to PCP and 3-MeO-PCP. More sedating and euphoric than 3-MeO-PCP, less manic. Duration 4-8 hours. Known for warm, opiate-like euphoria combined with dissociation. Very potent (5-15mg active). Popular in dissociative RC community but carries significant addiction risk.
description.origins: Research chemical appearing on markets around 2015-2016. Designed as analogue to 3-MeO-PCP with different effects profile. Less manic and more 'warm' than 3-MeO-PCP. Chinese labs primary manufacturers. Legal status varies—unscheduled in many regions. Gained popularity for less stimulating, more euphoric profile than 3-MeO-PCP. Still widely available on RC markets.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Warm euphoria, dissociation, sedation, music enhancement. Typical dose 5-15mg. Duration 4-8 hours. Popular among dissociative enthusiasts. Described as combination of opioid warmth and ketamine dissociation. Less 'hole' inducing than ketamine at normal doses. Some compulsive redosing but less than 3-MeO-PCP. Used for relaxation, introspection.
description.dangers: HIGH ADDICTION POTENTIAL: Euphoria leads to compulsive use. Tolerance develops quickly. Psychological dependence common. Bladder damage possible with chronic use (like ketamine). Respiratory depression when combined with depressants. Memory impairment. Confusion, poor coordination. Less manic than 3-MeO-PCP but still risk of poor judgment. Dangerous when mixed with alcohol, opioids, benzos. Long-term effects unknown. Withdrawal includes depression, anhedonia.

scientific_papers.title: 3-HO-PCP and related dissociative arylcyclohexylamines
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of 3-HO-PCP pharmacology and emergence on drug markets

notes: More sedating and euphoric than 3-MeO-PCP. Less manic but HIGH addiction risk due to pleasant effects. Cannot distinguish from PCP/3-MeO-PCP by reagent alone. Duration 4-8 hours. Very potent (5-15mg). Described as 'warm' dissociative with opioid-like euphoria. Bladder damage possible with chronic use. Popular but addictive. Not recommended due to high dependence potential.

description.overview: Clonazolam is an extremely potent designer benzodiazepine, roughly 2-3x stronger than alprazolam (Xanax). Never approved for medical use. Produces intense sedation, amnesia, and muscle relaxation. Duration 6-10 hours. Notorious for causing severe blackouts, compulsive redosing, and rapid dependence. One of the most dangerous RC benzos.
description.origins: Developed as research chemical around 2014-2015. Never approved for medical use anywhere. Rapidly gained notoriety for extreme potency and dangerous blackouts. Frequently sold as liquid drops or pressed pills. Common in RC benzo scene. Emergency scheduled in several jurisdictions 2019-2020. Still widely available despite scheduling. Known for ruining lives due to rapid addiction and blackout behavior.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational/self-medication: Extreme anxiety relief, sedation, sleep aid, Xanax-like effects but much stronger. Typical dose 0.25-0.5mg (extremely potent). Duration 6-10 hours. Mostly used by those seeking strong benzo effects or with high tolerance. Extreme amnesia common. Compulsive redosing during blackouts leads to taking massive doses unknowingly.
description.dangers: EXTREME DANGER: Ultra-potent—easy overdose. Severe blackouts lasting 12-24+ hours. Compulsive redosing during blackouts—users take entire bottles. Physical dependence develops EXTREMELY rapidly (days of use). Withdrawal can be FATAL—seizures, delirium, death. Respiratory depression with depressants. Disinhibition causes dangerous/criminal behavior. Many reports of waking up in jail, hospitals with no memory. Tolerance skyrockets. Nearly impossible harm reduction due to amnesia. Often mixed with other substances in pressed pills.

scientific_papers.title: Clonazolam and designer benzodiazepines: Emerging threats
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of clonazolam's extreme potency and risks

notes: EXTREME DANGER: 2-3x more potent than Xanax. Benzos show NO reagent reaction. Causes severe blackouts, compulsive redosing, RAPID dependence (days). Withdrawal FATAL. Considered one of most dangerous RC benzos—many horror stories. Often in liquid form (hard to dose). DO NOT USE unless experienced with benzos and aware of extreme risks. Harm reduction nearly impossible due to amnesia.

description.overview: Bromazolam is a designer benzodiazepine similar in potency to alprazolam (Xanax). Never approved for medical use. Duration 6-8 hours. Less potent than clonazolam but still dangerous. Produces anxiety relief, sedation, and amnesia. Common in pressed pills sold as Xanax. High addiction potential and dangerous withdrawal.
description.origins: Research chemical appearing around 2016-2018. Never medically approved. Designed as Xanax analogue. Became popular as clonazolam alternative (less potent = slightly safer). Frequently pressed into fake Xanax bars. Chinese manufacturers. Legal in some regions, banned in others. Widely available despite scheduling attempts. Common in current RC benzo market.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational/self-medication: Anxiety relief, sedation, sleep aid, similar to Xanax. Typical dose 1-3mg. Duration 6-8 hours. Popular among those seeking Xanax effects or with RC benzo tolerance. Causes amnesia and blackouts at higher doses. Some compulsive redosing. Often consumed unknowingly in fake Xanax bars.
description.dangers: Physical dependence develops rapidly. Withdrawal can be FATAL—seizures, delirium. Blackouts and amnesia common at recreational doses. Respiratory depression when combined with opioids/alcohol—FATAL. Disinhibition leads to risky behavior. Impaired driving. Found in counterfeit Xanax bars—often with fentanyl. Tolerance develops. Less extreme than clonazolam but still very dangerous. Medical taper required if dependent.

scientific_papers.title: Bromazolam: A novel benzodiazepine in counterfeit pharmaceuticals
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of bromazolam in fake Xanax pills

notes: Xanax-strength RC benzo in fake bars. Benzos show NO reagent reaction. Less potent than clonazolam but still dangerous. Withdrawal FATAL—never stop cold turkey. Blackouts common. Test fake Xanax with fentanyl strips—often contains fentanyl too. Similar potency to real alprazolam but may have fentanyl or other adulterants. Never combine with opioids or alcohol.

description.overview: Carfentanil (carfentanyl) is the most potent commercially used opioid—estimated 10,000x more potent than morphine and 100x more potent than fentanyl. Developed as large animal tranquilizer for elephants, rhinos, bears. Active doses measured in MICROGRAMS. Appeared in illicit drug supply 2016-2017 causing mass overdose events. Even brief skin contact or inhalation dangerous. ONE GRAIN OF SALT can be lethal. Schedule II controlled substance.
description.origins: Synthesized by Janssen Pharmaceutica 1974 as ultra-potent analgesic. Only approved use: veterinary medicine for immobilizing large animals (elephants 10,000+ lbs). Brand name Wildnil. Appeared in US heroin supply 2016 (Ohio, Florida mass overdoses). Also found in fake pills, cocaine. Likely diverted from veterinary sources or synthesized in clandestine labs. DEA emergency scheduling intensified.
description.uses: Medical: Large animal (elephant/rhino) tranquilizer ONLY. Dosed in micrograms. Typical elephant dose 1-3mg. Illicit: Adulterating heroin, fentanyl, fake pills. Users NEVER aware they're consuming carfentanil—sold as heroin/fentanyl. Impossible to dose—active amount invisible to naked eye. Used to 'boost' potency of weak heroin.
description.dangers: EXTREME LETHALITY—100x fentanyl potency. 20 MICROGRAMS (smaller than grain of salt) potentially FATAL to humans. Impossible to dose accurately. Respiratory arrest within seconds to minutes. Skin absorption possible—first responders endangered. Naloxone requires MASSIVE doses (10-20mg+), continuous IV infusion. Standard 2-4mg Narcan often insufficient. Death can occur before help arrives. Found mixed in drugs—users have no idea. Mass casualty incidents reported (Cincinnati 2016: 174 overdoses in 6 days). Respiratory protection required for first responders. No legitimate human medical use. Antidote may not work—too potent.

scientific_papers.title: Carfentanil: A Narrative Review of Its Pharmacology and Public Health Concerns
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of carfentanil pharmacology, public health impact, and clinical management

scientific_papers.title: Carfentanil and the Rise of Ultra-Potent Opioids
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of carfentanil's emergence in US drug supply and overdose crisis impact

scientific_papers.title: Mass Fentanyl Intoxication: A Syndromic Approach to Care
scientific_papers.summary: Clinical management strategies for carfentanil and ultra-potent opioid mass overdose events

notes: Carfentanil. MOST POTENT opioid in drug supply. 10,000x morphine, 100x fentanyl. Elephant tranquilizer. 20 MICROGRAMS (grain of salt) FATAL. Skin contact dangerous. Requires 10-20mg+ naloxone IV. Mass overdose events (Ohio 2016). Users NEVER aware. First responders need respiratory PPE. Schedule II. NO human medical use. Represents worst-case synthetic opioid. Orange Marquis. EXTREME DANGER.

description.overview: Methadone is a long-acting synthetic opioid (24-36 hour half-life) used for chronic pain and opioid addiction treatment. Gold standard for medication-assisted treatment (MAT). Prevents withdrawal and reduces cravings without euphoria at therapeutic doses. Also diverted and abused. Dangerous due to very long half-life—overdoses can occur days after starting.
description.origins: Developed in Germany 1937-1939 by scientists at IG Farben. Used in WWII Germany when morphine scarce. Brought to US post-war. FDA-approved 1947 for pain. Introduced for opioid addiction treatment in 1960s by Drs. Dole and Nyswander in NYC. Became standard MAT despite controversy. Heavily regulated—only dispensed at specialized clinics for addiction treatment. Generic and widely available but controlled distribution.
description.uses: Medical: Opioid use disorder treatment (daily dosing at methadone clinics), chronic severe pain (long-acting option). Typical dose 40-120mg daily for MAT, 10-40mg for pain. Duration 24-36 hours (single dose) but accumulates with daily dosing. Recreational/diverted: Opioid high, preventing withdrawal. Duration much longer than heroin—appeals to some, others find it too long. Take-home bottles frequently diverted.
description.dangers: VERY DANGEROUS OVERDOSE PROFILE: Long half-life means effects accumulate—safe on day 1, overdose on day 3. Respiratory depression FATAL, especially with other depressants. QT prolongation (cardiac arrhythmia risk). Extremely difficult withdrawal (2-4 weeks of acute symptoms vs 5-7 days for heroin). Sedation, cognitive impairment. Deaths common when switching from short-acting opioids (heroin) to methadone (underestimate potency). Diverted 'take-homes' dangerous—liquid formulation hard to dose. Drug interactions with benzos, alcohol FATAL.

scientific_papers.title: Methadone for opioid dependence: 50 years of clinical experience
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of methadone maintenance treatment efficacy and safety

testing.alt: orange to yellow (different from typical opioid purple)

notes: Long-acting opioid (24-36 hrs). DANGEROUS: Accumulates over days—can overdose on day 3 even if day 1 felt safe. Reagent reactions differ from morphine-based opioids (orange vs purple). Used in MAT clinics. Diverted liquid 'take-homes' dangerous. Withdrawal extremely prolonged (weeks). Test with fentanyl strips if source unknown. Never combine with benzos or alcohol—FATAL.

description.overview: Buprenorphine (Suboxone, Subutex) is a partial opioid agonist used for opioid addiction treatment and chronic pain. Unique 'ceiling effect' makes overdose difficult but not impossible. Blocks other opioids, precipitates withdrawal if taken too soon after full agonist opioids. Gold standard for MAT alongside methadone. Also widely diverted and abused, especially by those in withdrawal.
description.origins: Developed in 1960s-70s, FDA-approved 2002 for opioid dependence (Suboxone with naloxone, Subutex without). Revolutionary because it can be prescribed in office settings unlike methadone (clinic-only). Became widely used for MAT. Suboxone combines buprenorphine with naloxone to deter IV abuse. Generic versions available. Strict prescribing regulations but more accessible than methadone. Widely diverted—street market significant.
description.uses: Medical: Opioid use disorder treatment (Suboxone/Subutex), chronic pain (buprenorphine patch). Typical MAT dose 8-24mg daily sublingual. Duration 24-72 hours. Recreational/diverted: Preventing withdrawal, mild opioid high (ceiling effect limits euphoria), managing pain. Popular on street for self-treatment of withdrawal. IV abuse attempts despite naloxone (bioavailability issue makes it ineffective deterrent). Film strips easier to divert than pills.
description.dangers: PRECIPITATED WITHDRAWAL: Taking buprenorphine while full agonist opioids still in system causes SEVERE immediate withdrawal (buprenorphine displaces other opioids from receptors). Must wait 12-24+ hours after last heroin/fentanyl use. Respiratory depression possible, especially when combined with benzos, alcohol—many deaths. 'Ceiling effect' not absolute—high doses or combinations still dangerous. Very difficult withdrawal (weeks of symptoms). Diverted strips/pills dangerous if dosing unknown. Can be abused despite partial agonist profile. Neonatal abstinence syndrome if used in pregnancy (still preferred over full agonists).

scientific_papers.title: Buprenorphine for opioid use disorder: Clinical review
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of buprenorphine efficacy and safety for MAT

notes: Suboxone/Subutex. Critical MAT medication. DANGER: Causes precipitated withdrawal if taken too soon after full opioid use—wait 12-24+ hours. Partial agonist with ceiling effect but still causes respiratory depression with benzos/alcohol. Long duration (24-72 hrs). Widely diverted. Orange/yellow Marquis (differs from morphine-based opioids). Test with fentanyl strips if source unknown.

description.overview: O-PCE (2'-oxo-PCE, Eticyclidone) is a dissociative research chemical related to PCP and ketamine. More potent than ketamine, longer duration (4-8 hours). Produces strong dissociation and 'holes.' Less manic than 3-MeO-PCP, less warm than 3-HO-PCP. Known for clean dissociation. Very potent (5-15mg). Popular in dissociative RC community.
description.origins: Research chemical appearing around 2012-2014. Designed as ketamine/PCP analogue with unique profile. Chinese labs primary manufacturers. Legal in some regions, banned in others. Gained popularity for strong dissociative effects without excessive mania or stimulation. Still widely available on RC markets. Considered one of better ketamine alternatives by enthusiasts.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Strong dissociation, 'holes,' out-of-body experiences, music enhancement. Typical dose 5-15mg. Duration 4-8 hours. Popular among dissociative users. Described as 'clean' dissociation—less confusing than some analogues. Hole doses possible. Used for introspection, escapism, recreation. Some compulsive redosing.
description.dangers: Bladder toxicity possible with chronic use (like ketamine). Confusion, memory impairment, poor coordination. Dissociation impairs judgment—dangerous behavior possible. Respiratory depression when combined with depressants. Tolerance develops. Psychological dependence. Long-term effects unknown. Can cause anxiety, paranoia in some users. Very potent—easy to take too much. Dangerous when mixed with alcohol, benzos, opioids.

scientific_papers.title: O-PCE and related dissociative compounds in the drug market
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of O-PCE emergence as ketamine alternative

notes: Eticyclidone. Potent dissociative (5-15mg). Duration 4-8 hours. Cannot distinguish from PCP/ketamine analogues by reagent alone. Described as 'clean' dissociation without excessive mania. Hole doses possible. Bladder damage risk with chronic use. Popular ketamine alternative. Less studied than ketamine—unknowns remain.

description.overview: 3-MeO-PCE (3-methoxyeticyclidine) is a dissociative research chemical related to 3-MeO-PCP. Similar manic/stimulating profile to 3-MeO-PCP but slightly different character. Duration 4-8 hours. Very potent (5-15mg). Known for stimulation, mania potential, and compulsive redosing. Popular but carries significant risks.
description.origins: Research chemical appearing around 2014-2016. Designed as 3-MeO-PCP variant. Chinese manufacturers. Legal in some regions, banned in others. Gained popularity as 3-MeO-PCP alternative with slightly different effects. Still widely available. Known in dissociative RC community but controversial due to mania and addiction potential.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Dissociation, stimulation, euphoria, music enhancement. Typical dose 5-15mg. Duration 4-8 hours. Used for similar purposes as 3-MeO-PCP. Some users prefer it; others find it too manic. Compulsive redosing common. Popular among dissociative enthusiasts but risky.
description.dangers: MANIC EPISODES: Similar to 3-MeO-PCP—delusions of sobriety, poor judgment, dangerous behavior. Very stimulating. Compulsive redosing while dissociated. Bladder damage with chronic use. Tachycardia, hypertension. Confusion, memory issues. Psychological dependence. Tolerance develops rapidly. Dangerous with other depressants. Long-term effects unknown. Can cause psychotic episodes.

scientific_papers.title: 3-MeO-PCE: A novel dissociative arylcyclohexylamine
scientific_papers.summary: First documentation of 3-MeO-PCE toxicity cases

notes: Similar to 3-MeO-PCP—manic, stimulating dissociative. Very potent (5-15mg). Cannot distinguish from PCP analogues by reagent. Duration 4-8 hours. Causes delusions of sobriety and poor judgment. Compulsive redosing common. Bladder damage possible. Addiction risk. Not recommended due to mania potential.

description.overview: Temazepam (Restoril) is an intermediate-acting benzodiazepine prescribed primarily for insomnia. Duration 6-8 hours. More hypnotic (sleep-inducing) than anxiolytic compared to other benzos. Widely prescribed sleep aid but significant abuse potential, especially via IV injection of gel caps (dangerous). Popular in UK and Europe.
description.origins: Synthesized 1964, marketed by Wyeth. FDA-approved 1981 for insomnia. Became one of most prescribed sleep medications. Schedule IV controlled substance. Gel capsule formulation notorious for IV abuse (especially UK in 1980s-90s)—formulation changed to reduce this. Generic widely available. Common in medical settings and diverted to street.
description.uses: Medical: Short-term insomnia treatment. Typical dose 7.5-30mg at bedtime. Duration 6-8 hours (good for full night sleep). Recreational/diverted: Sleep aid, sedation, anxiety relief, euphoria (especially IV—dangerous). Popular among those with opioid use disorder. IV abuse of gel caps historically significant problem. Often combined with opioids (deadly).
description.dangers: Physical dependence with regular use—withdrawal FATAL (seizures). Respiratory depression when combined with opioids, alcohol—many deaths. IV injection of gel caps extremely dangerous: thrombosis, gangrene, limb amputations reported (UK epidemic 1980s-90s). Blackouts, amnesia. 'Sleep-driving' and other complex behaviors while not fully awake. Tolerance develops. Hangover effects next day. Counterfeit pills may contain other substances.

scientific_papers.title: Temazepam abuse: Clinical consequences of IV injection
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of severe complications from IV temazepam gel cap injection

notes: Restoril. Sleep-focused benzo. Benzos show NO reagent reaction. Withdrawal FATAL—never stop abruptly. NEVER inject gel caps—causes thrombosis, gangrene, amputations (UK epidemic documented). Often combined with opioids—respiratory depression FATAL. Popular sleep aid but significant abuse potential. Verify pharmaceutical pills with databases.

description.overview: 2C-I (2,5-dimethoxy-4-iodophenethylamine) is a psychedelic phenethylamine from the 2C-x family, similar to 2C-B but slightly more intense. Duration 6-10 hours. Produces strong visual hallucinations, color enhancement, and euphoria. Popular in rave/psychonaut communities as 2C-B alternative. More intense body load than 2C-B. Generally considered second most popular 2C compound after 2C-B.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Remained obscure until 2000s research chemical boom. Gained popularity 2005-2015 as legal psychedelic, especially in Europe. Often marketed as similar to 2C-B but more visual. Emergency scheduled in many countries 2012-2016. Still available on RC markets. Known deaths from overdose (mistaking mg for common doses).
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Visual hallucinations (geometric patterns, color enhancement, tracers), euphoria, enhanced music appreciation, tactile sensations. Typical dose 14-25mg. Duration 6-10 hours. Used at raves, festivals, concerts. Described as more intense and visual than 2C-B. Some prefer it; others find body load uncomfortable. Less 'gentle' than 2C-B.
description.dangers: DOSE-SENSITIVE: Small increases cause major intensity jumps. Several deaths from overdose (taking 100+ mg thinking it was a normal dose). Strong body load: nausea, vasoconstriction, muscle tension. Can cause difficult trips, anxiety, paranoia. Challenging headspace at higher doses. Tachycardia, hypertension. Long duration can be exhausting. Can trigger HPPD. Often sold as 2C-B or other substances—verify with testing. Cross-tolerance with other psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-I: Pharmacology and toxicology of a phenethylamine designer drug
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of 2C-I overdose cases and pharmacology

notes: More intense than 2C-B. Duration 6-10 hours. Green Marquis reaction (similar to 2C-B). DOSE-SENSITIVE—deaths from taking 100+ mg. Typical dose only 14-25mg. Stronger body load than 2C-B. Often sold as 2C-B—verify with testing. More visual and intense. Not recommended for beginners—start with 2C-B.

description.overview: 2C-C (2,5-dimethoxy-4-chlorophenethylamine) is a psychedelic phenethylamine from the 2C-x family. Less potent and less intense than 2C-B or 2C-I. Duration 4-8 hours. Produces mild visuals, gentle headspace, and subtle euphoria. Described as 'softer' and more introspective than other 2C compounds. Less common but valued by some for gentler experience.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Less popular than 2C-B/2C-I but available on research chemical markets 2000s-2010s. Known for being mild and manageable. Scheduled alongside other 2C compounds in various countries. Less commonly encountered than 2C-B or 2C-I. Considered niche compound for experienced psychonauts seeking subtle effects.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Mild visual effects, gentle euphoria, introspection, enhanced creativity, tactile sensations. Typical dose 20-50mg (higher than 2C-B due to lower potency). Duration 4-8 hours. Used for gentle psychedelic experiences, creative work, introspection. Described as more 'stoning' and less visual than other 2Cs. Some find it underwhelming; others appreciate subtlety.
description.dangers: Similar to other 2C compounds but milder: Nausea, body load, vasoconstriction possible but less severe. Can still cause challenging experiences at high doses. Less studied than 2C-B/2C-I—long-term effects unknown. Cross-tolerance with other psychedelics. Dose-response curve less understood. Often sold as other 2C compounds—verify identity. Can trigger HPPD like other psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-C and related chlorinated phenethylamines
scientific_papers.summary: Original documentation of 2C-C synthesis and effects

notes: Milder, less potent than 2C-B/2C-I. Duration 4-8 hours. Higher doses needed (20-50mg). Green Marquis (similar to other 2Cs). Described as gentler, more introspective. Less visual than 2C-B. Good for beginners seeking mild psychedelic experience. Cannot distinguish from 2C-B/2C-I by reagent alone—similar reactions.

description.overview: 2C-D (2,5-dimethoxy-4-methylphenethylamine, LE-25) is a psychedelic phenethylamine from the 2C-x family. Known for clear-headed, analytical headspace with minimal visuals. Duration 4-6 hours. Described as most 'clear' and least visual 2C compound. Popular for introspection, therapy, and cognitive enhancement at low doses. Less recreational, more therapeutic.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Called LE-25 in some literature. Less popular recreationally than 2C-B but valued for unique profile. Available on research chemical markets but never widely distributed. Scheduled with other 2C compounds. Known in psychedelic therapy/research circles for clear headspace. Rare nowadays.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational/therapeutic: Clear-headed introspection, analytical thinking, minimal visuals, emotional processing, creativity enhancement. Typical dose 20-60mg. Duration 4-6 hours. Used for therapy-like introspection, problem-solving, emotional work. Microdosed by some for cognitive enhancement. Less 'fun' than 2C-B—more serious/analytical. Described as 'psychedelic without losing your mind.'
description.dangers: Minimal visual/perceptual effects can be disappointing for those seeking psychedelic experience. Still can cause challenging psychological experiences—introspection can be uncomfortable. Nausea, body load less severe than other 2Cs. Long-term effects unknown. Less studied than 2C-B. Can trigger anxiety at higher doses. Cross-tolerance with psychedelics. Often mis-sold as other 2C compounds.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-D: The 'psychedelic tofu' - subjective effects analysis
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of 2C-D's unique clear-headed effects profile

notes: LE-25. Most clear-headed 2C—minimal visuals. Duration 4-6 hours. Higher doses (20-60mg). Described as 'psychedelic without losing your mind.' Good for therapy, introspection, analytical thinking. Less recreational, more therapeutic. Called 'psychedelic tofu' by Shulgin (takes on flavor of setting). Cannot distinguish from other 2Cs by reagent.

description.overview: 2C-T-2 (2,5-dimethoxy-4-ethylthiophenethylamine) is a psychedelic phenethylamine from the 2C-T-x family. More intense and longer-lasting than 2C-B. Duration 6-10 hours. Known for strong visuals, complex headspace, and significant body load. Popular in early 2000s rave scene. Several deaths led to emergency scheduling. More challenging than 2C-B.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Became popular in early 2000s, especially 2000-2003. Deaths from overdose (insufflation particularly dangerous) led to DEA emergency scheduling 2003. Less common after scheduling. Known as 'T-2' or 'Rosy' in early 2000s rave scene. Now rare but occasionally encountered.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Strong visual hallucinations, complex thoughts, euphoria, music enhancement. Typical dose 12-25mg oral (MUCH LESS if insufflated—2-5mg). Duration 6-10 hours. Used at raves, festivals. Described as more intense and challenging than 2C-B. Insufflation popular but dangerous—burns mucosa, higher OD risk. Now rare.
description.dangers: FATAL OVERDOSES: Multiple deaths, especially from insufflation. NEVER insufflate—much more dangerous than oral. Burns nasal passages severely. Strong body load: nausea, muscle tension, vasoconstriction. Challenging headspace can cause difficult trips. Long duration (8-10 hours) exhausting. Tachycardia, hypertension. Can trigger HPPD. Dose-sensitive. Cross-tolerance with psychedelics. Emergency scheduled due to deaths.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-T-2: Analysis of fatal intoxications
scientific_papers.summary: Study of 2C-T-2 overdose deaths leading to emergency scheduling

notes: T-2, Rosy. DANGER: Multiple fatal overdoses. NEVER insufflate—extremely dangerous, burns severely. Oral only, 12-25mg. More intense than 2C-B, longer duration (6-10 hours). Strong body load. Grey Marquis (different from 2C-B's green). Emergency scheduled 2003 after deaths. Rare nowadays. Very challenging—not recommended.

description.overview: 2C-P (2,5-dimethoxy-4-propylphenethylamine) is a psychedelic phenethylamine with EXTREMELY long duration (10-20 hours). Very potent (3-10mg) and intense. Produces strong visuals and challenging headspace. Known for being one of longest-lasting 2C compounds. Uncommon due to difficulty of long experience. More intense than 2C-B.
description.origins: Synthesized by Alexander Shulgin, documented in PiHKAL 1991. Remained very obscure until 2000s RC boom. Never widely popular due to extreme duration. Available on RC markets sporadically. Scheduled with other 2C compounds in various countries. Known in psychonaut communities but rarely sought due to 16+ hour commitment. Considered challenging even by experienced users.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Intense visual hallucinations, deep introspection, complex thoughts, time dilation. Typical dose 3-10mg (very potent). Duration 10-20 hours (exhausting). Used for extremely deep psychedelic experiences, spiritual work. Requires clear 24+ hours. Described as powerful and difficult. Not recreational—too intense and long. Only for very experienced psychonauts.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY LONG DURATION: 16-20 hours of intense effects mentally and physically exhausting. Very potent—easy to overdose. Challenging headspace can cause difficult trips lasting entire day. Strong body load. Vasoconstriction, muscle tension for many hours. Insomnia persists after trip. Bad trips are marathon experiences. Can trigger HPPD, PTSD from difficult experiences. Not recommended—overwhelming for most. Cross-tolerance with psychedelics.

scientific_papers.title: 2C-P: An ultra-long-duration phenethylamine psychedelic
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of 2C-P's extreme duration and potency

notes: EXTREME DURATION: 10-20 hours! Very potent (3-10mg). One of longest-lasting psychedelics. Exhausting and overwhelming. Green Marquis like other 2Cs. Only for very experienced users seeking marathon psychedelic experience. Requires 24+ hour clear schedule. Not recreational—too intense. Many prefer shorter compounds. Cannot distinguish from 2C-B by reagent.

description.overview: LSA (lysergic acid amide, ergine) is a naturally-occurring lysergamide found in seeds of morning glory (Ipomoea tricolor) and Hawaiian baby woodrose (Argyreia nervosa). Produces psychedelic effects similar to but milder than LSD. Duration 6-10 hours. Often causes significant nausea and physical discomfort. Historically used in Aztec religious ceremonies. Popular as legal LSD alternative but often unpleasant.
description.origins: Natural compound in several plant species, especially morning glory and Hawaiian baby woodrose seeds. Used ceremonially by Aztecs (ololiuqui). Psychoactive properties documented by Albert Hofmann (LSD discoverer) in 1950s. Became popular in 1960s counterculture as legal psychedelic. Seeds sold in garden stores but often treated with toxic fungicides/pesticides. Still used as legal LSD substitute despite difficult side effects.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational/spiritual: Mild psychedelic visuals, introspection, emotional experiences, altered thinking. Typical dose: 5-10 Hawaiian baby woodrose seeds or 200-400 morning glory seeds (strains vary). Duration 6-10 hours. Used for spiritual exploration, introspection. Effects described as more 'earthy' and sedating than LSD. Significant nausea very common—extraction methods attempt to reduce this but still present.
description.dangers: SEVERE NAUSEA AND VOMITING very common (vasoconstriction from ergot alkaloids). Abdominal cramping, diarrhea. Vasoconstriction can cause numbness, cold extremities. Garden store seeds often treated with toxic fungicides or pesticides—can cause serious poisoning. Some preparations involve extraction with harmful solvents. Challenging psychological experiences possible. Can trigger HPPD. Fatigue, sedation common during experience. Long duration can be exhausting. Pregnancy risk: ergot alkaloids can cause uterine contractions.

scientific_papers.title: Lysergic acid amide: Pharmacology and natural occurrence
scientific_papers.summary: Albert Hofmann's documentation of LSA discovery in morning glory seeds

notes: Natural LSD relative in morning glory and Hawaiian baby woodrose seeds. Ehrlich purple (lysergamide). SEVERE nausea very common—often unpleasant experience. Garden seeds often treated with TOXIC pesticides/fungicides. Only use untreated seeds sold specifically for consumption. Weaker and more sedating than LSD. Long duration (6-10 hrs). Not recommended due to side effects.

description.overview: PRO-LAD (6-propyl-6-nor-lysergic acid diethylamide) is a semi-synthetic lysergamide analogue of LSD. Similar effects to LSD but described as more visual, less mentally confusing. Duration 6-10 hours. Developed by David Nichols. Less common than other LSD analogues but valued by psychonauts for clearer headspace. Research chemical with limited human data.
description.origins: Synthesized by David Nichols and team at Purdue University, documented in research papers 1980s-1990s. Remained obscure until 2010s research chemical markets. Less popular than 1P-LSD or ALD-52 but sought by experienced psychonauts. Legal status varies—unscheduled in many countries but banned under analogue acts in some. Available sporadically on RC markets. Less studied than LSD.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Visual hallucinations, enhanced colors, introspection, less 'headspace' than LSD. Typical dose 100-200µg. Duration 6-10 hours. Used for psychedelic experiences with clearer thinking than LSD. Some users prefer it for functional tripping. Less anxiety-inducing than LSD for some. Good for nature, music, art appreciation.
description.dangers: Similar risks to LSD: Anxiety, paranoia, bad trips, confusion. Can trigger latent mental illness. Not suitable for those with psychotic disorder history. HPPD possible. Impaired judgment—dangerous behavior. Cross-tolerance with LSD and other psychedelics. Limited human safety data—less studied than LSD. Sold on blotter like LSD but could be mis-sold as LSD or contain other substances. Always test.

scientific_papers.title: Structure-activity relationships of lysergamides: PRO-LAD analysis
scientific_papers.summary: Original documentation of PRO-LAD synthesis and pharmacology

notes: LSD analogue. Described as more visual, clearer headspace than LSD. Ehrlich purple (lysergamide) but CANNOT distinguish from LSD, 1P-LSD, or other lysergamides. Duration 6-10 hours. Typical dose 100-200µg. Less studied than LSD. Cross-tolerance with all psychedelics. Test to verify—could be LSD or other lysergamide.

description.overview: LSM-775 (lysergic acid 2,4-dimethylazetidide) is a semi-synthetic lysergamide related to LSD. Shorter duration than LSD (4-6 hours). Described as similar to LSD but less intense and shorter. Very rare research chemical with minimal human use data. Developed by David Nichols. Occasionally appears on RC markets but uncommon.
description.origins: Synthesized by David Nichols' research team, documented in academic papers 1990s. Designed as shorter-duration LSD alternative for potential therapeutic use. Never approved for medical use. Remained completely obscure until appearing sporadically on RC markets 2015+. Very rare even among research chemicals. Little anecdotal data. Legal status unclear in most places—likely covered under analogue acts.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Similar to LSD but shorter (4-6 hours), less intense. Typical dose 150-300µg (less potent than LSD). Used by psychonauts seeking shorter psychedelic experience. Very few user reports. Effects described as LSD-like: visuals, introspection, altered perception. Shorter duration appeals to some but effects may differ from LSD in unknown ways.
description.dangers: VERY LIMITED HUMAN DATA: Safety profile unknown beyond animal studies and rare user reports. Similar risks expected as other lysergamides: bad trips, anxiety, triggering mental illness, HPPD. Impaired judgment. Unknown long-term effects. Cross-tolerance with psychedelics. Often sold as other lysergamides—test to verify. Extremely rare—if you have it, be extra cautious.

scientific_papers.title: Lysergamides with varying N1 substituents: LSM-775 characterization
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of LSM-775 synthesis and preliminary pharmacology

notes: Very rare LSD analogue. Shorter duration (4-6 hrs) and less potent than LSD. Ehrlich purple but cannot distinguish from other lysergamides. VERY LIMITED human data—safety unknown. If encountered, extreme caution. Likely mis-sold as LSD or other lysergamide. Test to verify. Cross-tolerance with psychedelics.

description.overview: Ibogaine is a powerful psychedelic alkaloid from the iboga plant (Tabernanthe iboga) native to West Africa. Known for extremely long duration (24-48 hours), intense introspective experiences, and unique ability to interrupt addiction. Used in addiction treatment clinics (opioid, alcohol, stimulant). Very dangerous—can cause fatal cardiac arrhythmias. Illegal in US, legal/tolerated in some countries for addiction treatment.
description.origins: Traditional use by Bwiti religion in Gabon and Cameroon for spiritual ceremonies, initiation rites. Discovered by Western medicine in 1960s for addiction treatment properties. Howard Lotsof documented anti-addictive effects 1962. Clinics opened in Mexico, Canada, Netherlands, New Zealand for ibogaine-assisted addiction treatment. Schedule I in US (illegal), but legal in some countries. Root bark vs. extracted ibogaine have different safety profiles.
description.uses: Traditional: Spiritual ceremonies, vision quests, initiation rites (Bwiti religion). Medical (outside US): Opioid addiction treatment (interrupts physical dependence and cravings), alcohol addiction, stimulant addiction. Single dose can eliminate withdrawal and reduce cravings for months. Typical dose: 15-25mg/kg (very high dose). Duration: 24-48 hours of intense effects, aftereffects days-weeks. Used in supervised clinical settings for addiction treatment. NOT recreational—extremely difficult experience.
description.dangers: POTENTIALLY FATAL: Cardiac arrhythmias (QT prolongation), sudden cardiac death documented. Deaths have occurred even in clinical settings with medical monitoring. Contraindicated for people with heart conditions, recent substance use (especially stimulants), certain medications. Requires extensive medical screening (ECG, blood work). Extremely physically and psychologically intense—12-48 hour ordeal. Severe ataxia (loss of coordination), inability to walk for hours. Nausea, vomiting. Can cause seizures. Dangerous drug interactions (especially SSRIs, stimulants, opioids). ONLY safe in medical setting with cardiac monitoring. DIY ibogaine use has caused many deaths. Not for recreational use.

scientific_papers.title: Ibogaine in the treatment of substance dependence: Clinical review
scientific_papers.summary: Review of ibogaine's efficacy and safety for addiction treatment

scientific_papers.title: Ibogaine-related fatalities: Cardiac risk assessment
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of ibogaine deaths and cardiac risks

notes: EXTREME DANGER: Can cause fatal cardiac arrhythmias. Used for addiction treatment in clinics outside US. Duration 24-48 hours. Ehrlich purple (tryptamine). ONLY safe in medical setting with cardiac monitoring, ECG, blood work. Many deaths from unsupervised use. NOT recreational. Contraindicated with heart conditions, many medications, recent drug use. Schedule I in US (illegal). Legal in some countries for medical use only.

description.overview: Blue lotus (Nymphaea caerulea) is a water lily native to Egypt and other parts of Africa. Contains mild psychoactive alkaloids (aporphine, nuciferine). Produces subtle euphoria, mild sedation, and aphrodisiac effects. Historically used in ancient Egypt (depicted in art, possibly in ceremonies). Legal in most countries. Sold as dried flowers for tea or smoking. Effects are VERY mild compared to classical psychedelics.
description.origins: Sacred plant in ancient Egypt—depicted extensively in tomb paintings and temple art. Possibly used in religious ceremonies, as aphrodisiac, in wine/beer. Mentioned in ancient texts. Contains aporphine (mild dopamine agonist) and nuciferine (various effects). Modern rediscovery in ethnobotanical community. Legal and sold in smoke shops, online. Widely available but effects overhyped in marketing.
description.uses: Historical: Ancient Egyptian ceremonies, aphrodisiac, added to wine. Modern: Mild euphoria, relaxation, aphrodisiac effects (mild), lucid dreaming (claimed but unproven), meditation aid. Consumed as: tea (most common—5-10g flowers), smoking (harsh, less effective), tincture, wine infusion. Duration 1-3 hours. Effects very subtle—not comparable to cannabis or psychedelics. Often disappointing for those expecting strong effects. Better for relaxation than recreation.
description.dangers: Very safe—minimal risks. Possible: nausea (high doses or sensitive individuals), drowsiness, dizziness. No documented serious adverse effects. Not addictive. Legal in most jurisdictions. Quality varies—adulteration possible. Some products mix with other herbs. Possible drug interactions unknown but likely minimal. May cause mild drop in blood pressure. Not recommended during pregnancy (insufficient data). Main danger: inflated expectations leading to disappointment or trying other substances.

scientific_papers.title: Blue lotus (Nymphaea caerulea): Phytochemistry and pharmacology
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of blue lotus alkaloids and historical use

testing.alt: no color change (alkaloids present but don't react strongly)

notes: Sacred Egyptian water lily. VERY MILD effects: subtle euphoria, relaxation. Not comparable to cannabis or psychedelics. Legal in most places. Usually consumed as tea (5-10g flowers). Duration 1-3 hours. Very safe, minimal risks. Often disappointing for those expecting strong effects. Historical/cultural interest more than recreational value. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Kanna (Sceletium tortuosum) is a succulent plant from South Africa. Contains alkaloids that act as serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SRIs). Produces mood elevation, anxiety reduction, mild euphoria, and empathogenic effects. Traditionally used by San and Khoikhoi peoples. Legal in most countries. Growing popularity as legal mood enhancer and MDMA/kratom alternative. Effects are subtle but noticeable.
description.origins: Traditional use by indigenous San and Khoikhoi peoples of South Africa for thousands of years. Chewed or smoked for mood elevation, reducing anxiety, hunger suppression during long hunts. Rediscovered by ethnobotanical community 1990s-2000s. Now cultivated and sold as extract, powder, or whole plant. Legal in most countries. Marketed as nootropic, mood enhancer, legal high. Standardized extracts more potent than traditional plant material.
description.uses: Traditional: Mood enhancement, anxiety reduction, social bonding, hunger suppression. Modern: Anxiety relief, mood boost, mild euphoria, empathogenic effects (described as 'gentle roll'), stress reduction, meditation aid. Typical dose: 50-150mg extract (standardized to mesembrine content) or 200-1000mg plant powder. Duration 1-3 hours. ROAs: oral (most common), sublingual, insufflation (harsh), smoking (traditional but wasteful). Used as alternative to SSRIs, MDMA, or anxiolytics.
description.dangers: Generally safe but caution needed: SEROTONIN INTERACTIONS—do NOT combine with SSRIs, MAOIs, MDMA, or other serotonergics (serotonin syndrome risk). Some users report headaches, nausea, anxiety (paradoxical). Can cause insomnia at higher doses. Insufflation painful/damaging. Quality varies widely between vendors—standardization important. Tolerance develops with frequent use. Some countries beginning to regulate. Insufficient data on long-term daily use. Pregnancy/breastfeeding: avoid (no safety data).

scientific_papers.title: Sceletium tortuosum (Kanna): Chemistry and pharmacology
scientific_papers.summary: Review of kanna's alkaloids and effects as SRI

notes: South African plant with SRI alkaloids. Mild euphoria, anxiety reduction, empathogenic effects. NEVER combine with SSRIs, MAOIs, MDMA—serotonin syndrome risk. Legal in most places. Dose: 50-150mg extract. Duration 1-3 hours. Safer alternative to pharmaceuticals for some. Quality varies—buy standardized extracts. Tolerance with frequent use. Not intense like MDMA but noticeable mood boost.

description.overview: Syrian rue (Peganum harmala) is a plant containing powerful MAOI alkaloids (harmine, harmaline). Traditionally used in Middle Eastern and Central Asian cultures. Main modern use: potentiating DMT for ayahuasca-like experiences ('pharmahuasca' or 'anahuasca'). DANGEROUS if combined with many substances, foods, or medications. Causes severe nausea/vomiting. Legal in most places but extremely risky without proper knowledge.
description.origins: Traditional use in Middle East, North Africa, Central Asia for medicinal and spiritual purposes. Used as dye, incense, folk medicine (Turkey, Iran, Pakistan). Contains β-carboline alkaloids (harmine, harmaline, harmalol) that inhibit MAO enzyme. Discovered by psychedelic community as DMT potentiator (creates oral activity). Often called 'Syrian rue' though native to broader region. Seeds widely available online/botanicals shops.
description.uses: Traditional: Folk medicine, dye, incense, spiritual rituals. Modern: Potentiating oral DMT (pharmahuasca/anahuasca), MAOI effects, visionary experiences. Typical dose: 2-4g seeds (ground). Effects alone: mild visuals, body load, nausea, sedation. With DMT: enables oral DMT activity, extends duration to 4-6 hours. Used for DMT ceremonies as ayahuasca alternative. Some use for MAOI antidepressant effects (dangerous without medical supervision).
description.dangers: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS WITH MANY SUBSTANCES: MAOIs interact with tyramine-rich foods (cheese, aged meats, fermented foods—can cause hypertensive crisis), SSRIs/antidepressants (serotonin syndrome—can be FATAL), stimulants (severe hypertension), opioids, alcohol, and many medications. Requires strict diet 24hrs before/after. Severe nausea and vomiting very common. Can cause serotonin syndrome with wrong combinations (potentially fatal). Hypertensive crisis possible. Pregnant/nursing: dangerous (emmenagogue effects). Legal but risky without extensive research. Many hospitalizations/deaths from improper use.

scientific_papers.title: Peganum harmala and its alkaloids: Pharmacology and toxicology
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of Syrian rue MAOI alkaloids and dangers

notes: EXTREME DANGER: Powerful MAOI. NEVER combine with: SSRIs, stimulants, tyramine foods, many medications—can be FATAL. Used to potentiate oral DMT (pharmahuasca). Causes severe nausea/vomiting. Requires strict dietary restrictions 24hrs before/after. Can cause hypertensive crisis, serotonin syndrome. Only for extremely experienced and informed users. Legal but very risky. NOT for beginners.

description.overview: Toad venom refers to secretions from the Colorado River toad (Incilius alvarius, formerly Bufo alvarius) which contain high concentrations of 5-MeO-DMT. When dried and smoked, produces extremely intense, short-lasting mystical experiences (15-45 minutes). Considered one of most powerful psychedelics. Popularized by figures like Mike Tyson. Controversial due to toad welfare concerns. Synthetic 5-MeO-DMT is identical and doesn't harm toads.
description.origins: Indigenous use possibly dates back centuries in Sonoran Desert region (disputed—may be modern practice). Toad venom contains 5-MeO-DMT and bufotenin. Modern popularity began 1980s-1990s. Albert Most published pamphlet on toad venom smoking 1984. Gained mainstream attention 2010s-2020s through celebrity endorsements. Toad populations threatened by overharvesting. Many advocate for synthetic 5-MeO-DMT instead (chemically identical, no toad harm).
description.uses: Recreational/spiritual: Extremely intense mystical experiences, ego dissolution, sense of unity/oneness, encounters with ineffable. Duration: 15-45 minutes of peak intensity, afterglow hours. Described as most powerful psychedelic by many users. Used for spiritual breakthroughs, trauma processing, end-of-life anxiety (clinical research). Synthetic 5-MeO-DMT preferred by many for ethical/consistency reasons.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY INTENSE: Can cause overwhelming experiences, terror, psychological distress. Not suitable for first psychedelic experience. Physical effects: tachycardia, increased blood pressure, difficulty breathing (feels like), muscle rigidity, loss of motor control during peak. Psychological risks: triggering latent mental illness, PTSD from difficult experiences, depersonalization/derealization. Contraindicated with heart conditions, mental health issues. NEVER use alone—sitter essential. Toad harvesting threatens species. Bufotenin in venom can cause nausea (synthetic 5-MeO-DMT doesn't have this).

scientific_papers.title: 5-MeO-DMT: Clinical pharmacology and potential therapeutic applications
scientific_papers.summary: Review of 5-MeO-DMT's effects and therapeutic potential

notes: Bufo alvarius toad venom containing 5-MeO-DMT. EXTREMELY INTENSE psychedelic. Duration 15-45 minutes but feels eternal. Ehrlich purple (tryptamine). ALWAYS have sitter present—total loss of motor control. Not for beginners. Toad populations threatened—use synthetic 5-MeO-DMT instead (identical, no animal harm). Can trigger serious psychological distress. Contraindicated with heart/mental health conditions.

description.overview: Ayahuasca is a traditional Amazonian plant brew combining DMT-containing plants (usually Psychotria viridis) with MAOI-containing plants (Banisteriopsis caapi vine). MAOIs make DMT orally active. Produces 4-6 hour visionary experiences. Used ceremonially by indigenous peoples for millennia. Increasingly popular in Western ayahuasca tourism and neo-shamanic ceremonies. Potentially therapeutic but carries significant risks.
description.origins: Traditional use by indigenous Amazonian peoples (Peru, Brazil, Ecuador, Colombia) for thousands of years. Used by shamans for healing, divination, spiritual work. Banisteriopsis caapi vine (MAOI) + Psychotria viridis leaves (DMT) traditional combination. Discovered by Western anthropologists mid-1900s. Popularized by Terence McKenna, Dennis McKenna, others. Now commercialized in ayahuasca tourism (controversial—exploitation concerns). Legal status varies: traditional use protected in some areas, prohibited in others. Churches like UDV and Santo Daime have religious exemptions in some countries.
description.uses: Traditional: Shamanic healing, spiritual guidance, divination, community ceremonies. Modern: Spiritual exploration, trauma healing, addiction treatment (some clinical research), personal growth. Duration 4-6 hours. Effects: intense visuals, emotional processing, purging (vomiting common—seen as cleansing), insights, mystical experiences. Often described as profoundly meaningful but difficult. Preparation (dieta) typically required in traditional contexts—dietary restrictions, abstinence, intention-setting.
description.dangers: MAOI INTERACTIONS: Ayahuasca contains MAOIs from B. caapi. DANGEROUS with: SSRIs/antidepressants (serotonin syndrome—potentially FATAL), stimulants (hypertensive crisis), tyramine-rich foods, many medications. Requires dietary restrictions 24hrs+ before/after. Intense purging (vomiting, diarrhea) very common. Psychologically challenging—can surface trauma, cause distressing experiences. Risk of triggering mental illness. Safety varies hugely by setting: traditional shamans vs. untrained facilitators vs. tourist traps. Reports of sexual abuse in ceremonies. Quality/potency varies wildly. Can cause hypertensive crisis, serotonin syndrome with wrong combinations. Contraindicated in pregnancy, heart conditions, mental health issues.

scientific_papers.title: Ayahuasca: Pharmacology, neuroscience, and therapeutic potential
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of ayahuasca's chemistry and therapeutic research

scientific_papers.title: Ayahuasca and public health: Risks and therapeutic potential
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of ayahuasca safety and medical applications

notes: Amazonian DMT + MAOI brew. Duration 4-6 hours. Ehrlich purple (DMT). MAOI DANGERS: NEVER combine with SSRIs, stimulants, tyramine foods—can be FATAL. Requires dietary restrictions 24hrs before/after. Intense purging (vomiting) very common. Psychologically intense. Quality/safety varies hugely by setting—research facilitators carefully. Traditional indigenous use vs. tourist ceremonies very different. Legal status varies. Not for beginners.

description.overview: Yopo (Anadenanthera peregrina) is a tree whose seeds contain DMT, 5-MeO-DMT, and bufotenin. Indigenous peoples of Caribbean and South America use powdered roasted seeds as insufflated snuff in traditional ceremonies. Produces intense but short-lived visionary experiences (30-90 minutes). Also called cohoba. Similar to cebil/vilca (Anadenanthera colubrina). Extremely painful to insufflate. Vomiting common. Traditional preparation methods differ from modern use.
description.origins: Traditional use by Taíno and other indigenous peoples of Caribbean, Orinoco basin (Venezuela, Colombia) documented since pre-Columbian times. Seeds roasted, ground with lime/ash, insufflated as snuff. Used ceremonially by shamans for divination, healing, communication with spirits. Documented by early European explorers 1496+ (Columbus expedition). Also called cohoba in historical texts. Seeds contain 5-MeO-DMT, bufotenin, DMT (ratios vary). Modern users often unprepared for intensity and pain of traditional ROA.
description.uses: Traditional: Shamanic ceremonies, healing, divination, vision quests. Seeds roasted, ground with calcium compound (lime, ash), insufflated. Modern: Psychonauts seeking natural psychedelic experiences. Duration 30-90 minutes. Effects: rapid onset intense visuals, altered perception, mystical experiences. EXTREMELY painful to insufflate—burning sensation. Nausea, vomiting common. Some modern users attempt other ROAs (oral with MAOI, smoking) with varying success.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY PAINFUL insufflation—severe nasal burning, damage to mucous membranes. Nausea, vomiting very common (bufotenin causes this). Rapid, intense onset can be overwhelming. Vasoconstriction. Tachycardia. Bufotenin may cause more physical discomfort than DMT/5-MeO-DMT alone. Psychological risks: bad trips, anxiety, panic, triggering mental illness. Traditional preparation methods poorly documented—risk of doing it wrong. Seed potency varies. Legal status unclear in many jurisdictions (seeds vs. extracted compounds). Not recommended due to severe discomfort. Synthetic alternatives (5-MeO-DMT, DMT) easier and more comfortable.

scientific_papers.title: Anadenanthera: Visionary and healing powers of South American snuff
scientific_papers.summary: Ethnobotanical and chemical analysis of Anadenanthera snuffs

notes: Anadenanthera seeds containing DMT, 5-MeO-DMT, bufotenin. Traditional snuff (cohoba). EXTREMELY PAINFUL to insufflate—severe burning, nasal damage. Nausea/vomiting very common. Duration 30-90 minutes. Ehrlich purple (tryptamines). Traditional ceremonial use vs. modern recreational very different. Not recommended—synthetic alternatives much more comfortable. Seed potency varies. Cultural appropriation concerns with non-traditional use.

description.overview: Changa is a smokable blend of DMT-infused herbs combined with MAOI-containing plants (typically Banisteriopsis caapi or Syrian rue). Created as ayahuasca-like experience through smoking rather than drinking. MAOIs extend and intensify DMT experience from 5-15 minutes to 10-20+ minutes. More gradual onset than pure DMT. Popular alternative to ayahuasca or freebase DMT. Carries MAOI risks but less severe than oral MAOIs.
description.origins: Invented by Australian Julian Palmer in early 2000s. Inspired by traditional ayahuasca but designed for smoking. Name possibly from I Ching or Australian slang. Gained popularity in psychedelic communities 2000s-2010s. Recipe varies—different herbs (mullein, passionflower, caapi leaves, blue lotus) infused with DMT and MAOIs. Less standardized than ayahuasca. Legal status unclear—DMT illegal but herbs often legal.
description.uses: Recreational/spiritual: Extended DMT experience with gentler onset/offset than pure DMT. Duration 10-20 minutes (vs 5-10 for pure DMT). Less 'rocket ship' intensity—more gradual and manageable. Visuals, mystical experiences, introspection. Used for spiritual work, healing, exploration. Smoking is primary ROA. Some users prefer changa over pure DMT for more grounded experience.
description.dangers: Contains MAOIs—dietary restrictions recommended (less critical than oral MAOIs but still advised). AVOID with: SSRIs, stimulants, other drugs. Can cause serotonin syndrome or hypertensive crisis (less likely than oral MAOIs but possible). Standard psychedelic risks: bad trips, anxiety, triggering mental illness. DMT component can cause tachycardia, hypertension. Quality/potency varies wildly—homemade blends inconsistent. Legal risks—DMT is Schedule I. MAOIs may cause nausea. Requires proper smoking technique.

scientific_papers.title: DMT and MAOI combinations: Pharmacology and experiences
scientific_papers.summary: Study of DMT with MAOIs and extended duration effects

notes: DMT + MAOI smokable blend. Duration 10-20 minutes (extended vs pure DMT). Ehrlich purple (DMT). MAOI risks: avoid SSRIs, stimulants, dietary restrictions advised. Gentler than pure DMT. Quality varies hugely. DMT is Schedule I—legal risks. More manageable than 'breakthrough' DMT for some users.

description.overview: Secobarbital (Seconal, 'reds') is a short-acting barbiturate once widely prescribed for insomnia. Highly addictive and dangerous in overdose.
