Largely replaced by benzodiazepines due to safety concerns. Still prescribed rarely for pre-surgical sedation or severe insomnia. Schedule II controlled substance. Recreational abuse continues. Very narrow safety margin—easy to overdose.
description.origins: Synthesized 1928, introduced medically 1934. Widely prescribed 1940s-1970s for insomnia, anxiety, seizures. Called 'reds' or 'red devils' due to red capsules. Popular recreational drug 1960s-1970s. Many overdose deaths led to restrictions. Largely phased out 1980s-1990s in favor of benzos. Still available for medical aid in dying (physician-assisted suicide) in some jurisdictions. Now rare but still encountered.
description.uses: Medical: Severe insomnia (rare), pre-surgical sedation, medical aid in dying. Historical: anxiety, seizure prevention. Recreational: Sedation, euphoria, disinhibition, alcohol-like intoxication. Typical dose 100-200mg (therapeutic). Duration 3-4 hours. Effects similar to alcohol or benzos but more dangerous. Often combined with stimulants ('goof balls'—very dangerous).
description.dangers: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS: Very narrow therapeutic window. Easy to overdose. Respiratory depression, coma, death. Combining with alcohol, opioids, benzos often FATAL. Highly addictive—physical dependence develops quickly. Withdrawal can cause seizures and death (like alcohol/benzos—requires medical supervision). Tolerance develops rapidly. Cognitive impairment, motor incoordination. Many accidental overdoses. Largely replaced by benzos for good reason—much less safe.

scientific_papers.title: Barbiturate toxicity and fatalities: Clinical review
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of barbiturate overdose deaths and dangers

notes: Seconal, 'reds'. Barbiturate sedative. EXTREMELY DANGEROUS: narrow safety window, easy overdose. Often FATAL with alcohol/opioids/benzos. Highly addictive. Withdrawal can be fatal—requires medical supervision. Schedule II. Largely replaced by benzos due to danger. No reagent reaction. If encountered, extreme caution.

description.overview: Pentobarbital (Nembutal) is a short-acting barbiturate. Historically used for insomnia, seizures, anesthesia. Now primarily used in veterinary medicine and for medical aid in dying (euthanasia). Highly dangerous in overdose. Schedule II controlled substance. Rarely prescribed for humans. Very difficult to obtain. Sometimes used in executions (lethal injection).
description.origins: Synthesized 1928. Marketed as Nembutal. Widely used 1940s-1970s for insomnia, anxiety, seizure control, anesthesia induction. Associated with many celebrity overdose deaths. Largely discontinued for human use 1980s-1990s. Still used in veterinary medicine. Used for physician-assisted suicide in jurisdictions where legal. Sought by right-to-die advocates.
description.uses: Medical (rare): Pre-surgical sedation, seizure emergencies, medically-assisted dying. Veterinary: Euthanasia. Historical: Insomnia, anxiety. Recreational (rare): Sedation, euphoria. Typical dose 100mg (medical). Duration 3-4 hours. Very difficult to obtain legitimately. Black market sources unreliable/dangerous.
description.dangers: FATAL OVERDOSE RISK: Very narrow therapeutic window. Respiratory depression, coma, death. Often lethal—used for euthanasia for this reason. Combining with other depressants (alcohol, opioids, benzos) almost always FATAL. Highly addictive. Withdrawal seizures can be fatal. Cognitive impairment. No reversal agent exists (unlike opioids with naloxone). Extremely dangerous. Avoid.

scientific_papers.title: Pentobarbital in medical aid in dying: Pharmacology and protocols
scientific_papers.journal: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
scientific_papers.summary: Use of pentobarbital for physician-assisted death

notes: Nembutal. Barbiturate. FATAL OVERDOSE RISK—used for euthanasia. No reversal agent. Often FATAL with other depressants. Withdrawal can be fatal. Schedule II. Very rare in human medicine now. Primarily veterinary or right-to-die use. Extremely dangerous. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Carisoprodol (Soma) is a muscle relaxant that metabolizes into meprobamate (a barbiturate-like sedative). Prescribed for acute musculoskeletal pain. Significant abuse potential—produces euphoria, sedation. Often combined with opioids ('Soma coma'). Schedule IV controlled substance in US. Banned in some countries due to abuse. Physical dependence develops with regular use.
description.origins: Introduced 1959 as muscle relaxant. Marketed as Soma. Gained popularity for abuse 1990s-2000s, especially combined with opioids (hydrocodone + carisoprodol = 'Las Vegas cocktail'). Scheduled as controlled substance 2012 in US due to abuse. Banned in EU since 2008. Still widely prescribed in US despite abuse potential. Popular in polydrug abuse.
description.uses: Medical: Acute musculoskeletal pain, muscle spasms. Typical dose 250-350mg. Duration 4-6 hours. Recreational: Euphoria, sedation, relaxation. Often combined with opioids for enhanced effects ('Soma coma'). Metabolizes to meprobamate which causes main psychoactive effects.
description.dangers: Physical dependence and addiction with regular use. Withdrawal symptoms (anxiety, insomnia, tremors) after discontinuation. Overdose causes sedation, respiratory depression, seizures, coma. DANGEROUS combination with opioids, benzos, alcohol—respiratory depression can be FATAL. Cognitive impairment, motor incoordination. Driving impairment. Some users experience paradoxical stimulation. Pregnancy risk—crosses placenta. Banned in many countries due to safety concerns.

scientific_papers.title: Carisoprodol abuse potential and dependence
scientific_papers.summary: Review of Soma abuse and addiction potential

notes: Soma. Muscle relaxant that converts to meprobamate. Significant abuse potential. Often combined with opioids ('Soma coma')—DANGEROUS. Physical dependence develops. Schedule IV. Banned in EU. Overdose with other depressants can be FATAL. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Diphenhydramine (Benadryl, DPH) is an OTC antihistamine used for allergies and sleep aid. At high doses (700mg+), causes deliriant effects: realistic hallucinations, confusion, dysphoria. Extremely unpleasant 'trip'—most users describe as nightmare. Popular among teens due to OTC availability but universally regretted. Very dangerous at recreational doses. Not a 'fun' drug.
description.origins: Synthesized 1943. Widely available OTC since 1946. Medical uses: allergies, insomnia, nausea, cold symptoms. Recreational abuse began emerging 1990s-2000s, especially among teenagers seeking legal high. Internet trip reports mostly describe terrifying experiences. Despite this, abuse continues due to easy access. Often first deliriant experience for young users.
description.uses: Medical: Allergies (25-50mg), insomnia (50mg), motion sickness. Recreational (not recommended): Deliriant hallucinations (700mg+). Duration 6-8 hours of delirium. Effects: seeing spiders/insects, talking to people who aren't there, extreme confusion, inability to distinguish reality. Almost universally described as terrifying, not enjoyable. Used by teens due to OTC access.
description.dangers: At recreational doses: Extremely dysphoric, terrifying hallucinations. Realistic visions of spiders, insects, shadow people. Confusion, amnesia, inability to recognize hallucinations as unreal. Dangerous behavior (walking into traffic, jumping from windows). Severe tachycardia, hyperthermia, urinary retention, seizures, rhabdomyolysis. Can cause long-term cognitive impairment. Overdose can be FATAL. Dementia risk with chronic use (even therapeutic doses). Extremely unpleasant—not recreational. Teenagers: AVOID—can ruin your life.

scientific_papers.title: Diphenhydramine abuse and toxicity
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of DPH abuse, effects, and dangers

notes: Benadryl, DPH. Antihistamine. HIGH DOSES (700mg+) cause TERRIFYING delirium: spiders, shadow people, confusion. NOT FUN—universally described as nightmare. Popular with teens (OTC) but deeply regretted. Dangerous: seizures, hyperthermia, can be FATAL. Dementia risk. AVOID recreational use. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: NEP (N-Ethylpentedrone) is a synthetic cathinone stimulant. Similar to pentedrone and other cathinones. Produces stimulation, euphoria, increased energy. Shorter duration than amphetamines (2-4 hours). Research chemical with minimal safety data. Addictive - compulsive redosing common. Legal status varies—often sold as 'research chemical' or 'not for human consumption.'
description.origins: Developed as research chemical 2010s. Part of synthetic cathinone wave after mephedrone bans. Little known use before 2015. Sold online as legal alternative to banned cathinones. Minimal scientific research. Potency and effects vary batch-to-batch. Banned in many countries under blanket cathinone/analogue laws.
description.uses: Recreational: Stimulation, euphoria, increased energy and focus, sociability. Typical dose 30-100mg insufflated or oral. Duration 2-4 hours. Often redosed compulsively. Used as alternative to cocaine, meth, or other cathinones. Some use for productivity (not recommended—unsafe).
description.dangers: Highly addictive - compulsive redosing leads to binges. Cardiovascular strain: tachycardia, hypertension, chest pain. Hyperthermia, dehydration. Anxiety, paranoia, psychosis (especially with binging). Severe vasoconstriction. Neurotoxicity unknown but likely similar to other cathinones. Crash/comedown: depression, fatigue, anhedonia. Long-term effects completely unknown—no human safety studies. Quality varies—adulterants possible. Legal risks.

notes: N-Ethylpentedrone. Synthetic cathinone stimulant. Highly addictive—compulsive redosing. Duration 2-4 hours. Orange Marquis (cathinone). NO human safety data. Cardiovascular risks, paranoia, psychosis. Quality varies. Legal status unclear. Research chemical—extreme caution.

description.overview: Hexen (N-Ethylhexedrone) is a synthetic cathinone stimulant. More potent than NEP. Short duration (1-3 hours) leading to compulsive redosing. Produces stimulation, euphoria, focus. Research chemical with no safety data. Highly addictive. Infamous for terrible smell (described as cum/semen). Legal status varies—often sold as research chemical.
description.origins: Appeared on RC markets mid-2010s. Became popular briefly as legal stimulant alternative. Notorious for awful smell/taste. Many users report extreme compulsive redosing. Minimal scientific study. Banned in many jurisdictions under cathinone/analogue laws. Still available from RC vendors in some countries.
description.uses: Recreational: Strong stimulation, euphoria, focus, sociability. Typical dose 40-120mg insufflated/oral. Duration 1-3 hours (very short—encourages redosing). Used as cocaine/meth alternative. Some attempt productivity use (very risky). Insufflation causes intense burning.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE: Compulsive redosing nearly unavoidable for most users. Very short duration drives binges. Severe cardiovascular strain: tachycardia, chest pain, hypertension. Hyperthermia. Extreme vasoconstriction (cold extremities, potential tissue damage). Paranoia, anxiety, psychosis common. Terrible comedown: depression, exhaustion, anhedonia. Awful smell/taste (described as semen—lingers on skin/breath). NO safety data. Neurotoxicity likely. Legal risks.

notes: N-Ethylhexedrone. Cathinone. EXTREMELY addictive—compulsive redosing. Duration 1-3 hours (very short). Orange Marquis. Infamous for terrible smell (cum/semen). Severe cardiovascular risks, paranoia. NO safety data. Avoid—many users regret trying. Research chemical.

description.overview: 3-FEA (3-Fluoroethamphetamine) is a fluorinated amphetamine with empathogenic and stimulant effects. Described as milder than MDMA but similar profile. Duration 4-6 hours. Research chemical with limited human data. Less neurotoxic than MDMA (possibly) but still carries risks. Legal status varies—often sold as research chemical.
description.origins: Synthesized as research chemical 2010s. Gained popularity as MDMA alternative when cathinones started getting banned. Part of fluorinated amphetamine series (2-FA, 3-FA, 4-FA, etc.). Each has different effects profile. 3-FEA specifically known for empathogenic effects. Minimal scientific research. Some countries ban all fluorinated amphetamines.
description.uses: Recreational: Empathy, emotional openness, mild euphoria, stimulation, music enhancement. Typical dose 100-200mg. Duration 4-6 hours. Used as MDMA substitute—less intense but similar vibe. Some use for social situations, raves, concerts. Described as gentler, less overwhelming than MDMA.
description.dangers: Neurotoxicity unknown—possibly less than MDMA but unproven. Serotonin depletion possible. Cardiovascular strain: tachycardia, hypertension. Hyperthermia risk (like MDMA). Jaw clenching, nystagmus. Combining with SSRIs/MAOIs risky (serotonin syndrome). Comedown/aftereffects: depression, fatigue. NO long-term safety data. Fluorinated amphetamines understudied. Quality/purity varies. Legal risks.

notes: 3-Fluoroethamphetamine. Empathogen-stimulant. MDMA-like but milder. Duration 4-6 hours. Orange Marquis. Neurotoxicity unknown. Serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs/MAOIs. NO long-term safety data. Research chemical. Quality varies.

description.overview: A-PHP (α-Pyrrolidinohexiophenone) is a synthetic cathinone from the pyrovalerone family (same as α-PVP/flakka). EXTREMELY potent and addictive. Very short duration (30 minutes-2 hours) causing compulsive redosing. Severe paranoia and psychosis common. Often vaped. One of most dangerous cathinones. Many horror stories.
description.origins: Appeared on RC markets mid-2010s after α-PVP (flakka) bans. Chemically very similar to α-PVP. Quickly gained reputation as extremely addictive and dangerous. Many trip reports describe psychotic episodes, paranoia, dangerous behavior. Banned in many countries. Still available from RC vendors in some regions.
description.uses: Recreational: Intense stimulation, euphoria (short-lived). Typical dose 5-30mg (very potent). Duration 30min-2hrs. Often vaped for faster onset. Compulsive redosing nearly universal. Described as more euphoric than α-PVP but equally dangerous.
description.dangers: EXTREME ADDICTION POTENTIAL: Compulsive redosing leads to multi-day binges. SEVERE PSYCHOSIS common: paranoia, hallucinations, delusions, violent behavior. Cardiovascular crisis: tachycardia, chest pain, heart attack. Hyperthermia. Extreme vasoconstriction. 'Stim dick' (erectile dysfunction). Insomnia for days. Terrible comedown: suicidal depression, exhaustion. Many users report regretting ever trying. Hospitalization/arrest common. NO safety data. Avoid.

notes: α-Pyrrolidinohexiophenone. Pyrovalerone cathinone like flakka. EXTREME DANGER: Highly addictive, severe psychosis common. Duration 30min-2hrs. Orange Marquis. Compulsive redosing, paranoia, violent behavior reported. Many regret trying. AVOID. Research chemical.

description.overview: Memantine (Namenda) is an NMDA receptor antagonist prescribed for Alzheimer's disease. At recreational doses (50-150mg+), produces dissociative effects similar to DXM or ketamine but much longer duration (12-24+ hours). Effects described as clearer, less confusing than DXM. Some use for harm reduction (tolerance reduction to other substances). Relatively safe at therapeutic doses.
description.origins: Synthesized 1963. Approved for Alzheimer's 2003 in US. Discovered by psychonauts 2000s-2010s to have dissociative effects at higher doses. Less well-known than DXM or ketamine but has dedicated following. Legal—available by prescription. Some obtain for off-label use (tolerance reduction, nootropic, recreational). Slow onset discourages abuse.
description.uses: Medical: Alzheimer's disease (10-20mg daily). Recreational/off-label: Dissociation (50-150mg), tolerance reduction to stimulants/opioids, nootropic (low doses). Duration 12-24+ hours (very long). Slow onset (2-4 hours). Effects: dissociation, altered perception, mild euphoria, reduced anxiety. Described as clearer and more functional than DXM.
description.dangers: Very long duration can be uncomfortable if dose too high (stuck dissociated for day). Cognitive impairment while active. Motor incoordination. Dizziness. At high doses: confusion, memory impairment, hallucinations. Can worsen mental health issues. Interactions with other drugs possible. Relatively safe compared to other dissociatives but still carries risks. Not recommended for frequent recreational use.

notes: Namenda. NMDA antagonist dissociative. Alzheimer's medication. Duration 12-24+ hours (VERY long). Higher doses (50-150mg) cause dissociation. Clearer than DXM. Used for tolerance reduction. Relatively safe but long duration can be uncomfortable. Prescription medication. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Baclofen is a GABA-B receptor agonist prescribed for muscle spasticity, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injuries. Similar mechanism to phenibut and GHB. At higher doses, produces sedation, euphoria, alcohol-like intoxication. Increasing recreational abuse. Physical dependence develops quickly. Withdrawal can be severe including hallucinations and seizures. Prescription medication—Schedule not controlled in US but regulated.
description.origins: Synthesized 1962. Approved for medical use 1977. Used for muscle spasticity, MS, spinal injuries, cerebral palsy. Researched for alcohol/GHB addiction treatment (high-dose baclofen therapy). Recreational abuse emerged 2000s-2010s, especially among opioid users and in prison populations. Awareness of abuse potential increasing.
description.uses: Medical: Muscle spasticity (10-80mg/day divided doses), MS, spinal cord injury. Off-label/research: Alcohol addiction treatment (up to 300mg/day under supervision). Recreational: Euphoria, sedation, anxiolysis, alcohol-like intoxication. Typical recreational dose 75-150mg+. Duration 4-8 hours. Used by some as GHB/phenibut alternative.
description.dangers: PHYSICAL DEPENDENCE develops quickly with daily use. SEVERE WITHDRAWAL: hallucinations, seizures, delirium, psychosis—can be life-threatening. Requires slow medical taper (like benzos/alcohol). Overdose causes severe CNS depression, respiratory depression, coma. FATAL when combined with other depressants (alcohol, opioids, benzos). Cognitive impairment, memory issues. Motor incoordination. Can worsen mental health conditions. High-dose therapy requires medical supervision.

scientific_papers.title: Baclofen withdrawal: Case reports and review
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of severe baclofen withdrawal syndrome

notes: GABA-B agonist muscle relaxant. Similar to phenibut/GHB. Physical dependence develops quickly. SEVERE WITHDRAWAL—hallucinations, seizures, can be FATAL. Requires medical taper. Often FATAL with alcohol/opioids/benzos. Prescription medication. Recreational abuse increasing. No reagent reaction.

description.overview: Hydromorphone (Dilaudid) is a semi-synthetic opioid approximately 5-8x more potent than morphine. Prescribed for severe pain, often in hospital settings or for cancer/palliative care. High abuse potential due to intense euphoria when injected or insufflated. Schedule II controlled substance. Common in diversion/street markets. Often preferred by opioid users over other pharmaceuticals.
description.origins: Synthesized from morphine 1924. Marketed as Dilaudid. Used medically for severe acute pain, chronic pain, cancer pain. Available as tablets (2mg, 4mg, 8mg), liquid, and injectable. Popular in 1960s-1980s among opioid users. Still widely prescribed and diverted. Known for producing intense rush when IV'd. Street names: D's, Dillies, Juice.
description.uses: Medical: Severe pain management, post-surgical pain, cancer/palliative care, chronic pain. Typical dose 2-8mg oral (opioid-naive). Recreational: Intense euphoria, sedation, pain relief. Duration 4-5 hours oral, 2-3 hours IV. Often crushed and snorted or injected for maximum effect. Highly sought after by opioid users—considered premium pharmaceutical opioid.
description.dangers: EXTREMELY HIGH OVERDOSE RISK: Very potent—easy to misjudge dose. Respiratory depression, coma, death. Risk magnified with IV/insufflated use. Often mixed with fentanyl in street supplies. Cross-tolerance with other opioids but potency differences dangerous. Physical dependence develops quickly. Severe withdrawal. Constipation. Injection risks: abscess, endocarditis, HIV/HCV. Naloxone required for overdose—may need multiple doses. Combining with benzos, alcohol OFTEN FATAL.

scientific_papers.title: Hydromorphone: Pharmacology and clinical applications
scientific_papers.journal: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of hydromorphone's pharmacology and medical use

notes: Dilaudid. Semi-synthetic opioid. 5-8x stronger than morphine. EXTREME overdose risk—very potent. Often contains fentanyl in street supply. Highly sought after—intense euphoria when IV'd. Physical dependence, severe withdrawal. Schedule II. Naloxone essential. Brown/purple Marquis.

description.overview: Oxymorphone (Opana) is a semi-synthetic opioid approximately 3x more potent than oxycodone, 10x morphine. Was prescribed for severe pain until reformulated/discontinued in many markets due to massive IV abuse epidemic. Original formulation easily crushed and injected, causing HIV/HCV outbreaks. Extended-release version (Opana ER) pulled from US market 2017. Still available in some countries.
description.origins: Synthesized 1914. Marketed as Opana/Numorphan. Prescribed for severe pain. Original Opana ER (2006-2012) easily defeated abuse-deterrent and became epidemic problem. Reformulated 2012 but abuse continued. Associated with major HIV outbreak in Scott County, Indiana 2015 (180+ cases from sharing needles). Manufacturer voluntarily withdrew 2017 at FDA request. Generic versions may still exist. Street names: Stop signs (octagonal tablets), blues.
description.uses: Medical (where available): Severe pain, post-surgical pain. Typical dose 5-10mg oral. Recreational/abuse: Intense euphoria when crushed and IV'd or insufflated. Duration 4-6 hours (IR), 12 hours (ER). Extremely sought after before withdrawal. Described as one of most euphoric pharmaceutical opioids.
description.dangers: CATASTROPHIC PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT: IV abuse caused major HIV/HCV outbreaks. EXTREME overdose risk—very potent. Respiratory depression, death. Reformulated version caused severe harm when injected (thrombotic microangiopathy). Physical dependence, severe withdrawal. Now rare in supply but if encountered—EXTREMELY DANGEROUS. Likely contaminated with fentanyl if on street. Naloxone essential—may need many doses.

scientific_papers.title: The Opana ER abuse crisis: Lessons learned
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of oxymorphone abuse epidemic and public health response

notes: Opana. Semi-synthetic opioid. 10x morphine potency. CAUSED HIV OUTBREAKS from IV abuse. Withdrawn from US market 2017. If encountered: EXTREME DANGER. Likely fentanyl-contaminated. Very potent. Historical abuse epidemic. Schedule II. Brown/purple Marquis.

description.overview: U-47700 (Pink, Pinky) is a synthetic opioid research chemical approximately 7-8x more potent than morphine. Developed by Upjohn 1970s but never marketed. Appeared on RC markets 2015. Linked to hundreds of overdose deaths 2016-2017. Extremely caustic—causes severe tissue damage. Emergency scheduled in many countries. Still occasionally encountered. Very dangerous.
description.origins: Synthesized by Upjohn Pharmaceutical 1976 as potential analgesic. Never approved or marketed. Rediscovered by RC vendors 2015. Sold online as 'research chemical' or 'not for human consumption.' Quickly linked to overdose deaths. Called 'Pink' or 'Pinky' due to pink/tan color. Emergency scheduled US 2016, permanent Schedule I 2017. Banned in most countries but still produced in clandestine labs.
description.uses: No legitimate medical use. Recreational/abuse: Opioid effects—euphoria, pain relief, sedation. Typical dose 5-30mg oral/insufflated (very potent). Duration 3-5 hours. Extremely caustic when insufflated—burns nasal passages severely. Often mixed with other substances (heroin, fentanyl, pressed pills).
description.dangers: EXTREME DANGER: Caustic—causes severe chemical burns to nasal passages, injection sites. Tissue necrosis, nasal septum perforation common with insufflation. Standard opioid risks magnified: respiratory depression, overdose, death. Linked to hundreds of deaths. Often mixed with fentanyl (even more dangerous). No quality control—potency varies wildly. Physical dependence. Naloxone works but may need high doses. Schedule I—serious legal consequences.

scientific_papers.title: U-47700: Pharmacology and role in overdose deaths
scientific_papers.summary: Analysis of U-47700 pharmacology and fatal overdoses

notes: Pink, Pinky. Synthetic opioid RC. EXTREMELY CAUSTIC—chemical burns, tissue necrosis. Linked to hundreds of deaths 2016-2017. 7-8x morphine potency. Often mixed with fentanyl. Nasal septum perforation from insufflation. Schedule I. AVOID. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Isotonitazene (ISO, toni) is a synthetic benzimidazole opioid from the 'nitazene' series. EXTREMELY potent—estimates range from 20-100x morphine, potentially approaching fentanyl potency. Appeared 2019 in illicit drug supply. Linked to overdose deaths worldwide. Used to adulterate heroin, pressed pills. Emergency scheduled many countries. Part of concerning trend of ultra-potent synthetic opioids beyond fentanyl.
description.origins: Nitazenes originally developed 1950s-1960s by CIBA pharmaceutical. Never marketed due to extreme potency/danger. Isotonitazene and related nitazenes (metonitazene, etonitazene, protonitazene) appeared on illicit markets 2019-2020. Likely synthesized in clandestine labs, possibly China. Used as fentanyl alternative/adulterant. Emergency scheduled in many jurisdictions 2020-2021.
description.uses: NO legitimate medical use. Appears in illicit supply: Adulterating heroin, fake pills (M30s, Xanax), pressed tablets sold as other opioids. Users often unaware they're consuming nitazenes. Doses unknown—sold as other substances. Effects: intense opioid effects, respiratory depression, overdose.
description.dangers: CATASTROPHICALLY DANGEROUS: Ultra-potent—tiny amounts cause overdose. Respiratory depression, unconsciousness, death within minutes. Many deaths attributed to nitazenes. Naloxone works but requires VERY HIGH DOSES, multiple administrations. Standard naloxone dose may be insufficient. Users often don't know what they're taking (sold as heroin, oxy, etc). Testing difficult—may not show up on standard screens. Assume any street opioid could contain this. NEVER use alone. Fentanyl test strips may not detect.

scientific_papers.title: Isotonitazene and the nitazene opioid analogs: Emerging threats
scientific_papers.summary: First comprehensive analysis of nitazene emergence in drug supply

notes: ISO, toni. Nitazene-class ultra-potent opioid. 20-100x morphine, approaching fentanyl potency. EXTREME FATALITY RISK. Found in fake pills, heroin. Requires VERY HIGH naloxone doses. Users often unaware. Emergency scheduled. Represents post-fentanyl threat. NEVER use alone. Orange Marquis.

description.overview: Metonitazene is an ultra-potent synthetic benzimidazole opioid from the nitazene series. Estimated 100x more potent than morphine, comparable to fentanyl. First appeared in illicit drug supply 2019-2020. Linked to numerous overdose deaths across US, Canada, Europe. Found in counterfeit pills (M30s, Xanax), heroin, and cocaine. Users typically unaware they're consuming it. Emergency scheduled Schedule I in US and many countries.
description.origins: Part of nitazene opioid series originally developed by CIBA pharmaceutical in 1950s-1960s, never marketed due to extreme potency. Metonitazene resurfaced in clandestine drug markets 2019-2020, likely synthesized in illicit labs. Used as fentanyl alternative or adulterant. Emergency scheduled by DEA 2021. Represents concerning trend of ultra-potent synthetic opioids beyond fentanyl.
description.uses: NO legitimate medical use. Appears adulterating: heroin, pressed fake pills (oxycodone M30s, Xanax bars, Percocet), cocaine. Sold as other substances—users unknowingly consume. Extremely dangerous due to unknown potency in street products. Typical street doses impossible to determine—leads to overdoses.
description.dangers: EXTREME OVERDOSE RISK—potency rivals fentanyl. Rapid respiratory depression, death. Requires HIGH doses naloxone, multiple administrations. Extremely small margin between effective dose and fatal dose. Found mixed with other drugs—poly-drug toxicity. Users unaware of what they're taking. Counterfeit pills appear identical to pharmaceutical products. Duration of effects unknown—may require prolonged medical monitoring. Physical dependence develops rapidly. Withdrawal severe. Post-fentanyl crisis substance—harm reduction critical.

scientific_papers.title: Metonitazene in the United States: History, Pharmacology, and Toxicology
scientific_papers.summary: First comprehensive review of metonitazene emergence, pharmacology, and toxicological findings

scientific_papers.title: Novel synthetic opioids: The pathologist's point of view
scientific_papers.summary: Review of designer opioids including metonitazene in postmortem cases

notes: Metonitazene. Ultra-potent nitazene opioid. ~100x morphine potency. EXTREME FATALITY RISK. Found in fake M30s, Xanax, heroin, cocaine. Users typically unaware. Requires multiple high-dose naloxone. Emergency Schedule I. Post-fentanyl crisis threat. NEVER use drugs alone. Fentanyl test strips may not detect. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Etonitazene is one of the original and most potent nitazene opioids, estimated 1000-1500x more potent than morphine. Originally synthesized in 1950s, abandoned due to extreme danger. Re-emerged in illicit drug supply 2020+. One of the most dangerous synthetic opioids ever identified. Found in fake pills and powder drugs. Minimal amount causes fatal overdose.
description.origins: First synthesized by CIBA pharmaceutical 1950s-1960s as part of nitazene analgesic research program. Never approved for medical use due to extreme potency and danger. Remained obscure until reappearing in European and North American drug supply 2020-2021. Likely synthesized in clandestine labs. Emergency scheduled internationally. Represents apex of designer opioid potency crisis.
description.uses: NO medical use ever approved. Illicit use: Adulterating heroin, fentanyl, fake pharmaceutical pills. Extreme potency means active doses are sub-milligram—impossible to dose accurately without laboratory equipment. Users virtually never aware they're consuming it. Effects: intense opioid effects, immediate respiratory depression, death.
description.dangers: MOST DANGEROUS opioid in current drug supply—potency exceeds most fentanyl analogues. Minuscule amounts (micrograms) can be fatal. Impossible to visually detect or dose safely. Requires EXTREME naloxone doses, continuous administration. May overwhelm typical naloxone supply. Death can occur within minutes of exposure. Found mixed with other substances—unpredictable effects. No safe use scenario for non-medical contexts. Represents worst-case scenario of synthetic opioid crisis.

scientific_papers.title: Etonitazene: A review of pharmacology and emergence in the illicit drug supply
scientific_papers.summary: Comprehensive review of etonitazene pharmacology and public health implications

notes: Etonitazene. MOST POTENT nitazene—1000-1500x morphine. EXTREME FATAL RISK. Micrograms can kill. Original 1950s research compound re-emerged. Found in fake pills, powder drugs. Impossible to dose safely. Requires extreme naloxone doses. May overwhelm medical response. NEVER use alone. Emergency Schedule I globally. Orange Marquis.

description.overview: Protonitazene is a synthetic nitazene opioid estimated 20-50x more potent than morphine. Appeared in drug supply 2019-2020 alongside other nitazenes. Found in fake prescription pills, heroin, and as standalone powder. Linked to overdose deaths across North America and Europe. Part of the nitazene family causing post-fentanyl crisis concerns.
description.origins: Developed during CIBA's 1950s-1960s nitazene research program, never marketed. Re-emerged in clandestine drug markets 2019-2020. Synthesized in illicit labs as designer opioid. Found in drug seizures and toxicology cases. Emergency scheduled Schedule I in US 2021 along with other nitazenes. Represents ongoing evolution of synthetic opioid market.
description.uses: NO legitimate medical use. Illicit: Found in counterfeit oxycodone M30 pills, fake Xanax bars, heroin, fentanyl mixtures. Users typically unaware of protonitazene presence. Sold as other opioids. Impossible to determine dose in street drugs—high overdose risk.
description.dangers: High overdose risk—20-50x morphine potency. Respiratory depression, death. Users don't know they're taking it. Found in fake pharmaceutical pills that look identical to real medications. Requires multiple naloxone doses. Small amounts fatal. May be combined with fentanyl or other nitazenes—extreme danger. Rapid tolerance, physical dependence. Withdrawal severe. Part of poly-drug contamination crisis.

scientific_papers.title: Protonitazene identified in biological specimens and drug seizure materials
scientific_papers.summary: First reports of protonitazene in US overdose cases and drug seizures

notes: Protonitazene. Nitazene opioid 20-50x morphine potency. Found in fake M30s, Xanax, heroin. High overdose risk. Users unaware. Requires multiple naloxone doses. Emergency Schedule I. Often mixed with fentanyl. Part of designer opioid crisis. NEVER use alone. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Brorphine (1-{1-[1-(4-bromophenyl)ethyl]piperidin-4-yl}-1,3-dihydro-2H-benzo[d]imidazol-2-one) is a synthetic opioid that appeared ~2018-2019 as research chemical. Moderate to high potency. Known for being CAUSTIC—damages tissues on contact. Found in pressed pills and powder. Linked to deaths in US, Europe. Short duration drives compulsive redosing.
description.origins: Benzimidazole-based opioid appearing on research chemical markets 2018-2019. Sold as 'legal' opioid alternative after U-47700 scheduling. Minimal human safety data when introduced. User reports described tissue damage, unpleasant side effects. Implicated in overdose deaths. Emergency scheduled in multiple countries 2020-2021.
description.uses: NO medical use. Recreational: Opioid effects—euphoria, pain relief, sedation. Typical dose 0.5-2mg (highly potent). Duration 2-4 hours (short). Often found in fake pharmaceutical pills. CAUSTIC nature makes insufflation extremely dangerous—nasal damage, necrosis possible.
description.dangers: CAUSTIC—causes chemical burns, tissue damage on contact. Nasal septum perforation from snorting. Respiratory depression, overdose risk. Short duration causes rapid tolerance, compulsive redosing. Physical dependence develops quickly. Withdrawal reported as severe. Found in counterfeit pills with unknown dosing. May be mixed with fentanyl or other opioids. Quality control issues. Naloxone should work but limited data. Legal status ambiguous in some areas—analogue act risk.

scientific_papers.title: Brorphine: Identifying a Novel Synthetic Opioid
scientific_papers.summary: First analytical characterization of brorphine in overdose cases

notes: Brorphine. Synthetic opioid RC. CAUSTIC—tissue damage like U-47700. Nasal septum damage from insufflation. Moderate-high potency (0.5-2mg dose). Short duration (2-4hr) drives redosing. Found in fake pills. Linked to deaths. Emergency scheduled. NO safety data. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: AP-238 (bucinnazine, 1-benzylbenzimidazole) is a synthetic opioid research chemical that appeared ~2020. Moderate potency (similar to codeine/tramadol). Caustic like U-47700—damages tissues. Short duration encourages redosing. Very little safety data. Reports of severe withdrawal. Part of post-U-47700 wave of designer opioids. Legal status unclear in many places.
description.origins: Benzimidazole opioid developed decades ago, never marketed. Appeared on RC markets around 2020 after other designer opioids scheduled. Sold as 'research chemical' powder. Marketed as legal opioid alternative. Minimal human use data. User reports describe it as caustic, short-acting, with unpleasant side effects.
description.uses: No medical use. Recreational: Opioid effects—pain relief, euphoria, sedation. Typical dose 50-150mg (reports vary). Duration 2-4 hours (short—drives redosing). Often insufflated despite being caustic. Some users report it as disappointing compared to traditional opioids.
description.dangers: CAUSTIC—burns nasal passages, causes tissue damage (like U-47700). Respiratory depression, overdose risk. Very short duration leads to compulsive redosing and rapid tolerance/dependence. Withdrawal reported as severe, potentially worse than traditional opioids. NO safety data. Quality/purity unknown. May be mixed with other substances. Legal status unclear—risk of analogue act prosecution. Naloxone should work but limited data.

notes: Bucinnazine. Synthetic opioid RC. CAUSTIC—tissue damage like U-47700. Short duration (2-4hrs) causes compulsive redosing. Severe withdrawal reported. NO safety data. Legal status unclear. Research chemical—extreme caution. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Escaline (3,5-methoxy-4-ethoxyphenethylamine) is a synthetic mescaline analogue from the escaline series. Produces visual psychedelic effects similar to mescaline but slightly shorter duration (8-12 hours). More potent than mescaline. Research chemical with limited human data. Described as visual, colorful, less headspace-heavy than many psychedelics. Part of Alexander Shulgin's work.
description.origins: First synthesized and documented by Alexander Shulgin in PiHKAL (Phenethylamines I Have Known And Loved) 1991. One of several mescaline analogues Shulgin explored (proscaline, allylescaline, metaescaline, etc). Minimal use until 2010s when appeared on RC markets. Legal status varies—often unscheduled but may fall under analogue laws. Limited scientific study.
description.uses: Recreational: Visual psychedelic effects, color enhancement, pattern recognition, mild euphoria. Typical dose 40-60mg. Duration 8-12 hours. Described as clearer and more visual than mescaline, less nauseating. Gentler headspace than LSD/psilocybin. Used for psychedelic exploration, creativity, introspection.
description.dangers: Standard psychedelic risks: bad trips, anxiety, panic, triggering latent mental illness. Vasoconstriction (phenethylamine side effect). Nausea possible but less than mescaline. NO long-term safety data in humans. Quality/purity varies (research chemical). May cause overstimulation at high doses. Legal status unclear—analogue act risks. Duration long—commit to full experience. Not suitable for those with mental health issues or heart conditions.

scientific_papers.title: PiHKAL: A Chemical Love Story
scientific_papers.summary: Original documentation of escaline and mescaline analogues

notes: Mescaline analogue. Psychedelic phenethylamine. Duration 8-12 hours. Dose 40-60mg. More potent than mescaline. Visual, colorful, less nausea. Shulgin compound (PiHKAL). NO human safety data. Research chemical. Legal status unclear. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Proscaline (3,5-methoxy-4-n-propoxyphenethylamine) is a synthetic mescaline analogue. Produces mescaline-like psychedelic effects with 8-12 hour duration. More potent than mescaline. Known for visual effects, color enhancement, warm bodyload. Less stimulating than some phenethylamines. Research chemical from Shulgin's work.
description.origins: Synthesized and documented by Alexander Shulgin in PiHKAL 1991. Part of homologous series with escaline (ethoxy), metaescaline (methoxy), allylescaline (allyloxy). Each differs by substituent group on 4-position. Proscaline (propoxy group) considered by some as sweet spot in series. Available from RC vendors 2010s+. Unscheduled in most jurisdictions but analogue act may apply.
description.uses: Recreational/psychedelic: Visual psychedelics, pattern recognition, color saturation, euphoria, introspection. Typical dose 30-60mg. Duration 8-12 hours. Described as warm, colorful, gentle. Less anxiety-provoking than LSD for some users. Used for psychedelic experiences, creativity, nature appreciation.
description.dangers: Standard psychedelic risks: anxiety, panic, bad trips, mental health exacerbation. Phenethylamine vasoconstriction. Possible nausea (less than mescaline). NO established safety profile—research chemical. Quality/purity unknown. Long duration requires time commitment. Legal ambiguity—analogue act. Not for those with cardiovascular or psychiatric conditions.

scientific_papers.title: PiHKAL: A Chemical Love Story
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of proscaline synthesis and effects

notes: Mescaline analogue. Psychedelic phenethylamine. Duration 8-12 hours. Dose 30-60mg. Warm, visual, colorful. Less nausea than mescaline. Shulgin compound. NO safety data. Research chemical. Legal status unclear. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Allylescaline (3,5-methoxy-4-allyloxyphenethylamine) is a synthetic mescaline analogue with an allyloxy group. Produces mescaline-like psychedelic effects. Duration 8-14 hours (one of longer mescaline analogues). More potent than mescaline. Known for strong visuals, color enhancement, introspective headspace. Research chemical from Shulgin's series.
description.origins: Synthesized and documented by Alexander Shulgin in PiHKAL 1991. Part of 4-substituted mescaline analogue series. Allylescaline (allyloxy) noted by Shulgin as particularly visual and aesthetic. Available on RC markets 2010s+. Less common than escaline/proscaline but has dedicated following. Unscheduled but analogue act concerns.
description.uses: Recreational/psychedelic: Strong visual effects, enhanced colors, pattern recognition, introspection, nature connection. Typical dose 20-40mg (quite potent). Duration 8-14 hours (long). Described as aesthetic, visual, with warm bodyload. Some users prefer over other mescaline analogues for depth.
description.dangers: Standard psychedelic risks: anxiety, panic attacks, triggering mental illness, challenging experiences. Phenethylamine vasoconstriction. LONG duration—requires full day commitment. Nausea possible. NO human safety studies. Research chemical—quality unknown. Legal uncertainty. Not for cardiovascular/psychiatric conditions.

scientific_papers.title: PiHKAL: A Chemical Love Story
scientific_papers.summary: Original allylescaline documentation

notes: Mescaline analogue. Psychedelic phenethylamine. Duration 8-14 hours (LONG). Dose 20-40mg (potent). Strong visuals, aesthetic. Shulgin compound. NO safety data. Research chemical. Legal unclear. Requires full day. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: MAL (Methallylescaline, 3,5-dimethoxy-4-methallyoxyphenethylamine) is a synthetic mescaline analogue. Similar to allylescaline but with methallyl group. Produces psychedelic effects comparable to mescaline. Duration 10-16 hours (very long). Visual, introspective. Research chemical with very limited human data. Rare even among mescaline analogues.
description.origins: Synthesized and documented by Alexander Shulgin in PiHKAL 1991. Less explored than other mescaline analogues. Occasionally appears on RC markets but quite rare. Minimal trip reports. Shulgin noted it as active and interesting but didn't elaborate extensively. Legal status: unscheduled but analogue concerns.
description.uses: Recreational/psychedelic: Mescaline-like psychedelic effects—visuals, introspection, color enhancement. Typical dose 40-65mg (estimated from limited reports). Duration 10-16 hours (very long). Described as similar to allylescaline. Used for deep psychedelic experiences.
description.dangers: VERY LIMITED DATA: Extremely few human experience reports. Standard psychedelic risks amplified by unknowns. VERY LONG duration—major time commitment. Vasoconstriction. Nausea possible. NO safety studies. Research chemical—quality/purity unknown. Legal ambiguity. Recommended only for experienced psychonauts willing to pioneer. Not for those with health conditions.

scientific_papers.title: PiHKAL: A Chemical Love Story
scientific_papers.summary: Brief documentation of MAL

notes: Methallylescaline. Mescaline analogue. Duration 10-16 hours (VERY LONG). Dose 40-65mg. VERY LIMITED human data—rare RC. Psychedelic effects similar to mescaline/allylescaline. Shulgin compound. NO safety data. For experienced only. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Metaescaline (3,5-dimethoxy-4-methoxyphenethylamine) is a synthetic mescaline analogue. All three methoxy groups (hence 'meta'). Produces psychedelic effects but generally considered less potent/interesting than other mescaline analogues. Duration 8-12 hours. Research chemical with limited interest—overshadowed by escaline/proscaline.
description.origins: Synthesized and documented by Alexander Shulgin in PiHKAL 1991. Considered less impressive than escaline/proscaline series. Shulgin noted it as active but not particularly noteworthy. Rarely available even on RC markets. Few modern experience reports. Legal: unscheduled but analogue act.
description.uses: Recreational: Psychedelic effects, visuals, mild euphoria. Typical dose 200-350mg (much higher than other analogues—less potent). Duration 8-12 hours. Described as mild, manageable. Some use for gentle psychedelic introduction. Generally not preferred over other options.
description.dangers: Standard psychedelic risks: anxiety, panic, mental health issues. Higher doses required mean more material consumed (purity concerns). Vasoconstriction. Nausea. LIMITED safety data. Research chemical. Legal ambiguity. Generally considered safer profile due to mildness but still carries unknowns.

scientific_papers.title: PiHKAL: A Chemical Love Story
scientific_papers.summary: Documentation of metaescaline as less potent analogue

notes: Mescaline analogue. Less potent than others. Duration 8-12 hours. Dose 200-350mg (high). Mild psychedelic. Shulgin compound but considered unremarkable. Rare RC. NO safety data. Legal unclear. Orange/brown Marquis.

description.overview: Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is a tropical tree native to Southeast Asia whose leaves contain alkaloids that act as opioid agonists and stimulants. At low doses, produces stimulant effects; at higher doses, opioid-like pain relief and sedation. Widely used for pain management, opioid withdrawal, and energy. Legal status varies by country and US state.
description.origins: Used traditionally in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia for centuries by laborers to combat fatigue and manage pain. Leaves chewed fresh or brewed as tea. Western awareness grew in 1800s but remained obscure until 2000s internet commerce. Banned in Thailand (ironically, its origin) since 1943 but recently re-legalized. DEA attempted scheduling in 2016 but withdrew after public outcry. Currently unscheduled federally in US but banned in several states.
description.uses: Traditional: Energy, pain relief, treating diarrhea, wound healing. Modern: Self-treatment for chronic pain (alternative to prescription opioids), opioid withdrawal aid (reduces symptoms), anxiety and depression relief, energy and focus (low doses), recreational sedation (high doses). Strains: Red (sedating, pain relief), Green (balanced), White (energizing). Typical dose 2-5g (moderate) to 5-10g+ (strong). Often consumed as powder in capsules, 'toss and wash,' or tea.
description.dangers: Physical dependence and withdrawal with regular use—symptoms similar to mild opioid withdrawal (muscle aches, irritability, insomnia, runny nose). Tolerance develops, requiring increasing doses. Nausea and 'wobbles' (dizziness, nausea) common at high doses or with certain strains. Constipation (opioid effect). Liver toxicity rare but reported with chronic heavy use or adulterated products. Respiratory depression possible when combined with other CNS depressants (alcohol, benzos, opioids)—deaths almost always involve poly-drug use. Seizures reported in rare cases. Quality control issues: products may be contaminated with salmonella, heavy metals, or adulterated with actual opioids. Some extracts (shots, enhanced products) extremely potent. Addiction potential debated but real for some users. Can test positive for methadone on some drug tests (false positive).
