bottom_line.message: The safest option is to avoid pills obtained outside of a licensed pharmacy. If you choose to use pressed pills, TEST EVERY SINGLE PILL, never use alone, and have naloxone available. Your life depends on it.

overview.title: Medical Emergency Response & Hospital Treatment
overview.warning: ⚠️ THIS IS EDUCATIONAL INFORMATION ONLY. In a medical emergency, ALWAYS call emergency services (911 in US) immediately. Time is critical.
overview.good_samaritan: Most US states and many countries have Good Samaritan laws protecting people who call for help during a drug emergency from arrest or prosecution. As of 2023, 47 US states + DC have some form of these laws. States with NO or very limited protections: Wyoming, Kansas, Texas (very limited). ALWAYS CALL 911 REGARDLESS - saving a life is more important than potential legal consequences.

emergency_response.name: Immediate Actions (Before Help Arrives)
steps: 1. CALL 911 / Emergency Services immediately - don't wait to see if symptoms improve
2. Stay with the person - never leave them alone
3. Recovery position - if unconscious but breathing, place on their side to prevent choking
4. Check breathing - if not breathing normally, begin CPR if trained
5. Keep warm - cover with blanket, maintain body temperature
6. Stay calm - reassure the person if conscious
7. Collect information - what was taken, how much, when, what route
what_to_tell_ems: Be HONEST about what substance was taken - doctors can't help properly without this info
Any other drugs or alcohol consumed
Bring pill bottles, drug samples, or paraphernalia if safe to do so
do_not: DO NOT induce vomiting unless specifically instructed by medical personnel
DO NOT give food or drink if person is unconscious or having seizures
DO NOT put person in cold shower or bath (risk of drowning, shock)
DO NOT try to 'walk it off'
DO NOT restrain violently - risk of injury, hyperthermia
DO NOT withhold information from medical staff

opioid_overdose.name: Opioid Overdose (Heroin, Fentanyl, Morphine, Oxycodone)
prehospital: Naloxone (Narcan) nasal spray or injection - reverses opioid effects
Multiple doses may be needed for fentanyl
Rescue breathing or CPR if not breathing
hospital: IV naloxone continuous infusion (fentanyl requires longer monitoring)
Oxygen support or mechanical ventilation if needed
Cardiac monitoring
Observation for 4-6+ hours (fentanyl may require 12-24h)
Withdrawal management if needed
notes: Naloxone wears off in 30-90 minutes but drug may last longer - hospital observation critical
Fentanyl and analogues may require repeated naloxone doses
Withdrawal can begin immediately after naloxone - uncomfortable but not life-threatening

stimulant_overdose.name: Stimulant Overdose/Toxicity (Cocaine, Meth, MDMA, Cathinones)
hospital: Benzodiazepines (Valium, Ativan) for agitation, seizures, blood pressure
IV fluids for dehydration
Active cooling for hyperthermia (ice packs, cooling blankets, cold IV fluids)
Cardiac monitoring and treatment for arrhythmias
Antihypertensives if blood pressure dangerously high
Treatment for rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown) with aggressive hydration
Possible intubation and sedation for severe agitation
notes: No specific antidote - treatment is supportive
Hyperthermia (>104°F/40°C) is medical emergency - can cause organ failure
Serotonin syndrome risk with MDMA - requires cooling and sedation
Cardiac complications can occur hours after use

psychedelic_crisis.name: Psychedelic Bad Trip / Acute Anxiety (LSD, Psilocybin, 2C-x, NBOMes, DOx)
prehospital: Reassurance: 'You took a drug, this will end, you're safe'
Do not physically restrain unless absolutely necessary for safety
hospital: Benzodiazepines for severe anxiety/agitation (not routinely needed)
Quiet room with minimal stimulation
Talk-down technique: calm reassurance, reality orientation
Monitoring vital signs (NBOMes and DOx can cause dangerous symptoms)
Treatment of hyperthermia if present
Most patients do not need medication - supportive care sufficient
notes: Classic psychedelics (LSD, psilocybin) are not physically dangerous in overdose
NBOMes are dangerous - can cause seizures, hyperthermia, death
DOx compounds last 12-30 hours - prolonged hospital stay may be needed
Antipsychotics generally avoided (can worsen symptoms)

dissociative_toxicity.name: Dissociative Overdose (Ketamine, PCP, DXM, MXE, 3-MeO-PCP)
signs: High blood pressure and heart rate
prehospital: Do not restrain unless necessary - increases injury/hyperthermia risk
hospital: Benzodiazepines for agitation (especially PCP)
Monitoring and support of vital signs
IV fluids
Treatment of hyperthermia if present
Observation until fully conscious and oriented
Activated charcoal if recent oral ingestion and patient cooperative
notes: PCP can cause extreme, unpredictable violence - chemical sedation often needed
Most dissociatives wear off with supportive care
Respiratory depression possible at high doses

ghb_overdose.name: GHB/GBL Overdose
prehospital: Be prepared for sudden awakening (can be agitated)
hospital: Airway protection (intubation if needed)
Supportive care - no specific antidote
Monitoring until fully conscious
Treatment typically short (2-4 hours) as drug wears off quickly
Withdrawal monitoring if chronic user
notes: Very narrow margin between recreational dose and overdose
Combining with alcohol is extremely dangerous
Patients often wake up suddenly and may try to leave - dangerous if still impaired

serotonin_syndrome.name: Serotonin Syndrome (MDMA, combinations with antidepressants)
hospital: Discontinue all serotonergic drugs immediately
Benzodiazepines for agitation
Aggressive cooling for hyperthermia
IV fluids
Cyproheptadine (serotonin antagonist) in severe cases
ICU monitoring for severe cases
notes: Can be life-threatening if untreated
Risk increased when combining MDMA/other drugs with SSRIs, MAOIs
Usually resolves within 24 hours if drug stopped and supportive care given

benzodiazepine_overdose.name: Benzodiazepine/Sedative Overdose (Xanax, Valium, Klonopin, Etizolam, Flualprazolam, Phenibut)
prehospital: Recovery position if unconscious but breathing
Monitor breathing closely - be prepared for CPR
Keep person warm (benzos can cause hypothermia)
hospital: Airway protection - intubation if severe respiratory depression
Oxygen support or mechanical ventilation if needed
IV fluids for low blood pressure
Activated charcoal if recent ingestion (within 1 hour) and patient alert
Flumazenil (benzo antidote) - used CAUTIOUSLY and rarely
Cardiac and respiratory monitoring
Observation until fully conscious and stable
notes: Flumazenil (benzo reversal agent) is RARELY used - can cause seizures in chronic benzo users or if combined with other drugs
Combining benzos with alcohol or opioids dramatically increases overdose risk - respiratory depression can be fatal
Most benzo-only overdoses are not fatal if breathing is supported - death usually from combinations
Counterfeit pills (Xanax, Valium) may contain fentanyl, flualprazolam, or other dangerous substances
Withdrawal can be life-threatening for chronic users - medical supervision required for detox
Designer benzos (flualprazolam, etizolam) may be more potent and longer-lasting than expected

general_supportive.name: General Hospital Supportive Care (All Overdoses)
common_interventions: Blood tests: electrolytes, kidney/liver function, drug screen
ECG to check for cardiac abnormalities
Activated charcoal if recent oral ingestion (within 1 hour) and patient alert

legal_protections.name: Legal Protections for Seeking Help
good_samaritan_laws: 47 US states + DC have 'Good Samaritan' or '911 Immunity' laws (as of 2023)
These protect callers from arrest/prosecution for drug possession when calling 911
Protection typically extends to the person overdosing AND the person calling
Minor drug offenses usually covered; may not protect large-scale dealing
States with NO or very limited Good Samaritan protections: Wyoming, Kansas, Texas (limited)
EVEN in these states: ALWAYS call 911 anyway - saving a life is more important than legal risk
Laws vary by state - check local laws, but emergency response is priority
naloxone_access: Naloxone (Narcan) available without prescription in most states
Often free from harm reduction organizations, health departments
Pharmacies in most states can dispense without prescription
Carry naloxone if you or friends use opioids

after_treatment.name: After Emergency Treatment
recommendations: Consider substance use treatment or counseling
Reduce or stop use - tolerance drops quickly, same dose can overdose again
Never use alone - have someone present who can call for help
Start with small doses if resuming use
Tell your doctor about the incident - they can help prevent future emergencies

myths_and_misinformation.title: Debunking Common Myths & Dangerous Misinformation
myths_and_misinformation.overview: These widespread myths persist in drug culture but are factually incorrect and can lead to dangerous decisions. Evidence-based facts are provided to counter each myth.

myths.myth: Fentanyl can absorb through skin and cause overdose from brief contact
myths.reality: Dermal absorption of fentanyl requires prolonged contact with high concentration (like prescription patches). Brief contact with powder is extremely unlikely to cause overdose.
myths.truth: Most 'fentanyl exposure' events in first responders are panic attacks, not true toxicity. Still use gloves for safety, but brief contact is not immediately deadly. Real fentanyl OD causes sedation/respiratory depression, NOT anxiety.

myths.myth: If someone is overdosing, put them in a cold shower to wake them up
myths.reality: Cold shower risks: drowning, injury from falling, aspiration of water, shock, doesn't address underlying problem. Ineffective and dangerous.
myths.truth: Opioid OD: Give naloxone, rescue breathing, call 911. Stimulant toxicity: Cool environment, medical help. Never use cold shower for overdose.

myths.myth: Letting someone 'sleep it off' is safer than calling 911
myths.reality: Opioid overdoses can progress to respiratory arrest and death. What looks like 'sleeping' may be dying. Good Samaritan laws protect callers in most areas.
myths.truth: If you can't wake someone, breathing is slow (<12/min), lips/nails are blue, or you're unsure: CALL 911 IMMEDIATELY. Give naloxone if available. Sleeping off an overdose = death.

myths.myth: Naloxone is only for heroin; it doesn't work on fentanyl
myths.reality: Naloxone works on ALL opioids including fentanyl and analogues. Fentanyl may require higher/multiple doses, but naloxone is the correct treatment.
myths.truth: Naloxone works on fentanyl. May need 4-10mg total (multiple doses) vs 0.4-2mg for heroin. Keep giving naloxone and doing rescue breathing until help arrives.

myths.myth: Activated charcoal or drinking milk helps with drug overdoses
myths.reality: Activated charcoal only works if given by medical professionals within ~1 hour of ORAL ingestion, patient is conscious, and specific criteria met. Milk does nothing.
myths.truth: Don't try to give activated charcoal or milk to overdose victim. Call 911, give naloxone if opioid OD, provide rescue breathing, monitor until help arrives.

myths.myth: Drug test detox drinks/methods actually work
myths.reality: Most detox products are scams. Detection times depend on: substance half-life, metabolism, frequency of use, body fat percentage. No reliable way to 'beat' modern drug tests.
myths.truth: Only reliable method: abstinence for appropriate detection window (THC: days-weeks, others: hours-days). Dilution may work for urine tests but often detected. Synthetic urine illegal in many areas.

myths.myth: Calling 911 for an overdose will get everyone arrested
myths.reality: 47 US states + DC have Good Samaritan laws protecting callers and victims from prosecution for minor drug possession when seeking emergency help. Only Wyoming, Kansas, and Texas (very limited) lack these protections. Even in those states, arrests during overdose calls are rare.
myths.truth: ALWAYS call 911 for overdoses. Good Samaritan laws exist in 47 states + DC (as of 2023). States without: Wyoming, Kansas, Texas (limited). Even in these states, saving a life > legal risk. Paramedics are there to save lives, not make arrests. Police focus is medical emergency, not prosecution.

myths.myth: Cops can legally lie about being cops if asked
myths.reality: True, but irrelevant. Undercover officers can and do lie about their identity. Asking 'are you a cop' provides zero protection or useful information.
myths.truth: Don't rely on asking if someone is law enforcement. Practice operational security: don't discuss illegal activity with strangers, use harm reduction, test your substances.

myths.myth: Carrying drug testing kits is evidence of drug use and can get you arrested
myths.reality: In most jurisdictions, harm reduction supplies (including test kits, fentanyl strips) are legal and increasingly encouraged by public health. Some states explicitly protect possession.
myths.truth: Test kits are harm reduction tools. Fentanyl test strips are legal in all 50 US states as of 2023. Check local laws, but carrying testing supplies is generally legal.

myths.myth: If you've done a substance before, you can always handle the same dose
myths.reality: Tolerance decreases rapidly with time off (days to weeks). Purity varies wildly between batches. After a break, your 'normal' dose can cause overdose or unexpected intensity.
myths.truth: Always start with a lower dose after any break. Tolerance drops quickly—especially opioids (can drop 50% in days). Test every batch for potency differences.

myths.myth: Mixing uppers and downers cancels out the danger
myths.reality: Speedballs (cocaine + heroin) and similar combinations are extremely dangerous. Stimulant masks opioid sedation, then wears off first causing delayed respiratory depression. Heart strain from opposing effects.
myths.truth: Never mix stimulants and depressants thinking they 'balance.' This combination has killed countless people including celebrities. Effects don't cancel—they compound danger.

myths.myth: Taking more will make a 'bad trip' go away faster
myths.reality: Taking more of any substance during negative effects will intensify and prolong the experience. For psychedelics, this can turn manageable anxiety into full psychotic break.
myths.truth: If having bad experience: change environment, have sober friend present, practice breathing, remember it will end. NEVER take more. For psychedelics, benzodiazepines can help (medical setting).

myths.myth: Edibles don't work on me, so I should keep eating more
myths.reality: Edibles take 1-3 hours to peak (sometimes longer). People eat more before feeling first dose, then all doses hit at once causing severe anxiety, paranoia, or physical distress.
myths.truth: Start with 5-10mg THC (or less). Wait minimum 2-3 hours before considering more. Edible overdose isn't fatal but can be extremely unpleasant for 6-12 hours.

myths.myth: Volumetric dosing isn't necessary for small doses
myths.reality: Eyeballing doses of potent substances (LSD, benzos, research chemicals, fentanyl) can cause massive overdose. Milligram differences can be lethal for some substances.
myths.truth: For substances active in microgram/milligram range: use volumetric dosing (dissolve known amount in liquid, measure precisely). Invest in 0.001g scale minimum. Eyeballing can kill.

myths.myth: You can't overdose if you're experienced/have high tolerance
myths.reality: Experienced users die from overdoses regularly. Reasons: tolerance inconsistency, batch purity variation, fentanyl contamination, combination effects, overconfidence.
myths.truth: Experience doesn't grant immunity. Many OD deaths are experienced users who thought they knew their limits. Always test, start lower than you think, never use alone.

myths.myth: Using Narcan causes painful withdrawal, so hesitate to use it
myths.reality: Narcan (naloxone) may cause withdrawal symptoms in opioid-dependent people, but this is NOT a reason to avoid using it. Death is worse than withdrawal discomfort.
myths.truth: ALWAYS administer naloxone if suspected opioid overdose. Withdrawal is temporary and non-fatal. Not breathing is fatal. Give naloxone immediately, worry about withdrawal later.

myths.myth: Eating food before/during MDMA ruins the experience
myths.reality: Empty stomach may speed onset slightly, but having food prevents hypoglycemia, provides energy, and reduces nausea. Prolonged dancing on empty stomach is dangerous.
myths.truth: Eat a light meal before. Bring snacks with electrolytes. Nutrition and energy matter more than slightly faster onset.

myths.myth: Drinking lots of water prevents MDMA toxicity
myths.reality: MDMA + excessive water = hyponatremia (dangerously low sodium), which can be fatal. MDMA impairs body's ability to regulate water/electrolytes.
myths.truth: Moderate hydration only. ~500ml (16oz) water per hour maximum. Sports drinks with electrolytes better than plain water. Don't force water.

myths.myth: Vitamin C, orange juice, or acidic drinks enhance psychedelic trips
myths.reality: No scientific evidence. May slightly affect absorption of some substances, but doesn't 'enhance' or 'intensify' trips in meaningful way.
myths.truth: Placebo effect. Drink whatever keeps you comfortable and hydrated. Focus on set, setting, and dosage instead.

myths.myth: You should put ice in your eyes or on your neck if overheating on MDMA
myths.reality: Ice directly on eyes is dangerous (corneal damage). Ice on neck provides minimal cooling. Vasoconstriction from MDMA + ice = poor combination.
myths.truth: If overheating: move to cool area, remove excess clothing, drink cool water slowly, wet towels on forehead/wrists, seek medical help if severe. NO ice on eyes.

myths.myth: Testing your drugs means you're paranoid or inexperienced
myths.reality: Testing is smart, responsible harm reduction practiced by experienced users who understand the contaminated drug supply.
myths.truth: Testing is a sign of intelligence and experience, not paranoia. Dead people don't get to be experienced users.

myths.myth: Pure MDMA is always white/clear crystals
myths.reality: Pure MDMA is typically tan, brown, or champagne colored due to precursor residues (safrole). Pure white MDMA is suspicious and may indicate different synthesis route or not MDMA at all.
myths.truth: Color does NOT indicate purity or identity. Always test with reagents.

myths.myth: If it looks, smells, or tastes right, it's safe
myths.reality: Appearance, smell, and taste are completely unreliable. Fentanyl, NBOMes, and other dangerous adulterants can be made to look identical to expected substances.
myths.truth: NEVER rely on sensory identification. Taste testing can kill you (NBOMes, fentanyl). Always use reagent tests and fentanyl strips.

myths.myth: Reagent tests show purity percentage
myths.reality: Reagent tests only show PRESENCE of a substance, not concentration or purity. A 'correct' color just means the expected substance is present—could be 10% or 90% pure.
myths.truth: Only lab testing (GC/MS) can determine purity percentage. Reagents are presumptive identification only.

myths.myth: If my dealer has good reviews/reputation, I don't need to test
myths.reality: Dealers often don't know what they're selling. Cross-contamination happens during production. Supply chains are long and unreliable. Today's batch may differ from yesterday's.
myths.truth: ALWAYS test every batch, every time. People die from trusted sources regularly.

myths.myth: Pills with the same stamp/logo contain the same thing
myths.reality: Anyone can press pills with any stamp. Same appearance = zero guarantee of identical contents. Pill presses are widely available. Cartels mass-produce fake pharmaceuticals.
myths.truth: Pill appearance is meaningless. 6 out of 10 counterfeit pills contain lethal fentanyl (DEA). Test every pill individually.

myths.myth: Fentanyl test strips aren't accurate
myths.reality: Fentanyl test strips are highly sensitive immunoassay tests, same technology used in medical settings. They detect fentanyl and many analogues at very low concentrations.
myths.truth: Fentanyl strips are reliable for most fentanyl analogues. Some novel analogues may escape detection, but strips catch the vast majority. Use them every time.

myths.myth: Amanita muscaria mushroom products sold in smoke shops are safe because they're legal
myths.reality: Amanita muscaria (fly agaric) is NOT psilocybin. Contains muscimol and ibotenic acid which cause: delirium, nausea, confusion, seizures (high doses), unpredictable effects. Legality ≠ safety. Potency varies wildly between products and batches.
myths.truth: Amanita muscaria is a deliriant, not a classic psychedelic. Effects are often unpleasant and unpredictable. Not comparable to psilocybin mushrooms. Legal status doesn't mean safe—many dangerous substances are legal.

myths.myth: Mushroom vapes and edibles from smoke shops contain only natural mushroom extracts
myths.reality: Lab testing has found many 'mushroom' vapes contain 4-AcO-DMT (psilacetin, synthetic psilocybin prodrug) or other research chemicals, NOT actual mushroom extracts. Unlabeled, unknown doses, no quality control, often mislabeled.
myths.truth: NEVER trust smoke shop 'mushroom' products. Lab tests show many contain synthetic tryptamines (4-AcO-DMT, 4-HO-MET) not listed on label. Unknown doses, contamination risks, legal gray area. For educational purposes: quality-controlled sources are essential for harm reduction research. Note: Psilocybin mushroom cultivation and possession is illegal in most jurisdictions. This information is for educational understanding only, not instruction or encouragement.

myths.myth: Delta-8, Delta-10, THC-O, and HHC from gas stations are just like regular weed
myths.reality: These synthetic cannabinoids are made by chemical conversion of CBD/hemp. Often contain: heavy metals, residual solvents, unknown byproducts. THC-O is fully synthetic (not natural). Many products fail safety testing. Effects can be much stronger and more anxiety-inducing than natural THC.
myths.truth: Synthetic cannabinoids carry real risks. Many products contaminated with toxic chemicals from improper synthesis. If using cannabis, stick to tested dispensary products or natural flower. Avoid gas station/smoke shop synthetic cannabinoids.

myths.myth: Kratom is completely safe because it's natural and sold legally
myths.reality: Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) contains opioid receptor agonists. Can cause: physical dependence, withdrawal (similar to opioids), liver toxicity (rare but documented), respiratory depression (high doses or with other depressants), seizures (contaminated products).
myths.truth: Kratom has opioid-like properties and risks. Can be physically addictive. Withdrawal symptoms are real. Deaths have occurred (usually with other substances). Use cautiously, don't mix with other depressants, buy from tested vendors only, start with low doses.

myths.myth: 7-hydroxymitragynine (7-OH) extract is just concentrated kratom
myths.reality: 7-OH is 13x more potent than morphine (by some measures). Isolated alkaloid products create much higher addiction/dependence risk than whole-leaf kratom. Easier to overdose. Withdrawal more severe. Some products contain synthetic 7-OH or other adulterants.
myths.truth: 7-OH extracts are significantly more dangerous than regular kratom leaf. Higher addiction potential, severe withdrawal, easier to overdose. Stick to whole-leaf kratom if using. Avoid concentrated extracts and isolated alkaloid products.

myths.myth: Products labeled 'not for human consumption' are safe research chemicals
myths.reality: This labeling is legal loophole to sell untested, potentially dangerous substances. No quality control, purity unknown, may contain toxic byproducts or wrong substance entirely. 'Research chemical' often means 'no human safety data exists.'
myths.truth: NEVER consume products labeled 'not for human consumption.' This label exists to avoid FDA regulation, not to protect you. Unknown purity, unknown substances, no safety testing. Research chemicals are experimental—use at extreme risk.

myths.myth: Phenibut is safe because it's sold as a supplement
myths.reality: Phenibut is a GABA-B agonist (similar to baclofen). Causes physical dependence rapidly (some users after just 1-2 weeks daily use). Withdrawal can include: seizures, psychosis, severe anxiety, insomnia. Tolerance builds quickly requiring dose escalation.
myths.truth: Phenibut is NOT a safe supplement. Highly addictive, dangerous withdrawal, narrow therapeutic window. If using, maximum 2-3 times per week, never daily. Taper slowly if dependent—never cold turkey. Many countries have banned or restricted it.

myths.myth: Tianeptine (gas station opioid) is just an antidepressant supplement
myths.reality: Tianeptine sold in gas stations (brands like 'Pegasus,' 'Zaza Red') contains massive doses (100-500mg vs medical dose of 12.5-37.5mg). Acts as mu-opioid agonist at high doses. Extremely addictive, severe withdrawal (worse than many opioids), deaths documented.
myths.truth: Gas station tianeptine products are essentially unregulated opioids. Extremely addictive, brutal withdrawal, overdose risk. Multiple states have banned. AVOID entirely. If addicted, seek medical detox—withdrawal is severe and dangerous.

myths.myth: Salvia divinorum is safe because it's legal in some places and natural
myths.reality: Salvia is extremely potent kappa-opioid agonist. Causes complete dissociation from reality, loss of motor control, potential for injury, intense dysphoria common. Not recreational for most people. Psychological distress possible.
myths.truth: Salvia is legal in some areas but intensely powerful and often unpleasant. Not like other psychedelics. Most people find experience frightening. If using: have sitter, remove dangerous objects, sit/lie down before effects start, start with very low dose.

myths.myth: Kava is completely harmless because it's used traditionally
myths.reality: Kava can cause: liver toxicity (rare but serious—multiple deaths documented), dermopathy (scaly skin with chronic use), interaction with medications, potentiation of alcohol and sedatives. Traditional preparation methods may be safer than extracts.
myths.truth: Kava carries liver toxicity risk, especially concentrated extracts and supplements. Avoid if you have liver issues or take medications. Don't mix with alcohol. Traditional aqueous preparation (not extracts) considered safer. Monitor for signs of liver problems.

myths.myth: Gas station/sex shop 'male enhancement' pills are safe herbal supplements
myths.reality: FDA testing has found many contain UNDISCLOSED pharmaceuticals: sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), vardenafil (Levitra), or dangerous analogs. Often in uncontrolled doses combined with other stimulants. Can cause: dangerous blood pressure drops, heart attacks, strokes, priapism (medical emergency), fatal interactions with nitrates (heart medications).
myths.truth: NEVER use gas station sexual enhancement products. FDA has issued hundreds of warnings. Products contain hidden prescription drugs in unknown doses. Fatal if combined with nitrates (nitroglycerin, isosorbide). Can cause heart attacks, strokes, prolonged erections requiring surgery. If you need ED medication, see a doctor—legitimate prescriptions are safe and effective.

myths.myth: If a sexual enhancement product is labeled 'all natural' or 'herbal,' it doesn't contain pharmaceuticals
myths.reality: FDA lab tests repeatedly find undisclosed sildenafil, tadalafil, and analogs in products labeled 'all natural.' Some contain multiple drugs combined (e.g., sildenafil + tadalafil), which is never done medically. Labels are often completely fraudulent.
myths.truth: Labeling is meaningless for these products. FDA has found prescription ED drugs in hundreds of 'herbal' supplements. Some contain chemical analogs not approved for human use. Never trust labels on gas station/sex shop enhancement products.

myths.myth: Taking more sexual enhancement pills will work better without risks
myths.reality: These products already contain uncontrolled (often excessive) doses of pharmaceuticals. Taking multiple pills can cause: severe hypotension (dangerously low blood pressure), heart attack, stroke, seizures, priapism (requires emergency treatment), death.
myths.truth: If product contains hidden sildenafil/tadalafil, taking multiple doses is overdosing on prescription medication. Can be fatal, especially with alcohol or other drugs. Seek medical help immediately if experiencing chest pain, vision changes, prolonged erection (>4 hours), or severe headache.

myths.myth: 'Female arousal' pills and 'libido enhancers' from smoke shops are safe
myths.reality: These products also frequently contain undisclosed pharmaceuticals, stimulants, or untested chemicals. Some found to contain: yohimbine (can cause hypertension, anxiety, seizures), sildenafil, synthetic stimulants, or unknown substances. No quality control, unknown ingredients.
myths.truth: Avoid all gas station/smoke shop sexual enhancement products regardless of target gender. Many contain dangerous undisclosed stimulants or pharmaceuticals. If experiencing sexual dysfunction, consult healthcare provider for safe, tested options.

myths.myth: Sexual enhancement products are regulated by FDA because they're sold in stores
myths.reality: These products fall into regulatory gray area as 'supplements.' Manufacturers can sell them without FDA approval. FDA only acts AFTER harm occurs. Thousands of tainted products on market at any time. No pre-market testing required.
myths.truth: Sexual enhancement supplements are NOT FDA-approved and NOT regulated like medications. FDA can only issue warnings after finding problems. Being sold in stores means nothing about safety. Check FDA Tainted Supplements database before using any product.

myths.myth: Acid stays in your spinal fluid forever and can cause flashbacks years later
myths.reality: Completely false. LSD is metabolized and eliminated from body within days. HPPD (persistent perceptual changes) is real but rare, not caused by 'stored' LSD.
myths.truth: LSD doesn't remain in body long-term. HPPD is a recognized condition but mechanism is neurological adaptation, not stored drug. Flashbacks are psychological, not pharmacological.

myths.myth: Molly (powder MDMA) is purer/safer than ecstasy (pills)
myths.reality: Form doesn't indicate purity or safety. Powder can be anything (often cathinones, methylone, or meth). Pills can be anything. Both need testing.
myths.truth: 'Molly' is often NOT MDMA. Powder form is easier to fake than press into convincing pills. Test everything regardless of form.

myths.myth: Smoking DMT can't cause psychological damage because it's natural
myths.reality: Natural ≠ safe. DMT can cause severe psychological distress, PTSD-like symptoms, depersonalization/derealization, or worsen latent mental illness. Integration support important.
myths.truth: DMT is extremely powerful. While physical safety profile is good, psychological risks are real. Not for everyone. Set, setting, and integration critical.

myths.myth: Ketamine is safe because it's used in hospitals
myths.reality: Medical ketamine is pure, precisely dosed, in controlled setting. Street ketamine may be cut, contaminated, or analogues (2-FDCK). Chronic use causes bladder damage.
myths.truth: Medical use ≠ recreational safety. Test your ketamine. Chronic use causes 'K-cramps' and bladder damage (can require surgery). Limit frequency, stay hydrated.

myths.myth: Xanax is safe because it's prescribed by doctors
myths.reality: Benzodiazepines are physically addictive. Withdrawal can cause seizures and death. Street 'Xanax' is often pressed pills containing fentanyl or RC benzos (flualprazolam, etizolam).
myths.truth: Benzos have legitimate medical use but serious risks. NEVER stop cold turkey after regular use. Street 'Xanax' often contains fentanyl—test every pill.

myths.myth: Poppers (alkyl nitrites) are harmless party drugs
myths.reality: Poppers can cause: sudden drops in blood pressure, methemoglobinemia (oxygen transport disruption), vision damage (especially amyl nitrite), chemical burns. Dangerous with Viagra/Cialis (severe hypotension).
myths.truth: Poppers carry real risks. Never mix with erectile dysfunction drugs (can be fatal). Don't get on skin. Use in ventilated area. Frequent use damages blood cells.

myths.myth: You can't overdose on LSD or mushrooms
myths.reality: While lethal overdose is extremely rare, dangerous psychological reactions (psychotic breaks, dangerous behavior, HPPD) occur at high doses. Physical toxicity exists at extreme doses.
myths.truth: Psychological overdose is real and dangerous. Start low, go slow. NBOMes (often sold as LSD) CAN cause fatal overdose.

myths.myth: MDMA is safe if you stay hydrated and cool
myths.reality: While hydration and temperature management are important, MDMA has inherent risks: serotonin syndrome, hyponatremia (drinking TOO much water), cardiac stress, neurotoxicity.
myths.truth: MDMA is never 'safe.' Harm can be reduced through: testing, proper dosing (1-1.5mg/kg), limiting frequency (3 month breaks minimum), staying cool, moderate hydration.

myths.myth: Crack is more dangerous/addictive than powder cocaine chemically
myths.reality: Crack and powder cocaine are the same drug (cocaine). Crack is freebase form, powder is HCl salt. Route of administration (smoking vs snorting) affects onset/intensity, not the chemical itself.
myths.truth: Different form, same drug. Faster onset (smoking) creates more intense experience and potentially faster psychological dependence, but chemical addiction potential is identical.

myths.myth: Cannabis is completely harmless and non-addictive
myths.reality: While relatively safe, cannabis can cause: psychological dependence (~9% of users), anxiety/paranoia, cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome, impaired driving, respiratory issues (smoking), and may worsen mental health conditions.
myths.truth: Cannabis is low-risk but not zero-risk. Start low (especially edibles), avoid driving, be cautious with high-THC products, take breaks to avoid dependence.

myths.myth: Pharmaceutical drugs from a pharmacy are always safe to mix
myths.reality: Prescription drugs have dangerous interactions. MAOIs + stimulants = hypertensive crisis. SSRIs + MDMA = serotonin syndrome. Benzos + opioids = respiratory depression/death.
myths.truth: Always research drug interactions. Tell doctors ALL substances you use. Never assume 'legal' = safe to combine.

myths.myth: Putting LSD in the freezer preserves it best
myths.reality: Freezing can cause condensation when removed, degrading LSD on blotter. Temperature fluctuations and moisture are main enemies, not temperature itself.
myths.truth: Store LSD in airtight container (foil, then baggie), cool dark place (not freezer). Desiccant pack helps. Avoid light, heat, moisture, oxygen. Will stay potent for years if stored properly.

myths.myth: Old drugs just get weaker, not dangerous
myths.reality: Some substances degrade into toxic compounds. MDMA can form MDA (more neurotoxic). Some research chemicals degrade unpredictably. Degraded reagents give false results.
myths.truth: Discard old substances (>1-2 years) or test before use. Replace reagents every 6-12 months. Degraded drugs may be less effective OR more toxic.

myths.myth: You can't overdose on mushrooms you grew yourself
myths.reality: Psilocybin content varies by strain, growing conditions, and individual mushroom. Some mushrooms in same flush can be 2-3x more potent than others. Contamination possible.
myths.truth: Home-grown mushrooms still need careful dosing. Start low (1-2g dried). Potency varies. Can't visually determine psilocybin content. Weigh accurately, know your strain.

myths.myth: LSD causes chromosome damage and birth defects
myths.reality: Thoroughly debunked. Based on flawed 1960s research. Multiple subsequent studies found no chromosomal damage or increased birth defects from LSD use.
myths.truth: LSD does not damage chromosomes. However, using any drug during pregnancy is not recommended due to other potential risks.

myths.myth: Strychnine is commonly used to cut LSD blotter
myths.reality: Completely false. Strychnine is bitter and toxic at doses that would fit on blotter. No evidence of strychnine being used to cut LSD. Myth from 1960s-70s.
myths.truth: LSD blotter adulterants are typically other psychoactives (NBOMes, DOx compounds), not poisons. Test with Ehrlich reagent.

myths.myth: Ecstasy/Molly always contains meth, bath salts, or is never real MDMA
myths.reality: While adulteration is common, lab testing shows many samples do contain MDMA. Purity and cutting agents vary widely by region, source, and time.
myths.truth: Assume your 'molly' could be anything. Test with multiple reagents (Marquis, Mecke, Simon's) + fentanyl strips. Don't assume it's fake OR real—verify.

myths.myth: One use of meth/crack/heroin will instantly make you addicted
myths.reality: Addiction is a complex process involving genetics, psychology, environment, and repeated use. While these drugs have high addiction potential, one use doesn't guarantee addiction.
myths.truth: Risk factors matter: genetic predisposition, mental health, environment, frequency. That said, these substances carry very high addiction risk—avoid if possible.

bottom_line.title: Critical Takeaways
points: Question everything you hear about drugs, especially from non-expert sources
Verify claims with evidence-based organizations (Erowid, DanceSafe, NIDA, etc.)
Dangerous myths persist because they sound plausible—always fact-check
When in doubt about safety, err on the side of caution and seek medical help
Harm reduction is about making informed decisions based on facts, not myths
Share accurate information to combat dangerous misinformation in your community

news.title: Harm Reduction News & Alerts
news.description: Enable Live News Feeds below to see real-time alerts from DrugsData, FDA, DanceSafe, and other trusted sources. Add your own verified articles using the guide in ADDING_REAL_NEWS.md.

link_display_rules.warning_text: Education only. Presumptive tests ≠ lab confirmation.
